Everyone delivers a captivating performance - not a false note in the lot. It is violent & not for the feint of heart. For those of you that aren't deterred by that, sit back & enjoy. I'm just sorry that it wasn't longer.

reviewText: We're a long ways from the Young and the Restless, but that would be an equally fitting title because nobody in Westeros can stand still and few live to be old.  The soap opera is alive and well.I've never read a single word from the Martin books but darn it if I'm not packed and ready to move to Westeros.  There's seemingly naked ladies on every street corner and ten blood feuds for every man, woman and child.  Despite it's crass manor, Game of Thrones is the house guest you will likely never ask to leave.  Every week you are treated to an orgy - literally - of drinking, whoring, double-crossing, incest, murder and even the occasional magic among other skullduggery.  Tyrion has got to be the baddest dude since Omar walking the streets in a trench coat.I'm not sure how this all plays in the books, but it makes excellent television.  Game of Thrones is essentially everything missing from almost every other tv show I've seen.  Ever.  Thanks to the wealth of literature to draw from, Game of Thrones is the show every other show wants to be.  LOST wanted to be this show.  Sopranos wanted to be this show.  ROME tried like hell to be this show.  But Game of Thrones succeeds in actually presenting a solid, thoughtful, satisfying and logical story from beginning to end.  There are few random machinations of plot or characterization that do not propel the audience forward.  A ten episode season of Game of Thrones is better than 20 of most other tv shows.  It's not since BBC's Sherlock has a show made an art out of brevity.  There are more than likely throngs of book fans clamoring for clarity when such a large volume is compressed so much, but it's all the better for the tv viewer.  If I wanted everything the book offered - I'd just read the book.Season two is turning out to be a notch or two below the first season, but it was a hard act to follow after all.  Even on it's own as a standalone story - fiery cliffhanger and all - season 1 is a heck of a ride.  Seriously, stop the story right there in the sand with Daenerys and you can infer quite a bit.  Game of Thrones is preachy, over-sexed, bloody and at times, downright esoteric.  But boring?  No.  It took me two full seasons watching episodes multiple times to figure out most of who belongs to what family and all that but it never really mattered.  Dothrakis throw a mean wedding party. A Lannister always pays his debts.  A Stark is always honorable.  And though winter is coming, dragons are too.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This show is really great. I thought it was a historical medieval show when I first turned it on but I find it's much better than that. Kinda like animated series are great because the medium gives them unlimited possibilities but they can still utilize real world characterizations and stories as well. I have watched and re-watched this show and other great HBO/Premium cable shows as opposed to the disposable broadcast/basic cable shows so it's actually a lasting investment.You quickly care about most of the characters, even the bad ones, due to the great story telling that hasn't gotten dull even after 2 seasons. I like season 1 better than 2 because it is more clear cut with a clear climax and ties up more loose ends than 2 did. The locations are amazing and varied, my favorite being the Eyrie castle in the sky.The plot is more believable than the majority of "real" series on TV which have so many silly events and circumstances it's sickening(sons of anarchy, hell on wheels,etc.). This is not a soap opera like many other shows are as well. There is never any unnecessary emotional pandering or "music video" montages, annoying product placement, etc.The clever plots are wonderful to see and were clearly thought through beforehand by a thoughtful, intelligent writer and production team. A lot of this is why HBO/premium channel and other subscriber based, as opposed to advertiser based, shows are the best. I think they are even better than 99% of movies.Another great thing is that if you don't want to wait for the show you can read the great book series which I'm doing now. The books are of course much deeper and fill in a lot of the missing pieces at least for me. The show illustrates a version of the events and for me gives appropriate faces(if not all accurate to the books) to the characters as well as voices. I see the TV production and the books as one entity that gives you the full experience, especially since the author of the books is actively writing for the show but the books were done years before the show so they were not just some typical hollywood screenwriter trying to make a buck by writing what the studio bigwigs THINK/DEMAND is a salable product.RECOMMENDED!
summary: Loved it, Great Story and Action, Watched over and over, The books are great too!

reviewText: HBO does it again.  The Game of Thrones.story, for those of you who haven't read it, takes place long ago when the death of an important advisor to the king has died, setting into a series of events that will draw the 7 kingdoms of Westeros into chaos with intrigue.  Sean Bean plays Eddard Stark, the warden of he north, a noble man who is called into service for his king, a boyhood friend.  Without giving too much away, he resulting series of events sweeps every character in this incredible story not a whirlwind of betrayal and murder, leading eventually to war ( which is next season).The best way to describe the (very) sweeping epic Game of Thrones is like Lord of the Rings, only with more violence and more sex.  It is a very adult story without the usual stereotypes and plot contrivances of normal fantasy stories.  The genius of the story, other than it's sweep, is how the author, George RR Martin, keeps you on edge.  Do not get to attached to any character as he has no problem killing off even major characters.  This being HBO and a miniseries, none of the subtext is left out.  This is NOT a story for children or those with delicate sensibilities.  It is often shocking, brutal, violent, very sexual and yet thrilling and sensational.  The biggest surprise for me was Peter Dinklage as Tyrion Lanister, a man of great complexities.  The Emmy he got was well deserved.  This series will only get better as time goes on.  Do yourself a favor and check it out.
summary: Another truly great show by HBO

reviewText: This first episode of the Game of Thrones brings together a marvelous cast and pulls tidbits from multiple iconographic fantasy genere books in the canon.  I have not read the books so I cannot comment as to the accuracy of the show based upon the books.I will say it only took me a few moments to get sucked into this multi-layered and complex plot- and this is only the first episode.  It was very entertaining and what I would call 'smart'.  This is not Tolkien, this is not Dungeons and Dragons rip-off.  There are references that some who know Tolkien or played D&D; will get(according to my husband) but as someone who is not highly versed in the fantasy genre of the like, I did not feel I was on the outside looking in.  Essentially, you might appreciate some of the borrowed references but if you don't you will still find this excellent entertainment.Being an HBO production, if you do not like nudity or crude humor, swear words, etc. you may wish to take a pass on this.  Those are not my favorite elements but they do add a sort of dark realism to something that could be quite pithy in the wrong hands.The feel of this first episode is dark with the repetition of the foreshadowing: "Winter is coming".  We are introduced to numerous characters and it takes a bit to sort it out but I've gotten it pretty well figured after watching the second episode.There is a great deal of symbolism and foreshadowing in this episode and those to come which is why I think it is so brilliant.  They are subtle in many ways and parts call to mind King Lear.  You can tell the production of this series is quite epic, not unlike the story itself-  they have taken their time in creating real, believable characters in a dark times swirled together with elements of fantasy and mythology.I can't wait to watch the entire series.  Again, this is not for children (there are some brutally violent scenes, language and nudity) and, for me, the creators have made suspension of reality a little too easy when watching).  I was completely immersed.  I am also looking forward to reading the books.I agree with previous reviewers that this will become a classic tale of fantasy.  Love the young tomboy daughter who hates her needlework- I can see a heroine in the making there.Enjoy!

reviewText: This HBO series, somewhat reminiscent of The Lords of the Ring in plot and style, is based on the popular medieval fantasy books by George Martin (not the Beatles producer), The first season is basically about the struggle for power in the mythical Seven Kingdoms between two families, the evil Lannisters headed by the wife of the King, Queen Cersei (a fine performance by Lena Headey) and the more honorable Starks, who rule in the north of the realm, led by Ned Stark (a good turn as well by Sean Bean). There is a third dynasty as well, the Targaryen, related to the previous, murdered king, whose two survivors are the evil, bleach blond Viserys (a magnetic Harry Lloyd) and his beautiful, ethereal sister Daenerys (the petite Emilia Clarke, a revelation in a stunning performance). They live in exile among the savage Dothraki, a race of brutal, nomadic horse riders, and Viserys hopes that the marriage of Daenerys with their leader Khal Drogo will help him raise an army of Dothraki to invade the Seven Kingdoms, overthrow the king and put him in charge of the realm.The series benefits from some great performances. Besides those I just mentioned, I have to add Peter Dinklage as the sardonic dwarf Tyrion Lannister, brother to the queen, and Jack Gleeson as the insufferable, cruel child heir to the throne, Joffrey. Not all performances in the series are remarkable, though: most of the Starks, especially Ned's sons, fail to make much of an impression.The series has a very good start, then somewhat loses steam in the middle episodes, but rises again in the last two chapters for a rousing finale. I quite enjoyed the series, but I cannot call it a masterpiece. One problem that the many characters and the various, convoluted plots make it confusing at times. Some plot threads, especially the one in the frontier, could have been excised completely and the series would not have suffered. The stunning photography and locations certainly helps.
summary: Great entertainment, though it falls just short of being a masterpiece

reviewText: Another reviewer commented that there's not much "story" here and that what "story" there is has been juiced up, so to speak, with gratuitous sex and violence. I disagree. There is a good "story" here. A story that deals with honor and familial bond and vengeance and the cost of revenge, not only within a family, but to an entire realm. This "story" also explores what it means to be "high born" or "low born." How luck plays a part in life's trials and tribulations. How youth can be foolish and brash. How oldsters can hold on to grudges that destroy lives for generations. I agree that in the series there's a lot of gratuitous nudity, particularly of young women. If it wasn't gratuitous we'd see more male nudity, more nude old men and women, nude fat people, etc. I was disturbed by the casual references to the use of young boys, and other perversions like incest. But the truth is the royal families of Europe historically participated in all sorts of debauchery, and sexual lechery; as did (and does) the Catholic church with all it's pedophile priests. So there's plenty of pure story here. So much so, you could delete the scenes of violence and sex and still enjoy this series. (I, in fact, ofter turn away from the violence and the sex (actually close my eyes and plug my ears against the sound of flesh being cut or seared) then peak to continue watching "the story" continue. The young girl Arya's in particular. What a tough fearless little girl. I want to follow her "story" to the end.

reviewText: The new golden age of television continues with this absolutely spectacular HBO series, based on the brilliant writing of George R.R. Martin.  You cannot help but be drawn into the bleak, yet richly colorful world of these fantasy/medieval style characters when the writing is this good and the actors so unforgettable.  The sets are often exquisitely beautiful, and the costumes dazzling.  At times the whole looks like pre-Raphaelite painting. ----  Having not read the books, I was now and then  confused as to who is who.  But I came to realize that the series would eventually give me all the information I needed to remain fully engaged and fully delighted.  --- There isn't a false note in the cast, nor a false line in the dialogue.  And one has the feeling, no matter how fantastic the kingdoms and their warring monarchs, that one is delving into our history and our evolution as a moral species.  Speculative fiction at its best --- which this most certainly is ---  is always about us and always about us now as well as "long ago."  Games of Thrones is setting a whole new standard for daring, complexity, and sumptuous execution of the vision.  Highly recommended.
summary: Fantasy at its finest: more of the new golden age of television.

reviewText: Both this show, and this blu ray set, are incredible!  I'd never seen Game of Thrones before purchasing the blu ray, and it is one of the best purchases I've made; I've already watched all of the blu rays multiple times, and they definitely hold up after multiple viewings!The blu rays themselves are great quality in terms of picture, sound, etc.  It's also wonderful to have the complementary digital copies of both the episodes and bonus features (for me, that allows me to easily watch my favorite scenes {like those between Daenerys and Drogo}) whenever I want just a little taste. I will warn you that these particular digital copies do take a really long time to download to iTunes (I purchased this season and Season 2 http://www.amazon.com/Game-Thrones-Complete-Blu-ray-Digital/dp/B0060MYM7O/ref=sr_1_1_ha?ie=UTF8&qid;=1368277573&sr;=8-1&keywords;=game+of+thrones+season+2+blu+ray at the same time, and my computer was literally downloading for over a week without pause).Bottom line, I can't imagine anyone being disappointed by this purchase! There's nothing that I can see not to recommend the show, and the blu rays are top quality. Great storylines, great acting, terrific characters including plenty of strong female leads. I can see this show appealing to all ages (well, teenagers and all ages of adults; I don't think the content is appropriate for children). When you consider the fact that they literally created a new language (Dolthraki) for the show as opposed to creating just a few words for the actors to say, you have to imagine that a lot of effort was put into making this show, and it definitely pays off. It's wonderful to see such a high quality fantasy show that both remains relevant in our time, and is highly entertaining..definitely recommended!

reviewText: Let me start off by saying that I hadn't seen this show until I purchased it on Blu-ray based on consumer reviews.  One star might be a bit harsh, but I have to counterbalance all of the ridiculously high 5-star ratings this show has received.  Seriously, there's nothing amazing about it.  Sure, the scale of it is grand, but the pace moves like a snail throughout most of it.  In fact, the first 4-5 episodes are a total bore.  There are endless conversations that serve no purpose, as well as many controversial elements that seem to exist for no other reason than shock value or titilation: full-frontal nudity, incest, gay sex, lesbian sex, even kids killing kids.  And the graphic, gorey deaths are not limited to just humans: there are plenty of animals slaughtered in bloody detail.  I'm not offended by any of it, although I could do without the onscreen violence toward animals.  I didn't mind similar elements in HBO's series "Rome" because they seemed to support the story more or could be supported by history.  In GOT, however, most of them felt gratuitous as if HBO said to the creative team, "Hey, we're HBO so we have to have these things, so find a way to throw them in."After 10 episodes, I don't feel anything for any of the characters.  I couldn't care less who sits on the throne of the Seven Kingdoms, and that's the real problem with the show.  If I cared about the characters, I'd be interested in the events of future seasons, but since watching this season was a chore I have no interest in putting more $$$ in HBO's pocket.

reviewText: This series, based on Martin's "A Song of Fire and Ice" double trilogy, is unparalleled in just about every category one would look for in a show.  Be it the writing, directing, casting, acting, wardrobe, or set production, you won't be let down.  In fact, not only won't you be let down, but you're in for a visual treat, and one that grips you emotionally.  You'll laugh, cry, and in every way blown away by how well the show is put together.Very basically, the show is about the King's throne, and who will out maneuver whom to get their family, or someone in their family to the top, to be King. You'll watch with rapt attention how the choices each of the 10 or so major characters affect the rest of the world.  Peter Linklage absolutely dominates his role as "the Imp"--the youngest son of the richest family in what they refer to as "the 7 Kingdoms," and just dares you to root against him as he is the dwarf son of the patriarch of the Lannister family.As amazingly acted as this show is, it's hard to find even a single flaw in the entire show.  If the show has any weaknesses, it would be in trying to pass 20 something year old actors as 14 and 15 year olds, and, if you want to call it a weakness, there are only 10 shows per season and as the show keeps delivering one of the most epic, addictive performances, I've found it hard, personally, not to watch the 20+ episodes which have been made because you'll always be yearning for more.For the parents, I would strongly suggest you watch an episode before allowing anyone under the age of 13 from watching as you might find yourself forced into having "the talk" with them long before you want to. When they warn you about the sex, nudity, and violence, they're not kidding.  There's plenty of each, however none are used gratuitously.  They're used as needed to show the character of each, well, each character.So, pros would be: Acting, Directing, Production, Writing, Costuming/Wardrobe, make-up, special effects.The negatives would be: only 10 shows a season, only available through either pay-cable, or pay-amazon, though quite honestly, it's worth every penny, and, for those who've read the books, the age-inappropriate casting.  Since the very first episode I was highly dubious when I saw 2 characters who, in the books, are only 14 and 15, but both arrive sporting beards any 30 year old would envy, and a girl who's supposed to be 12 looking closer to 20 than 12.  With that being its worst flaw (and quite explicable by saying, quite simply, the show was never meant to be exactly the same as the books.  Those who haven't read the books won't even notice it), again, it's a show without equal.To sum up, it's as I said in the title.  In my opinion, to date, this is the very best show ever made for the small screen.  The scope of the story, and the glorious visuals just beg you to watch the show with a projector so you can watch it on a 120" screen.  The producers spared no expense in making this show everything it could be.  Other than giving us 20 hours of viewing per season instead of 10, I'm not altogether certain there's anything which could've been done better.
summary: Not just the best SciFi/Fantasy show ever made, but perhaps the best show ever made in ANY genre

reviewText: "Game of Thrones" is a very well produced, filmed and written series. The cast is tremendous......Each episode draws the viewer into an interesting world of Seven Kingdoms.....At times it reminds me too much of the Lord of the Rings movies especially a decidedly older Sean Bean as Lord Ned Stark....the sex in this series while frequent and sometimes violent gets tiring after awhile....At times I wondered if it was necessary to show in the first place. Some might argue the violence and the "gore" that results is just "the way it was" in medieval times....Again, I found it tiring after awhile. The drama itself and the story are so intriguing and engaging that I continued to watch, but I thought the sex and gore were just "dull: after awhile. I thought the series could stand alone without it them. I don't think HBO or the media have to overdo such scenes to draw an audience. I don't get the allure myself, but then, noone seems to have an imaginationthese days....so it has to be be on the screen...Else....who would watch? Oh my!

reviewText: George R.R. Martin's A SONG OF ICE AND FIRE is the most critically-acclaimed work of epic fantasy since THE LORD OF THE RINGS. Over the course of five very large books, it has amassed a large, international fan following. With its adult content, mature themes and focus on well-motivated characters, only HBO was capable of bringing the project to the screen, and fans were delighted when it was announced that they would indeed be handling this adaptation.GAME OF THRONES has to work on two levels: to satisfy the existing fans of the books and also to rope in many new readers unfamiliar with the novels. Broadly speaking, it succeeds. The budget is huge but not infinite and there have been compromises over cost. Most notably, armies rarely feel like they consist of more than 20 people and the direwolves do more closely resemble big dogs than ferocious animals from myth. But on almost every other level the show is a huge success.The casting is almost flawless. Sean Bean brings his world-weary, craggy looks to the role of Eddard Stark and effectively plays him as an older warrior haunted by the decisions of his past. Mark Addy may only be a fraction of the size of Robert Baratheon from the books, but this is forgotten as he nails Robert's ferocious attitude, mixed with a love of wine and women but an unhealthy obssession with the past (which takes the phrase 'rose-tinted spectacles' to a new level). Nikolaj Coster-Waldau nails Jaime's arrogance, whilst Maisie Williams, Isaac Hempstead Wright and Sophie Turner play their roles as the Stark children to perfection. Jack Gleeson sells Joffrey's cruel brutality with aplomb, whilst Conleth Hill is Varys from the books, simply stepped onto the screen and played with total conviction. Likewise superb is Iain Glen as Jorah Mormont, who provides able support to newcomer Emilia Clarke as Daenerys. Clarke has arguably the toughest role of the cast, moving from scared young girl to confident ruler, but manages the task ably. Jason Momoa has little to do as taciturn warlord Khal Drogo, but comes to life in two highly memorable scenes later in the season, whilst Harry Lloyd brings the requisite amount of demented charm to the role of Viserys (one of the few characters much-improved in the transition from book to screen).Michelle Fairley, Lena Headey and Aidan Gillen are also effective as their characters of Catelyn Stark, Cersei Lannister and Littlefinger, but these roles are the ones most notably changed from the book. Catelyn is more predictably reactive than in the books, whilst Cersei has been softened somewhat. More controversial are the changes to Littlefinger, reduced from the master schemer and conniver of the books to a shifty brothel-owner who inexplicably entrusts his motivations to prostitutes he's just met. Gillen does good work in the role, but the Littlefinger of the TV series is a shadow of that in the books.Do we need to say anything of Peter Dinklage as Tyrion save that he is absolutely brilliant? True, he sometimes struggles with the accent, but after a while it ceases to matter (and Tyrion over-enunciating himself to make sure everyone knows he's a noble is something that the character would do) and his Emmy/Golden Globe-winning performance is riveting throughout. His acting partners - Jerome Flynn as Bronn and, in the last two episodes, Sibel Kekilli as Shae - provide able support in his storyline. And of course Charles Dance is just perfect as Tywin Lannister, taking method to a new level when he guts a real (dead) stag live on screen whilst delivering a monologue about his house's power. Kit Harington also makes for an effective Jon Snow, with the other members of the Night's Watch also portrayed with skill (a special mention for Owen Teale as Alliser Thorne, who is much less of a two-dimensional villain than in the books and on-screen becomes someone who, whilst antagonistic, neverthless has a plausible motivation).The writing is, for the most part, decent. Many scenes from the book are translated to the screen with vigour and skill. There are also several new scenes, such as a revelatory conversation between Robert and Cersei, which adds more depth to the story. The biggest issue is with the sex and nudity in the series. Not that it's there - this is a HBO show after all and the books are hardly lacking in it - but that it is often used as a crutch to support scenes of exposition and that it is frequently badly-written. The worst scene of the season is the aforementioned 'Littlefinger explains his character backstory to some random prostitutes' scene, which is cringe-inducing (despite Gillen and Esme Bianco's attempts to sell the dialogue). Whilst these scenes are relatively rare, they do slow the narrative and take time away from more compelling matters elsewhere.Elsewhere, the effects are solid, the (Emmy Award-winning) opening title sequence is amazing and the musical score highly effective.The Blu-Ray presentation is also second to none. The picture quality is crisp and shows off the superb set design and excellent cinematography. The special features are stunning, with particular praise reserved for the in-universe documentaries about the Great Houses (voiced by the castmembers). The episode commentaries are also enjoyable, though not as packed with information as might be wished.Overall, this is a superior season of television, although not quite up there with HBO's best. As (disclosure) the creator of the GAME OF THRONES Wiki and a moderator on Westeros.org I was predisposed to enjoy the series anyway, but in some areas HBO exceeded all my expectations. The weaker elements - the more pointless scenes of sexposition and the entire absence of the powerful flashback scenes, such as the tower of joy sequence (probably the best scene in the book) - are regrettable but, so far, minor.
summary: Despite some minor issues, a strong season of television

reviewText: I heard the reviews for Game of Thrones, yet originally dismissed the miniseries based upon several misconceptions.  True, this is not overtly centered around fantasy elements despite being part of the genre; and yes, there is an abundance of political drama.  However,  HBO and George R.R. Martin have succeeded in creating some of the most riveting characters and suspenseful narration ever witnessed in film.  If you have even a remote interest in dark fantasy, Game of Thrones is the best miniseries ever created.Acting is phenomenal across the board. Recognizable actors/actresses and newcomers alike never miss their mark.  From children to adults, not a single line is delivered without conviction.  The intensity with which you will come to love, or loathe each character is testament to the writing and skillful acting that brings each character to life.  Brace yourself for a rollercoaster of emotions.This is truly an adult series, and if you shy away from extreme violence or blunt sexuality and nudity - you will not enjoy Game of Thrones.  Yet for those who are not put off, I can say that nothing feels forced.  Instead, it feels like a much grittier, natural depiction of the time period and setting.I will not delve into specific episodes, because I honestly enjoyed each of the (10) 50-54 min long episodes equally.  However, there is something to be said about a 10 hour miniseries that is consistent throughout.  In fact, it was difficult to watch less than 3-4 episodes at a time.  Witnessing several stories unravel at once akin to Lord of the Rings was deeply engaging.  George R.R. Martin stated in several interviews he was influenced by J.R.R Tolkien and H.P. Lovecraft, and it shows.  The ghastly White Walkers invoke an almost preternatural fear from their domain behind the Wall, and the characters and backstories are dynamic and unique.Regarding bluray player playback - I also own an Oppo BDP-83, which a few reviewers claim has issues playing the bluray version of Game of Thrones.  I did have to shut off the system and turn it back on several times.  However, once it registered the disc I only had to wait about 15 sec.  Such a minor inconvenience is not even noteworthy considering how revolutionary this series is, and how FANTASTIC it looks and sounds on bluray.  This is nothing new either.  As bluray discs are compressed more, it is inevitable that the players will need additional software updates.  You can't blame HBO for releasing the bluray with better visual and sound quality.George R.R. Martin has said there will be 7 books in the series, and is currently writing the 6th.  I can say, without a doubt, that if HBO continues to live up to its own standards - this will be a collection for the ages.  More than Harry Potter, or any other series - I will look forward to the next installment.Game of Thrones should be placed next to the word EPIC in the dictionary. These four letters can sum up my entire review.HBO, thank you.
summary: BELIEVE the Reviews.  Words Cannot Describe the Greatness of HBO's Game of Thrones

reviewText: Game of Thrones stands alone on the pinnacle of made-for-cable series-making.  Beautiful production values, cinematic scope, detailed creation of a fantastical world, and gorgeous acting (and actors) all make this a must-see as well as simply a joy to experience--even in the violent bits, which are (mostly) not gratuitous.  I cannot praise this series enough.  If you have read these books by George R. R. Martin, then you are already a fan, and if not, you are just missing out.  The only flaw is that there are not enough behind the scenes or commentaries with the Special Features.  The commentaries there are (every other episode basically) are disappointing and lame for the most part.  The best commentary is the one with the Stark children actors, and WARNING:  Lena Headey (Cersei Lannister) says the F-word every other sentence during her comments.  She is beautiful, but her language and the quality of her commentary are not.  I'm a complete GoT fan and wanted insights, which to my mind, repeated "[insert actor's name here] is F-ing awesome" isn't.  But don't let that put you off if you're considering buying this.  The series itself stands alone in its excellence.
summary: What Can I Say?  It's Awesome!

reviewText: Rarely does a TV series or movie match the greatness of the book.  The Game of Thrones TV Series is the exception. Great acting, great casting, set and scenery match well with details in the book series. The one advantage that the Game of Thrones TV Series has over the books is that the plots are more streamlined and move faster than in the books. Certain details are left out but do not impact the story in a negative way. All of it looks fantastic in the Blu-ray format by the way.  The only minor criticism I have is that I wish there was a separate disk with all of extra features and not scattered over all of the disks.
summary: Great Series to Match a Great Book

reviewText: Having read most the Game of Thrones books I was very happy to be able to get to watch these on Amazon Prime. Usually a lot is left out of TV made from long books and true there is some small details missing, but overall these are very very well done. reviewText: Update: If you did not see the series on HBO, I strongly recommend getting the DVDs for the season rather than watching them on line from Amazon or Netflix. I watched the first season and there was so much I missed because I did not have a firm grasp on the relations between the characters. All the little family trees helped, but not much. I watched the complete first season over again, and it made far more sense. I did not attend to the "extras" in the review. I suggest they are "fair to good". There is a voice-over commentary for almost all episodes, except that the quality is uneven. If the writer(s), director, or producer are commenting, the value is very good. If, as in the second episode, the commentary is by three child actors, the commentary is almost worthless, unless you have an adolescent in your audience.Given all the other reviews, it is hard for me to think of anything new to say about this celebrated HBO series which as some strong similarities to the 2 season historical drama "Rome". It seems the writer has "borrowed" a bit from just about everyone, most heavily relying on the real history of the Plantagenets and the War of the Roses, although there is little evidence that the dialogue owes anything to Shakespeare's great plays about that history. Of course, there is also a strong flavoring of Tolkien, as if you needed Sean Bean (Boromir in LOTR) in the lead role of Ned Stark to tell you that.When I began watching, I had high expectations, which were temporarily deflated through the third to about the seventh episode. I yearned for more back story, which the narrative gave out in drips and drabs. I anticipated that the king would die in some way during the first season, and the fact that Sean Bean does not reappear in season 2 give away some of the plot.Another element which enlivened my interest is that Peter Dinklage's character, Tyrian Lannister, begins to appear more regularly by episode 7, and starts having an active effect on events. Even in this season, there is no mystery to why Dinklage got several acting awards for his role in this series. Aside from Bean and Dinklage, the acting is sound, if not necessarily inspired. If I were to identify one actor and role I began to anticipate, it was Emilia Clarke, who plays the exiled Daenerys Targaryen.The season succeeded in what may have been its two primary objectives. I am now anxious to see what happens in Season 2 (especially to see more of Dinklage) and to buy some of the books by George R. R. Martin, on which the series is based. It is this deep history which made Tolkien's books so magical and which works for Martin's story as well.
summary: Another pseudo-Medieval story, with a strong pull

reviewText: I debated wether I should watch this or not as I was afraid it would ruin the magic of the books for me (the first three anyway). But I was pleasantly surprised. The series stayed pleasingly close to the books and when it deviated it usually did so by omission of detail and not by making up new material (I hated that in the LOTR movies).A lot of people seem to complain about the gratuitous sex scenes, it's a sign of our askew view that apparently a naked breast or penis offends people whereas a full frontal beheading appears to be fine. I never got that, why is sex worse then violence? Well there is plenty of both in this series (books and show) and that's just fine with me.Where in my opinion it falls a little short is scenes that show armies or mass events like drogos wedding. The problem is that in the books you read about 10000nds of participants whereas in the show you see a hundred at best in very carefully choreographed and narrow shots. The fastness of the events and/or landscapes isn't captured too well, but that is most likely a concession to budget.All in all, good acting, close adaptation of the book and a good flow through the 10 installments of the show make this a four star series for me...

reviewText: I absolutely love this series, and watching it in 1080p makes it even better. The shows so beautiful, that it makes me wish DirecTV had more shows in 1080p instead of just the pay-per-view movies. At the original price I wasn't going to buy this as I had it saved on my DVR, but when it went down to 35 dollars I had to pick it up. I've read the books and already loved the story, so there's not much to complain about here as they stay relatively faithful. However, it is a little annoying to have awesome characters killed off, almost more so in a TV show as I wasn't used to losing main characters. Also, the whole Daenerys Targaryen storyline is so frustrating, it's hard to believe she's so gullible, but I understand it was done to move the plot line along. The acting, sets, and costume design are all superb in this show, it's hard to find anything wrong with it. I think the show should be watched by both people that like fantasy, and people that might not care for fantasy stories but love character drama. After watching it one more time in full HD, I can't wait for the start of the second season.

reviewText: I have recently watched the first seasons of two shows that I thought were really excellent. Both were way above what I have generally come to expect from television. The first was this show (Game of Thrones for those who have already forgotten what product page they are looking at) and the other wasJustified: The Complete First Season. I do not think that it is a coincidence that both were based on novels (Game of Thrones was, of course, based on the novels by George R.R. Martin, and Justified was based on novels by Elmore Leonard). I think that novelists often have more freedom than television writers. They can make their characters more ambiguous and interesting and they can make their story lines darker. They do not have to pander as much and as a result, shows that base themselves on novels, wind up being way more interesting as a general rule (there are exceptions).That is certainly true about this show. The show has a whole host of really interesting characters. Way too many to list. The web of characters is quite complex but they are all drawn so well, each character is so unique and distinctive, that the viewer never gets confused about who is who. The show also has a pretty dark story line. I will not give any specifics away for those who have not watched the first season yet but the show does not shy away from allowing good people to die. The politics of the show are complex. It is really an adult show. Not only due to its complexity but also because there is a lot of violence and nudity. I applaud HBO for not ironing out all the complexity, or removing all the violence and nudity, in order to appeal to the widest possible audience.The complexity is really part of what makes this such an engaging show. There are so many characters, and the show shifts between story lines, and it always leaves each story line at a critical moment so that the audience is dying to get back to that story line. Sometimes when a show, or a movie, has multiple story lines going at once, some of the story lines wind up being way more interesting than others, and the viewer winds up feeling like they just have to get through one story line so that they can get back to the more interesting story lines. This show manages to produce multiple story lines (Robb Stark, Arya Stark, Sansa Stark, Tyrion Lannister, Jon Snow, and Daenarys Targaryen all have their own story lines) and they are all equally interesting and engaging. I have never seen a show that I thought was as successful in weaving various story lines together. That is part of what makes the show so addictive. Even when you are watching Daenerys' story line, or Arya's story line, you are eager to get back to Jon Snow's story line, or Tyrion's story line, etc.. It really is a fantastic achievement.I have not actually read the Martin books this show is based on but it is clear to me that Martin was successful in creating a really interesting and believable alternate world which this show brings to life. Watching the show is an immersive experience not unlike reading the Lord of the Rings. I doubt that any fantasy writer will ever be as successful as J.R.R. Tolkien in creating an alternate world but Martin deserves praise for what he has accomplished with Game of Thrones. It is the details that really make it feel like a genuine world. For example, the Northern wall, the new and old gods, the fact that Winter comes rarely and at unpredictable times, the various cultures, the death of the dragons, etc.. There is an entire mythology operating in all of those details. I am actually not a huge fantasy enthusiast. I have read very few fantasy novels, but I understand the appeal of escaping to another world, and this show allows the viewer to escape into another world for an hour at a time (or more, if you are like me, and cannot stop at just one).There are two more things that the show does particularly well. First, it sets up some really evil villains. All of the Lannisters, with the possible exception of Tyrion, are genuinely detestable. They are villains that the viewer loves to hate and the hope that they will eventually get their comeuppance is more than enough to keep the viewer watching. Second, the show sets up some really interesting mysteries. What is happening north of the wall? Are we going to see the White Walkers? Are the dragons going to return? I love it when shows set up mysteries like that. I don't think I have ever watched a show that has been as successful as this one at creating a sense of unrequited anticipation in me. I am dying to see the White Walkers. The fact that we just hear stories about the White Walkers, without seeing them (at least in the first season) was genius. However interesting the White Walkers wind up being if, and when, we see them, seeing them cannot compete with the mystery (What are they?).The show is extremely addictive. I have to be careful starting an episode because I can never stop after just one. Or two. Or three (let's be honest). This is certainly one the most interesting, and well written, shows I have ever seen. Here is my advice to television studios: make more show adaptations of novels. You already have a solid set of characters to start with, and a story, and the show is almost guaranteed to be edgier and more interesting than anything that was developed for television (there are, of course, exceptions, like Breaking Bad, which I have heard is quite good and edgy). The success of shows like Game of Thrones, Justified, and Dexter (which was also based on graphic novels) prove that audiences crave good writing, interesting characters, and dark story lines, and are willing to follow shows with some moral complexity and ambiguity. So that is my advice for television studios. Here is my advice for viewers: watch this show! (unless you hate good writing, or are too busy saving the world to be sucked into an alternate universe for a few hours at a time).

reviewText: When Game Of Thrones starts out focuses in on the Stark royal family of Winterfell, the northernmost land of an island in political turmoil.  You quickly get inundated in who's who and the intrigue going on, then we see there are other threads going on and the story is widened to a whole world.  Sean Bean as the noble Eddard Stark is such a great character and we cringe as we see him get sucked into a political whirlpool that quickly has him over head and lost in the corruptions far from his northern homeland of Winterfell, and it makes us care deeply for the rest of his family as they get turned into the arch enemies of the evil Lannister family, oddly whose best character is the outcast dwarf son Tyrion Lannister, the best character in the whole series.The story is marvelous, as are the characters.  HOWEVER, for me as the plot unfolds and the story goes on, a mystical thread starts to appear, a fantasy concerning dragons and magic ... pretty much stuff I don't really care for ... HOWEVER, the production, writing, characters, acting, effects and story is all so good I am hooked, even though I don;t really like to get involved so much in such silly fantasy stories.Season 3 will cap that for me, as I will have to make a decision whether to follow the story into this fantastic silliness, or be happy for the two first seasons that were really spectacular and so well done.
summary: So great that I'd like to give it a 5, but ....

reviewText: George R.R. Martin's bloodthirsty fantasy novels have found their home on HBO in Game of Thrones. An epic, sprawling story full of memorable characters and sinister events, it quickly sweeps you up into its complicated world while reminding you that not all fantasy is as innocent as Narnia.White walkers have not been seen in centuries, but the Guardians of the Wall fear their return with the approaching winter. Summer has lasted for ten years and the cold is coming. But of more immediate concern is the news that the King's advisor has died, and he comes to Winterfell to invite Lord Stark (Sean Bean) the position, much to the concern of Lady Stark (Michelle Fairley), who fears her husband's absence will mean misfortune for them all. King Baratheon's presence in the northern kingdom brings unease when his wife Cersei (Lena Headey) is discovered by Lord Stark's son as having a "special relationship" with her twin brother Jamie (Nikolaj Coster-Waldau). The boy is thrown from an upper window and the family is left to deal with the horrific consequences.Lord Stark's illegitimate son Jon (Kit Harrington) travels north to take the black cloth and become a Guardian of the Wall, and strikes up an unlikely friendship with Cersei's older brother, Tyrion (Peter Dinklage). Meanwhile, across the Narrow Sea, the official heir to the throne is seeking out means of reclaiming his kingdom. Viserys (Harry Lloyd) has arranged a marriage between his sister Daenerys (Emilia Clarke) to Khal Drogo (Jason Momoa), a chieftain lord who has promised to help him reclaim his throne. But as the two armies prepare for war and unravel a shocking plot of betrayal and murder, an ancient evil rises in the north...In purely cinematic terms, Game of Thrones is a masterpiece. It creates a fascinating and dangerous world in which an unforgettable cast of characters dwell. Some we love, and others we love to hate, but none of them leave us with a lack of emotion. The detail and setting is immaculate and the cast is incredibly strong, ranging from the big-screen names mentioned here to later appearances by such individuals as Aidan Gillen, whose character proves more interesting than most, the lynchpin that drives all, a clever man who is more than he seems (one early prophetic line of dialogue has him telling Lord Stark, "not trusting me was the wisest thing you have done since you got off your horse") and Charles Dance. But the tagline of this series is "don't get too attached," and that proves true: in these stories, no one is safe and before the end, some of our favorite characters will die.Sean Bean is the main driving force of this first season, and arguably its strongest point. This is assisted by the fact that he is the "leading character" but it is hard not to come to love him for the smaller things, such as the pride he takes in watching his youngest daughter learn to handle a sword. He is also one of the few truly "good" men involved, since elsewhere we have fornicators, rapists, warlords, and pimps. Unfortunately, the fantastic storytelling comes with a heavy dose of violence, sex, and nudity, along with the not-so-occasional f-word. Sometimes, it is to further the plot, but most of the time it is simply there to be controversial. In certain ways, for me at least, it also diminished the overall experience.I cannot say that this series is enjoyable, because in many ways it is heart-wrenching, but it creates a unique world that I have never experienced before but am eager to experience again, and that in of itself is a remarkable accomplishment.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Storyline: Seven noble families fight for control of the mythical land of Westeros. Political and sexual intrigue is pervasive. Robert Baratheon, King of Westeros, asks his old friend Eddard, Lord Stark, to serve as Hand of the King, or highest official. Secretly warned that the previous Hand was assassinated, Eddard accepts in order to investigate further. Meanwhile the Queen's family, the Lannisters, may be hatching a plot to take power. Across the sea, the last members of the previous and deposed ruling family, the Targaryens, are also scheming to regain the throne. The friction between the houses Stark, Lannister and Baratheon, and with the remaining great houses Greyjoy, Tully, Arryn, and Tyrell, leads to full-scale war. All while a very ancient evil awakens in the farthest north. Amidst the war and political confusion, a neglected military order of misfits, the Night's Watch, is all that stands between the realms of men and icy horrors beyond.I'm really glad I purchased the DVD for this program - trying to keep track of seven intriguing families in a medieval setting can be quite a stretch, and really needs to be viewed more than once. The 'Episode Guide', included with the boxed set, and features family trees, is a real help. Add a little 'fantasy' to the story, and the production becomes even more interesting.The HBO production is First Rate. The sets are done in a semi-permanent method, and locations are in several different countries, including Iceland. Sets, locations, acting, costumes and make-up all show the attention to detail that is needed to make a believable project.  "Pillars of the Earth" and "World Without End" are two other recent efforts (Tandem Productions/Sony Pictures Home Entertainment) that also show what can be done to provide great entertainment.My favorite actor in this series has got to be Peter Dinklage, who plays Tyrion Lannister, and is often referred to as 'The Imp' due to his 'short stature'. He is thought to be a hedonistic fool, but he is really nobody's fool. He is the canniest character of the bunch, and always seems to maneuver himself into the most advantageous position. He is hedonistic, but that just adds to the fun of watching a good actor. His acting prowess in the first season, earned him much higher billing in the second.

reviewText: I haven't read the George R.R. Martin set of books that this HBO series is based on.  I don't usually like fantasy fiction. But I have now ordered the entire set of books -Song Of Ice and Fire Hardcover Box Set featuring A Game of Thrones, A Clash of Kings, A Storm of Swords, and A Feast for Crows (Amazon Exclusive)andA Dance with Dragons (A Song of Ice and Fire, Book 5)and I plan on reading them very soon.The HBO series is one of the best productions - television or otherwise - that I have seen. We don't have HBO on our TV so I just rented the series.  What an entertaining last couple of days I've had, watching the first season straight through.Cinematography, special/visual effects, writing, editing, costuming, historical validity, musical score, setting, mapping, sound - all are fabulous.And the casting - wow! Each and every person was perfect for their role.  Like everyone else, I think, I loved Peter Dinklage in his role as Tyrion Lannister.  There are definitely many reasons he won an Emmy and a Golden Globe for this role, plus was nominated for and won many more. Sean Bean as Eddard Stark - perfect.  Emilia Clarke as Daenerys Targaryen - gorgeous AND perfect for the role. Jack Gleeson as Joffrey Baratheon - slimy and perfect in the role. I don't think I've ever seen a production of this size that was cast as well (thumbs up to Nina Gold, casting director).This is definitely an adults-only production.  Lots of nudity, sexual situations, incest, foul language, violence - it has it all. But it doesn't feel gratuitous.  It feels like I was plunked down to wander these kingdoms and was seeing life as it really was back then.I don't know how well this show follows the books.  I have heard and read from others that the producers/director, with the author's help, did a superior job.  I am anxious for season two and I am also very excited to read the books myself.Do whatever you need to watch "Game of Thrones" if you haven't yet.  I can't believe you will be disappointed.
summary: Excellent, excellent, excellent - oh, did I say excellent?

reviewText: If you haven't watched Game of Thrones... for shame!  If you have, then you really should be interested in this great Blu-Ray set.  The price is currently $39.99 (I mention this because other sets have gone up in price as they become scarce).  Hopefully this set will be in print for awhile.As most of you know, this series is based on the novels by George 'I hate Twitter' R.R. Martin.  The first season here follows the first novel pretty faithfully - which should appease some of you LOTR and Hobbit film haters (which deviated GREATLY from their novels).  Warning: have a strong stomach for blood, gore, violence, and nudity.  And now that I've gotten most of you readers interested...The story is simple, yet the characters and interactions are complex.  Martin created a pretty basic world without a lot of 'fleshing out', letting the story take it's own path and revealing little bits of lore and history here and there.  But he did spend a TON of time planning the families, their histories, their interactions, and so on.  People in Westeros are pretty rotten for the most part - which really makes you develop love-hate relationships.  It's great because when a main character is killed off, the viewer isn't really too sad about losing a really great hero - but more upset about losing an interesting character.The Blu-Ray is stunning, and a lot can be said about seeing this series in HD.  Granted, some of the effects can come off as a bit cheesy... I mean this is HBO budget, not Hollywood blockbuster budget... but the scenery and the sets are quite good.  Costuming is also top quality.  This is a series which is a delight in full HD.  So splurge on the Blu-Ray over the original DVD release.The set comes with tons of extras (listed from box):15 Character profile clipsCreating the Dothraki languageInside the Night's Watch From Book to ScreenCreating the ShowOpen 7 Audio Commentaries Guide to WesterosComplete Guide to WesterosIn-Episode GuideAnatomy of an EpisodeHidden Dragon EggsBottom line?  A great series with excitement, twists and turns, complex plots and betrayals, violence, and - most importantly - interesting and enjoyable characters - even if most of them are pretty self serving!  Enjoy!

reviewText: Why does anyone need a review for Game of Thrones. Either you love it or you hate it, probably the former, possibly both. But if you are somehow on the fence, here are my comments.- This series is extremely graphic, both in terms of violence and in terms of sex content. I have no hard feelings towards those who call Game of Thrones "elf porn". Both forms of graphic content often feel gratuitous, or included just for the shock factor. Game of Thrones is more "gritty and visceral" than "elegant", I would say.- This series is interpersonally and morally very rich. The protagonists are by and large very complex people, and they create some very fascinating situations. This character complexity is to me the main appeal of the series.- The music, visuals, and acting are top-notch, as good as anything you've watched. This series is a real tribute to Martin's books (actually... series 1 is just the first book), and I'm grateful for the precedent it sets for production quality of fantasy TV serieses.

reviewText: You win, or you die.  That also applies to risky new shows.  HBO took a big gamble with this show.  And it looks like they've won.This is the HBO adaption of George R. R. Martin's best-selling epic, A Song of Ice and Fire.  A Game of Thrones is the first book in the series, and they have named the show accordingly.  So far, five books out of the planned seven volumes have been published.  The first show season covered the events in the first book.Sean Bean heads the stellar cast.  He plays the role of Eddard Stark, Lord of Winterfell.  He receives an offer from King Robert to take up the position of Hand of the King.  A position recently made vacant by the death of their former mentor, Lord Jon Arryn.  The King's Hand administers the country on behalf of the reigning monarch.  Eddard, known as Ned, takes half of his family down south to the capital, King's Landing.  Meanwhile, across the Narrow Sea, a marriage deal has been brokered between Princess Daenerys and Khal Drogo.  Daenerys and her older brother Viserys are the last of the Targaryens.  The Targaryens are an ancient noble family.  They have ruled Westeros for three hundred years until Robert Baratheon led a successful rebellion.  And now, the ambitious Prince Viserys wants to take back his throne, with the help of the Dothraki horselord, Khal Drogo.  In the far north, Ned's bastard son, Jon Snow takes his vows and joins the ancient brotherhood of the Nightwatch.This is a breakout performance for British actress Emilia Clarke.  She plays the role of the most important character in the entire epic saga, Princess Daenerys Targaryen.  Peter Dinklage plays the role of the Imp, Tyrion Lannister.  Lena Headey plays the role of the evil queen, Cersei Lannister.  Newcomer Kit Harrington plays the role of the bastard, Jon Snow.  And Michelle Fairley rounds out the stellar cast of first-tier characters by playing the part of Catelyn Tully-Stark, Ned's wife.Production values are of high quality.  The locations, mostly Northern Ireland, are nothing short of awesome.  And the special effects, especially in the season finale, are spectacular.  This, in my opinion, is the best show on HBO.  If you have missed the first season, or if you do not subscribe to HBO, then this DVD set is just the ticket.

reviewText: Recently started going through these episodes again after viewing season two several times and it's really a new experience knowing more about the land of Westeros (a sort of parallel medieval England, Europe, and North Africa with a Hadrian's Wall of its own in its northlands). Amazing how much younger the characters seem in early episodes compared to season two, at least the ones who live. The most striking thing about this series is just how real and true it all seems despite the fantasy elements, from the nastiness of politics to the brutality of war and the justifications everyone makes for their decisions. Much like real life you'll find no one is an innocent here but you'll be rooting for some and loathing others nonetheless, and that's the great part of this show, almost every character has a compelling backstory and they all seem to be fighting for something missing in their lives, from love to power to dragons. Of all the cable shows out there, this has been the only one I've bothered with. George R.R. Martin's source material is certainly a plus to have backing this series, much like Tolkien's books were to Peter Jackson's LOTR films, so it has that going for it instead of screenwriters just making stuff up on the fly. Don't miss this, it's a powerhouse of a series.

reviewText: I wont waste time going into the story.  You can see plenty of that in the other reviews.The Blu-Ray is excellent and takes advantage of the format more than any disc I currently own.  The picture is flawless with bright colors and a life-like image.  You will notice details you didn't during the original broadcast airing.  For example, the scenes in the crypt were sort of dark and hard to make out during the original airing have been lightened up a bit.  You can see more details of the statues of the Stark ancestry.The DTS audio track is amazing!  Your side channels will get quite a workout.  The sound is immersive, but not overbearing.  I could crank the volume up fairly loud and it still would sound perfect.  I have a 7.1 surround sound system, and there was one scene early in the first episode where a raven comes flying in from the rear to the front that startled my cat and I.  I simply wasn't expecting that sort of detail in sound.There are quite a few extras.  The one that really stands out is the in-episode guide to the Seven Kingdoms.  When you turn this feature on, a side menu with four icons appears over the picture.  Don't worry, you can make it transparent so it's not blocking the scenes.  The first icon brings up a list of characters that are currently in the scene and will give you a bit of information about them when you select them from the list.  The second icon gives you the current location, also with a bit of information.  The 4th icon takes you to the complete guide where you can access all of it's content from a single menu.Then you have the third icon, the History icon, and this is the most interesting.  Periodically, when a character mentions something from past history, it will flash.  When you select that icon, you will see a list of history items, and the one that was just "unlocked" will be selected.  Press this, and you're taken to a short animated video segment explaining the historic moment the character just mentioned, narrated by one of the characters in the story.  Sometimes its the same historic moment from another viewpoint; so not only does it give you history, it gives you historical perspective from the different houses.  After the history video, it brings you right back to the episode where it continues.  Most of this history is in the narrative of the books, and so I think this was a very clever (and well produced) way to get that narrative back into the hands of the viewers.  It makes this world even richer than it was when we first viewed the series.I also feel that watching episodes back to back makes the series much enjoyable and easier to understand.  This show is dense with characters, history and plot.  So having to wait a week meant having all these details fade before the next episode.  I feel like I appreciate this series even more now that I own it.Finally, I actually received my set on Monday, one day before release the street date, when they had guaranteed release day delivery.  I guess that's one of the perks of being a Prime member.  Kudos to Amazon for their great service.  :)Great series.  Outstanding reference-quality Blu-Ray.  Definitely not to be passed up if you like the series and own a Blu-Ray disc player.
summary: Game of Thrones in 1080p and DTS

reviewText: It's great, but, one star deducted for the gratuitous sex scenes. They're just unnecessary.There are more sex scenes in a show featuring children than in any comparable TV program.The shots are titillating, if you need that kind of thing in your life, but there's no real context for any of it. At certain points, Game Of Thrones comes over as little more than pornography.Woman walks in, takes top off, lord tells servants to leave, sex ensues.It breaks up the action, the character development and the intrigue. Yes, it's a show for adults. Yes, people have sex. But people go to the toilet too and there's no effort to show that.I suppose this is all leading up to a series where we can expect penetration shots, and lots of group sex interspersed with an increasingly shonky story line.It's a slippery slope. Is it trying to compete with the internet by showing 'quality sex scenes'? Resorting to so much of it mars an otherwise excellent program.

reviewText: IF YOU'VE NEVER READ GAME OF THRONES.....Should you watch the show or read the book first? (no real spoilers)First - just to note (in case you didn't know), Game of Thrones is based on a book series called "A Song of Ice and Fire" by George R.R. Martin.  There are five so far (the first written in 1996, the most recent written in 2011), and he's planning to write at least two more (at the time of this review - 1/4/12).  "A Game of Thrones" is the first installment of the series.  HBO decided they liked the name "Game of Thrones" rather than "A Song of Ice and Fire" (I can see why - sounds less fantasy and more mainstream) and so that's the name of the whole series.  Each season is based on one novel.  So the first season was based on "A Game of Thrones" and the second season will be based on the second book, "A Clash of Kings," and so on.  Well, it may not be in exact perfect book order, and it will be interesting to see what they do in books 4 and 5, which have overlapping storylines.  Plus, aCoK is really too long to have in one season...the second season will air in April, 2012.Anyway, back to the original question.  Show or book first?This is a really difficult question.  For most books turned into show/movie, you'll want to read the book first, because it is usually superior to the adaptation.  However, we are talking about HBO here, so be prepared for a VERY good show.  Are there differences from the book?  Yes, but in general it stays true to the storyline and all differences are done artistically and were approved by the author, George R.R. Martin.NUMBER OF CHARACTERS - There are a LOT of characters in this story.  Because the show has to be condensed somewhat from a 800 page novel to 10 hours of airtime, it can get really confusing to know who is who while watching the show.  It can get confusing in the book as well, but things are usually more detailed for you in the book so it is easier to reference.  However, it always help to put a face to a name, so that's a plus for the show.  But once again, sometimes there will be a really long part in the book that will be eliminated entirely from the show, and the absence can throw you off a little.  The book definitely has more backstory, and you'll probably be able to more accurately identify characters when watching the show after.NEW SCENES FOR THE SHOW - Since we can't just look into the minds of the characters as in the book, there are a lot of invented scenes between characters in the show.  This isn't a bad thing, but it's just to give you more of an idea of who these people are and what is going on in their minds.  There is also a (sort-of) made-up character for the show, the prostitute Ros.  At first I thought she was added in there for just eye candy or something and found that sort of annoying, but ultimately I think she is just an outlet for us to get into the minds of characters since it's a show and not a book.  Also, her interactions with Greyjoy display (in my opinion) his disgusting personality, and since he's a much more important character in book 2 than 1 (his personality and backstory are almost non-existent in Book 1, they just hint at it), Ros was a way to kind of ease his character into the second season.DIFFERENCES - Like I said, the show is generally true to the book.  However, if you read the book first, you may get super annoyed with some of the differences when watching the show.  One of the major differences is ages.  Everyone is a lot older in the show (the children, especially), and people are generally a lot different and better looking.  That's not really an issue though, or else the show would seem odd and creepy.  An example is Dany, a 13 year old in the book, is in frequent nude and sex scenes.  In the show, I think they say she is 17 (but the actress is actually 24).  It would also seem silly if Robb (14ish in the book) was actually 14 in the show, with him playing the type of role he has.  My major gripe was a few storyline differences that I didn't think were necessary at all for the show, but I'm a nitpicker.  An example is the major absence of direwolves in the show.  They're there, but are much more prevalent in the book!  I love the direwolves and think they are very symbolic, and wish HBO did more with them.  Maybe next season.DO YOU LIKE TO READ? - That's probably the best way to decide.  The book is BIG.  Around 800 pages.  It's similar in size to a Harry Potter book, and in my opinion, even more captivating.  But it's a LOT of material, and you have to really pay attention due to the number of characters and intertwining story lines.  If reading isn't your strong suit, the show may be better at breaking it down for you.  If you are interested in reading all of the books, that's about 5,000 pages to trek through.  For comparison - if you read the Harry Potter books, all 7 books in the series are roughly the same number of pages as the first FOUR books of A Song of Ice and Fire.YOU CAN'T GO WRONGIf you are an HBO fan, you know that HBO doesn't produce garbage.  This show is a masterpiece - one of my favorite shows in a long, long time.  It reminds me of a mix of Lord of the Rings and the Sopranos, with it's edgy, unforgiving attitude and a splash, but not too much, of fantasy.  People aren't casting spells with wands like Harry Potter or anything.  The fantasy aspect is very, very subtle.  Actually, way more subtle than I expected.  It's very reminiscent of medieval times.  The acting is superb and like most HBO shows, there aren't a lot of big names.  Sean Bean and Peter Dinklage are probably the most well-known.  The scenery and the show itself is drop dead gorgeous, however, maybe due to budget constraints, the show feels quite a bit "smaller" than the book.  Feasts, castles, celebrations, cities....all seem smaller in the show.I think all changes in the show were done very well and nothing butchered the book.  Although nothing can compare to the books for me, I think aids it in really bringing it to life.  Plus, Martin was along for the ride of the writing and making of the show, so you know he'll try not to let writers deviate too much from the heart of the story.My two major recommendations are:#1 - watch show, read book, re-watch show: this is better if it's hard for you to get into books or just really want to see it first.  Then you can read the book, and think, "Hmm...I never remember seeing this person," and low and behold, when you watch it the second time around, that character IS there.  It really puts the pieces together.  However, prepare to be confused.  This is normal. The show has many, many major characters, and it can be really difficult to keep track.  I know several people who only watched the show and didn't read the book who can't point out Varys.  If you read the book, you damn well know who that is!  The show and the book alike both start out a little bit slow....but trust me, they both quickly turn into something quite thrilling and action-packed.  Just wait until Season 2.#2 - read the book, then watch the show: the only downside to this is that you may sometimes be disappointed if things don't live up to your idea of the books standards.  You might find yourself saying things like, "WHAT!  That's not how they consummated!" and nitpick.  However, you'll understand MUCH more of of what is happening in the show with your book knowledge.Also, this book was right up HBO's lane.  HBO likes to make gritty, real, intense and often unforgivingly brutal shows.  There aren't any good or bad guys, and when you think you found one....well, take a closer look.  Sick of fantasy books where things are too black and white (too good vs. evilish) or where the big characters are never killed off no matter how many deadly situations they are in?  Sick of books just not being REAL?  Well, Game of Thrones, the book and the movie, are a fantasy lover's dream.  Whether or book or show first, watch and read them both to really appreciate the art of Game of Thrones and the Song of Ice and Fire and series.
summary: For the Game of Thrones Newbie - SPOILER FREE

reviewText: What I love about it is it's one of my favorite shows based on one of my favorite book series of all time. It's a nice little collector's box that consolidates the whole first season of Game of Thrones. Shop.HBO.Com said that the Digital Copy was redeemable on iTunes, Amazon, or Vudu, with a UV copy being available via Flixster. But when I went to see my options, Game of Thrones had only iTunes or Vudu.Overall, it's a good price to have a dual format. Season 1 will release again this year with Season 2 in HBO Select format that will do all of the above, but Amazon is still uncertain.

reviewText: Although the series is based on fantasy books written by George R. R. Martin, it's nevertheless a study of human emotions and motives, mixed with political intrigues that even those who don't necessarily like fantasy can enjoy.  Among many notable performances by the actors in the series, Sean Bean gives a wonderful performance as Eddard Stark, the Lord of Winterfell.  He's a strong leader with no political ambitions and has been content to stay in his hold in the north.  He is coerced into becoming the "Hand" of the king, Robert Baratheon, whom he helped to claim the Iron Throne after the murder of Aerys II Targaryen, popularly called the Mad King, by Jaime Lannister.  Lord Stark must move to Kings Landing, the capital in the south, and learn the ways of the court.After the questionable death of the King, his son Joffrey Baratheon takes the Iron Throne.  Joffrey is a coward as well as a cruel and despotic young man who enjoys inflicting misery upon others, especially his fiancee, Sansa Stark.  Lord Stark's other daughter, Arya, is a delightful, but wilful young lady who tends to be a tomboy. Lord Stark begins questioning whether Joffrey is really the king's son, which leads to his political downfall.Another part of the storyline concerns Daenerys Targaryen, the daughter of Aerys II Targaryen.  She and her older brother fled the Seven Kingdoms after their father was murdered.  She is forced by her brother to marry Khal Drogo, but the union turns into a love match.  Daenerys wants to reclaim the Iron Throne, which she feels is hers by birthright.Adding to all of the political intrigues taking place throughout the Seven Kingdoms is a lurking danger coming from the north.  There is a 700 foot tall wall of ice in the north that protects the Seven Kingdoms from dangers from the north beyond the Wall.  The planet upon which the story takes place has seasons that can last for generations and winter is coming.
