reviewText: The mass media tends to ignore fantasy stories, especially high fantasy stories. So it came as a pleasant surprise to me that George R.R. Martin's fantasy epic A Song Of Ice And Fire was being adapted for television -- and HBO crafts it with all the dignity it deserves, with plenty of grime, blood and a tangle of convoluted storylines.The castle of Winterfell is thrown on its ear when King Robert (Mark Addy) of Westeros arrives to ask Eddard "Ned" Stark (Sean Bean) to be his Hand. But soon after Ned agrees, he receives a message from his mentor's widow, informing him that Queen Cersei's (Lena Headey) family, the Lannisters, are secretly plotting against the king -- and that they are killing off anyone who might be a threat to them.One of Ned's younger sons is gravely wounded when he sees something shocking, and the acid-tongued dwarf Tyrion (Peter Dinklage) is framed for the crime. Ned's bastard son Jon (Kit Harington) joins the Watch near the Wall -- but has little idea of the horrors that are approaching with the White Walkers.And across the Narrow Sea, exiled princess Daenerys Targaryen is wed to the barbarian lord Khal Drogo (Jason Momoa), so that her brother can invade Westeros and take back the throne. But Daenerys quickly grows in strength and wisdom, and the Small Council of Westeros has reason to fear her when it's found that she's pregnant -- but her greatest power is that of the dragon's daughter.As Ned takes to his new duties, he begins investigating the death of his predecessor, and begins to uncover a shocking secret about the queen and her children. Treachery, death and war will be brought to Westeros, and a war will begin with the blood of the good-hearted."A Game of Thrones" is truly an epic story -- it took a whole ten episodes to encapsulate a single book, and the story is far from over. There are countless plot threads woven into one enormous, bloodsoaked tapestry, linked together even if they are technically separate. And since this is only based on the first of Martin's books, it ends on a note both depressing and uplifting. Lots of plot threads are left dangling, but in such a way that you end up wanting to know what happens next.The entire series is draped in cold stone walls, grimy medieval atmosphere, windswept steppes, splatters of dark blood and the occasional sunny day. They don't skimp on explicit violence (including the death of a beloved character) or sex, but the focus here is always on the clashing families, battles and seedy plots of the queen. And despite that focus, there is still a hint of the magical in this fantasy -- talk of dragons, the White Walkers and their undead wights.As for the cast, it is BRILLIANT -- Sean Bean is perfection as the world-weary, good-hearted Eddard, and he's got a brilliant backing cast in Lena Headey, Emilia Clarke, the amazing Peter Dinklage, Jason Momoa, Michelle Fairley, and countless others. Even the child actors like Maisie Williams and Jack Gleeson are absolute perfection.And best of all, their characters are all so REAL. They have good points and bad points, strengths and failings, and they often change drastically over the course of the season (Daenerys turns from a pallid little wallflower to a powerful and icy queen)."A Game of Thrones" is a truly spellbinding experience, if not one that you want to see all together. Bloody, complicated and full of richly-developed characters, this is a future classic.
Title: N/A

reviewText: HBO have made an art form of producing long, complex and brilliant television series packed full of gritty realism and adult content, eg. The Sopranos, Entourage, and of course The Wire. If you had to choose a fantasy series that would fit this mould, then George Martin's brutal epic 'A Song of Ice and Fire' would immediately spring to mind. It is as though he had written for this format from the beginning. 'A Game of Thrones' is essentially a hybrid of The Sopranos and Lord of the Rings, where feuding noble houses engage in intricate power games in a fantasy landscape which is threatened both by a relentless demonic winter and the return of the dragons.The best way to describe this series is to say that it is a remarkably faithful adaptation of the first novel. The writers adhere closely to Martin's story and characters, down to identical scenes and lines. The complexities of the plot are conveyed well, as is the 'tone' of the books. If you enjoy the books you will find much to enjoy here. The production values are excellent, with an attention to detail and effects that echoes Peter Jackson's Lord of the Rings films. The actors are mostly excellent, particularly Maisie Williams as Arya and the inspired choice of Peter Dinklage as Tyrion. Sean Bean simply is Eddard Stark, though it feels a bit like Boromir has somehow wandered into the HBO studio. As in the book, though, the sections set in Westeros are immeasurably better than the storyline of Danaerys and her travels in the East, which feel like a parody of an old sword and sandal flick.The Song of Ice and Fire books are chock full of sex and violence, so both make an appearance on screen here. The violence is done right, brutal and not hidden by cutaways. If someone cuts off a head or rips out a throat, we get to see it. One of the strengths of Martin's stories is that they do not romanticise violence. The sex in his books is also largely about the exercise of power and a comment on the difficulty of real relationships in this feudal society, not about giving the reader a thrill. HBO made the unfortunate choice of turning this into an excuse for titillation, with scenes that stick out as pandering in the way that they did in parts of The Wire. Though at least the word 'teats' seems to have gotten lost 'twixt book and screen.'A Game of Thrones' is the best book in the series, with a strong arc both for the overall plot and for individual characters. The following books have had a tendency to meander and to pile bleak and depressing events upon each other. I'm not sure they would translate as well to the screen. But we shall see.
summary: An HBO adaptation made in heaven

reviewText: It is basically a ten hour movie that moves, I loved it.  I can sit down and watch all ten episodes back to back and stay riveted to the TV the whole ten hours. reviewText: I tried watching this show because so many people have compared it to Lord of the Rings. However, that comparison is superficial at best. Like LOTR, the producers of Game of Thrones did a good job recreating Medieval style costumes and scenery. That's about the only similarity.In terms of the plot and characters - what really matters - the two couldn't be more different. LOTR has an epic story of war and morality, with fascinating characters and deep character studies. Game of Thrones, by contrast, seems to be populated by a bunch of losers and whores. I've watched 2 episodes - got too bored to finish - and couldn't detect anything resembling an interesting story. There's a few minutes of mysterious blue-eyed monsters killing people in the first episode (what I thought were lousy special effects), but most of the series seems to focus around the drama of the king's family.Even after 2 hours of watching, I barely remembered any of the characters' names, much less cared about them. Except for Sean Bean's character, they all seem equally annoying. The only point I got excited was when I thought the little girl was going to kill the obnoxious blond kid (alas, she didn't). Unlike Tolkien's Hobbits, the series doesn't have a point of view character who pulls the viewer into the world, making it tough to invest in the characters. This is especially problematic when there are so many characters, most of who fail to make much of an impression.On another note, HBO seems obsessed with sex and violence in its shows. As a matter of artistic preference, I don't have a problem with explicit sex or violence scenes, but only if they serve the story or character development. However, in Game of Thrones, the directors certainly weren't subtle in their cinematography. At times, I felt like I was watching a porno - I felt embarrassed to be watching it with my wife. Much of it seemed thrown in there for the sake of titillating audiences when a far more subtle approach would have served just as well.I haven't read the book so I don't know whether the HBO series is doing it justice. However, I'd warn fans of LOTR and other fantasy classics that they'll likely find Game of Thrones disappointing. It's too bad - with the sort of money HBO has, it has the ability to create a genuine fantasy epic TV show, but instead we get Desperate Housewives in a Medieval setting.

reviewText: I hadn't even heard of these books before the TV show came on, but it's the best thing I've ever seen on television. The performances are amazing, the sets and locations are lavish and beautiful, and the story, which should be complicated and unwieldy, is told so well that I just wanted more, more, MORE! I could cheat and read the books as I'm really dying to know what happens next, but I don't know if that would just mess up stuff like the Ned-reveal in the second-to-last episode or what was to happen with Dany and Khal Drogo or even how the fate of Robert would affect everything midway through (I am still suspicious of his "accident!"). So, there are two sides. The side of me that wants to read the books knowing that there is probably a lot more story in them with richer character descriptions and plot that had to be cut out for television. Then, there's the other side that LOVED seeing it filmed and wants to be surprised. I just don't know. It's such a perfect TV show that if the book isn't AS perfect, I'd feel let down.Anyway, big five stars for "Game of Thrones." Best show I've ever, ever seen. Even better than, I'll say it, "Firefly."
summary: Should I Read The Books Or Just Watch the Show?

reviewText: I read the book several years ago and I currently think that it is one of the best of the fantasy genre. This HBO television adaptation of the George RR Martin's story is right on with nearly every detail. And although I already knew how things were going to play out by the end of this season one (book one) story arc, I still found the action to be riveting, suspenseful and dramatic. I am downright amazed at how good this TV show turned out to be.The Story - As a single novel, "A Game of Thrones" is one of the most interesting, innovative and surprising stories of its kind. Martin has created his very own unique overlay to the traditional fantasy yarn, one that clouds the distinctions between good and evil and one that is based on well thought out character types and world building. The set up for the larger story (in the books that follow) is outstanding. The TV show is completely true to the story.The Characters - Martin's characters (and there are lots of them) have some real depth and dimension, but the TV show really takes these characters even further into the visual dimension. I think it added to what I already thought I knew about these characters. And while every single actor is perfect in their role, I was especially impressed by Peter Dinklage as Tyrion Lannaster, Maisie Williams as Arya Stark and Kit Harington as Jon Snow. These three are definitely some of the most interesting characters from the books and their portrayals were dead on.The Setting - The overall look to this TV show is wonderful! The settings are true to their geographic placement in Martin's world, but they are also so accurately and interestingly detailed. In the special features, it was stated that each place was to have its own unique look, so that you knew immediately that you were in Winterfell, The Wall or Kings Landing.Overall, five stars for this perfect TV show adaptation. I'm anxiously awaiting the next couple of seasons because they should be just as good as this first season.
summary: Wow! An Excellent Adaptation of the Book, Powerful Character Drama!

reviewText: I finally broke down and tried out Season One of Game of Thrones and found myself quickly being hooked.  From the very first scene, I was intrigued about what is going on in this world and that only grew as I was introduced to and got to know the characters in this fantasy world.Game of Thrones is set in some archaic world of sword-fighting, knights, and court intrigue...to put it mildly.  Also, on this world, the summers and winters can last for years and there are these scary beings who live beyond a huge wall of ice that is patrolled by the sworn men of the Night Watch.  The world is broken up into Seven Kingdoms, all ruled by a King who took the Iron Throne when the former royal family was driven across the sea (leaving just a sister and brother of that line to try and re-claim the throne).  The King's best friend and supporter is "Ned" (played wonderfully by Sean Bean, better known from The Lord of the Rings) who lives up north, has a boatload of kids he's trying to raise to be honorable, and tries to steer clear of politics.  To little avail, of course.There are many characters to love and characters to hate.  Just as there are dirty little secrets to be kept, double-crossing of all kinds, and hints of scary stuff to be unleashed once the long winter's night finally falls.  Oh, and hints of dragons once past and perhaps yet to be.Be warned, there are gory bits in this show, nudity, and general nastiness.  But there are also scenes where honor is upheld no matter the cost and where characters come into their own, overcoming huge trials in the process.  There are also plenty of gray characters who you never know whether to trust or not, as well as characters who are just plain crackerjack crazy.  This show will definitely keep you guessing...Perhaps, the biggest issue was in trying to keep all of then straight at first and figuring out who belongs to what house and has what totem (stags, dire wolves, lions, or dragons are the four main ones), but by the third episode or so you will figure it all out.  I could have used a bit less gore in a few scenes, as well...but overall this is a fabulous fantasy series, one well worth hitching a ride on.  Take a chance.  You might just get hooked, too!
summary: Glad I Finally Took a Look

reviewText: my stepdaughter hooked me on this show and I have since then gotten many friends to get into it as well.  I usually lead into my pitch by saying it's like Lord of the Rings meets King Arthur meets PORN and then they go fight ZOMBIES.  How can you lose?As an HBO show, it is not limited to broadcast television's same standards for ratings etc.  This means it can be much more graphic, both in terms of violence and also sexuality.  Many "taboo" subjects are tackled.  There truly is something for everyone.The DVD itself is a clean, tight transfer and a beautiful package.  I have not yet finished going through all the features.  The show itself has ten episodes per season (one of the few drawbacks to an HBO show) but each of the five discs also has other fun things to check out.  I have to admit this is one of the reasons I've been slower getting around to the features.... it's easier when they are on a separate features disc as in most movie packages.  When I am watching the show I am usually burning through all ten episodes in a marathon run and then I have put away each of the discs in succession so I don't get them back out and watch the features.I must treat myself to a features day one of these days though.Meanwhile, if you like this show, you NEED to own it.  The only reason I can imagine not getting the DVD is if you get it on Blu-Ray.  I love GoT so much I even ordered the cookbook.  LOL

reviewText: I know (from my kids, who are GN fans), that the series does not stay true to the novels, but I don't care a bit. The gritty, barbaric medieval period is realistically brought to life by the production design team and the actors. History buffs will enjoy speculating which real life city/country/historical period is the inspiration for places, people and events in the story. There is a lot of gratuitous sex, but I am told by my resident experts that there is a reason for the choice to include it, so I will keep watching.

reviewText: While I have after several viewings managed to "get into" Game of Thrones, I can't help enjoying it with reservations because:1) I'm not a fantasy aficionado and don't have quite the appreciation of "world-building" which the more seasoned fantasy enthusiasts seem to applaud. This is why I had to stop after a certain point when reading Tolkien. I finished the Hobbit, the Lord of the Rings, and Silmarillion. Halfway through Unfinished Tales I just thought--and feel free to laugh--"who cares"? It had stopped being a story and become, to me, a sort of desperate escapist history which couldn't have ended until Tolkien died, and clearly not even then. (Perhaps I am being unkind to Tolkien since a lot of his Middle Earth lore was published posthumously anyway. Perhaps he never intended to publish any of it and it's his fans who can't let go.) And though Game of Thrones is, so far, the only addition to my viewing diet that is of the Dungeons & Dragons sort, and in spite of the show's creators' best efforts to foreground the drama rather than the fantasy, I here and there find myself blushing over some quite awful writing of the "you can, you must" or "I can, and I will" variety (as if they'd never read Shakespeare, or read him and resisted him), as well as over the rather far-fetched proper names of peoples/places which sound like they were wrenched from the board-game/trading-card imaginations of unbecoming nerds. In other words, Game of Thrones too often feels like the product of a sad loser made for sad losers. (And even then, sad losers are the products of bad parents, bad education systems, income disparity, structural inequality, etc. So they can hardly be blamed.)2) Despite my reservations I know Game of Thrones could have been far worse: it could have been more like the books on which it was based. Granted, I have never read any of the books, but I spent days systematically reading every 1-,2-,and 3-star review for them on this website. Okay, a bit of an overstatement since I did this almost a year ago and more reviews were undoubtedly added since then. Even so, there were quite enough reviews a year ago for me to decide that I would NEVER read the books. This was due to my impression that:a) the fantasy element in the books is present to an extent which I would find unbearable. The author's tendency to overload the narrative with unnecessary detail and history of his fantasy world was a serious complaint among the reviewers: the word "editor" was mentioned a lot, often in conjunction with "where was the," and more often in conjunction with "where the ---- was the."b) in spite of a 700 to 1000-page minimum per book, and in spite of the publication of 5 books over 16 years (1996-present) the story is still not finished. But not only is the story not finished: the other serious complaint is that the plot is headed absolutely nowhere. (Hint: The author was a writer for TV serials in Hollywood in the '80s. Were the expectations high to begin with?)I'm unqualified to speculate what fate awaits the books, except to say I feel sorry for those fans who spent so much time reading them only to become increasingly frustrated by what seems no more than a marketing ploy designed to keep stringing them along. (It takes 10 hours to finish the first season of Game of Thrones. How many hours did it take to slog through Game of Thrones the novel, let alone the whole series thus far? Again, they have my profound sympathy.) What doom this spells for the TV series is harder to say. Presumably the show's existence hinges on the books' existence, although perhaps not necessarily so: I vaguely remember watching an interview in which the author stated that he had divulged certain plot points to the show's creators in the event that he was hit by a bus (no comment) before bringing the book series to its conclusion. Then again, HBO often cancels its series before their completion, and sometimes for quite inexplicable reasons. (In the instance of Rome the reason was reportedly a financial one. Fine. In the instance of Deadwood it was never clear if the reason was to do with money or ratings. Then they cancelled John from Cincinnati for its mere 3-million viewership. Huh?) At the moment, however, Game of Thrones has nothing to fear: consumer interest is apparently strong enough for HBO to have ordered a third and fourth season (that's 2 years) to cover the third novel Storm of Swords. And who knows how the two novels after that will be divided. It's certainly enough time for the author to decide if he's going to keep scribbling in the margins or give his poor readers their due.
summary: It Could Have Been Worse. . . . It Probably Will Get Worse

reviewText: It has begun!  The much touted HBO miniseries A GAME OF THRONES arrived with Episode 1, and though the entire series cannot be judged on one episode, this initial hour has all the promise of an involving and visually stunning adaptation of the 1996 George R.R. Martin series of books of adult fantasy fiction titled 'A Song of Ice and Fire'.  The 'game' is played by seven families - Stark, Lannister, Baratheon, Greyjoy, Tully, Arryn, and Tyrell - and what we find in the initial episode is a taste of the intrigue to come.In this first episode Lord Eddard Stark (Sean Bean) is the patriarch of House Stark, one of the major noble houses of the Seven Kingdoms of Westeros and ancestral rulers of the North. Near the castle of Winterfell, Eddard's children discover a dead direwolf and five of its pups still alive. As the direwolf is the symbol of the Starks, Eddard allows each of his five children to keep one of the pups as pet. A sixth pup is discovered a short distance away from the others. It is a mute albino, and this one is given to Jon Snow (Kit Harington), the bastard son of Lord Eddard Stark. King Robert Baratheon (Mark Addy) , Eddard's childhood friend, journeys to Winterfell with his family to ask Eddard to become Hand of the King, the top advisor and military commander in the realm, due to the death of the previous Hand, Lord Jon Arryn. Eddard's wife, Catelyn Stark (Michelle Fairley), receives a letter from her sister Lysa Arryn, stating that Jon Arryn's death was a murder plotted by Queen Cersei (Lena Headey) and her powerful family, the Lannisters. Though reluctant to leave his duties and family, Eddard is convinced by his wife to accept the position in order to investigate Jon Arryn's death. Eddard's middle son Bran Stark (Isaac Hempstead-Wright) is engaging in climbing Winterfell castle's walls and towers accidentally sees Queen Cersei and her twin brother Jaime Lannister (Nikolaj Coster-Waldau) having incestuous relations. To protect their secret affair, Jaime throws the boy out of a tower window.  Where the story goes form here will follow throughout the remaining episodes.Though some would criticize an early report on a series merely at its inception, it seems only fitting that offering a word on encouragement to pay attention to this new series is warranted.  We can only hope that the series continues to build as it progresses.  The cast is filled with excellent actors, both seasoned and refreshingly new.  Grady Harp, April 11
summary: Heads Up for A GAME OF THRONES

reviewText: I'm not going to be able to say anything here that hasn't already been said about this amazing show. As I have not read the books yet I can really judge this show based on how it plays as a standalone piece as opposed to comparing it to the source. I think the acting is brilliant, the directing, the sets, sceneries (most of all of this show is shot on location) special effects and casting as well as pacing is stellar. I have absolutely no complaints about this show. It's the best show on tv right now (aside from Breaking Bad) and easily the best piece of fantasy ever shot for television. On Blu-Ray this show is immaculate, black levels are deep, colors are vibrant and lush, texture detail is sharp, and with certain scenes being shot on 35mm, actually have retained film grain. This show has everything that a fantasy fan could want, zombies, dragons, beheadings and tons of great female nudity. Since this show plays on HBO the standard running time per episode is about an hour since there are no commercial breaks. Special features are plentiful and the audio commentary is entertaining and informative as it should be. Any fan of Lord Of The Rings or Frank Frazetta art or Conan The Barbarian will like this show for the same reasons they like those fantasy pieces. This show doesn't cater to stupid people, if you aren't paying attention then you won't be able to keep track of people or place names. This show has magic and mysticism like you would want a fantasy show to have while grounding it in a very authentic Medieval setting with political intrigue. I highly recommend this show.

reviewText: The best opening season to a television show since the first series of Lost for me - a phenomenal fantasy epic with hidden depths like you wouldn't believe. No one is what they seem, any predictions you make will be confounded and not one player has a golden ticket for survival. Every character, even those who on the surface level appear evil have their conflicted sides, their understandable motivations, their troubled pasts. Complexity abounds but never gets in the way of good honest fun - this spirit is perfectly embodied by the undoubted star of Game of Thrones, Tyrion Lannister 'the imp' played by the disarmingly charismatic Peter Dinklage. The diminutive rascal towers above the competition delivering classic aside after classic aside - whether cracking funnies, delivering put downs, double dealing to save his skin or even dropping an unexpected 'C' bomb when referring to his warmongering and domineering father everything he does turns to gold. He even whistles while he works like an x-rated new member of the seven dwarves - Deviant perhaps?Other standout performances are Emilia Clarke's turn as the beautiful but deadly Daenerys, she gives the character an otherworldly innocence mixed with an unexpected fierceness, and Aidan Gillen's smirking schemer Petyr Baelish, a real slippery snake with a twinkle in the eye. Saying that everyone will have their favourites, lord knows there are about forty major characters, and none of the cast obviously hit a bum note. Special mention in this regard should go to the child actors, five or so of whom play very important roles - Jack Gleeson in particular deserves credit for making the sadistic wimp Joffrey quite so hilariously repellent!The extras on the DVD are a mixed bag really, the character profiles are very short though of course it's a nice touch to see the actor's candidly championing their on-screen counterparts. The real draw for me was seeing what George R. R. Martin had to say about the enterprise and working out just how close his involvement was. The impression I got was pretty close and I'd recommend that in addition to watching the short 'Making Of' and 'From Book to Screen' films that you also listen to his commentary track for Episode 8 - I have to admit that I very rarely listen to any commentaries on DVDs but made an exception in this case and it was interesting hearing him vigorously defending the choices that were made for the adaptation.Game of Thrones - the only mainstream show to feature a decapitation roughly once every other episode. Long may it reign.

reviewText: I see most negative reviews mostly center around the gratuitous nudity.  Let it be noted that anybody who would define this as X rated has never seen such a film.  That being said, I did have the sense most of the sex was pointless and therefore boring, and there the similarities with porn end.  "The Borgias" certainly suffered from the same disease of needing to draw in audiences that would otherwise have had their attention spans strained to the breaking point without this sort of filler.  It's a numbers game.  (I wish "Rubicon" would have played out half its intrigue in the bedroom, as we might have gotten a second season - for I have never seen a better show).Otherwise I can find little fault with this production.  The show follows the book fairly accurately through the first 6 or so episodes, but does get a tad rushed toward the end.  (Still light years ahead of what a movie can due - sorry, but LOTR was butchered).  Acting and script are outstanding.  Sean Bean will be sorely missed.  Peter Dinklage is brilliant and I was thrilled to see him awarded an Emmy for this role.

reviewText: When they won a few awards at the Golden Globes, I thought I must give this show a chance. I had heard of it earlier but thought it's some sort of a show about a moving circus. Then I saw Peter Dinklage's amazing body language upon receiving the Golden Globe for acting. I was still not convinced about whether or not I should see this show so I asked a knowledgable friend if this was anywhere in the league of Spartacus. He said it was maybe the best tv show he had ever seen putting aside the Sopranos and The Wire (former my favorite, latter his all time favorite) so anyway I decided I must watch.The show is based on kings, seven kingdoms, dragons, magic, demons, jesters, men, harlots, a very bleak sense of humor sometimes almost too cruel but the direction is absolutely stellar which means despite having such a prodigious quantity of creatures and characters, the show maintains a thoroughly engaging plot and script.At the end of the first show, I sat at my screen unblinking and revered by what had transpired. The last four episodes of this season were so engaging that I saw them one after another. The ninth episode called Baelor is when I stood up in front of my television screen hurling words and pumping my fist in the air. I don't clearly remember but it was a scene in TROY which made me do something like this almost a decade back.Anyhow, all characters, whether likable or despicable, seem to have a stranglehold to them.And yes, it would be safe to add GAME OF THRONES to the lineage created by many first seasons like "Prison Break" , "Lost" , "Spartacus" , "Sopranos" as one of the most REMARKABLE and unobtrusive study of the land. I, however, secretly think this may just turn out to be the greatest television series ever. Writing a review for something of this magnitude isn't easy. And oh, Ned Stark and his younger daughter were among my two favorite characters of this show. Can't wait till April for the second season.

reviewText: "When you play the game of thrones, you win or you die. There is no middle ground." Frankly, I'd rather play the game of Jenga; the repercussions are less dire. When you hear the term "transcendent television" being bandied about, you must break out that grain of salt. Except that GAME OF THRONES does fit the phrase. It deserves all the plaudits. I've finally caught up with this show, and I am astounded with how good it is. Big ups to HBO for going all in with fantasy writer George R.R. Martin's sweeping saga of warring dynasties and dark magic beyond the border. It's a hell of an undertaking. I'll be emptying out my bin of adjectives.George R.R. Martin has a knack for making his readers care for his characters, and this seamlessly translates onto the screen, by virtue of exceptional writing, superb production values, and a scintillating cast. The thought and labor that went into the exquisite show opening alone informs you that the showrunners are not effing about.The canvas spans geographies and numbers a sprawling cast. In a world in which summers span decades and murderous winters can last a lifetime, powerful noble families play the game of thrones. In the chilly north, the undermanned Night's Watch diligently patrols the ancient Wall, safeguarding the realm from demonic elements that stalk the darkness beyond. Except that there's been nary a sighting of these fell creatures in many decades. The Night's Watch, long since fallen on hard times, nowadays tends to be composed of felons, knaves, and vagabonds.While much of the story takes place in the Seven Kingdoms and focuses on the power struggle between the honorable Starks and the conniving Lannisters, things are developing in the East, in the grassy plains of Essos. There, the son of a deposed king hungers for what once was his inheritance, to the extent that he sells his petrified sister to the warlord of the fierce Dothraki, a clan of nomadic horsemen, in hopes of marshalling an army. From the first episode, ominous clouds of war hover over the Seven Kingdoms.I can't recall a recent show that's gripped me so from jump. Showrunners/head writers David Benioff and D. B. Weiss invest these ten episodes with humanity and amazing clarity. This is a remarkable feat, given the complex characters and dense mythology and the many interweaving plot threads and the huge chunks of exposition. This being a faithful adaptation of Martin's novel, you can't sit easy. Favorite characters may or may not break your heart, may or may not make it to Season Two.Credit the writers but also credit the actors for bringing their roles to vivid, full-blooded life. I dunno, maybe it's the British accents. Love them, hate them, but each part is nuanced, each character not altogether noble, not altogether depraved. Excepting the vile Prince Joffrey; I really hate that kid, all praise to young Jack Gleeson for eliciting such emotion. I didn't think I could sympathize with Lena Headey's scheming Cersei Lannister but there are moments in which she demonstrates an aching vulnerability (which she then promptly masks). Sean Bean - or "poster boy," to quote one of the showrunners - lends marvelous gravitas to his lead role of Eddard Stark. But, to me, the ones who really stand out are the misfits and outcasts. I love, really love, the clever dwarf prince Tyrion (Peter Dinklage) and Eddard Stark's feisty tomboy daughter Arya Stark (star-in-the-making Maisie Wiliams) and Eddard's bastard son Jon Snow (Kit Harington). Dinklage so well-deserved his Emmy and Golden Globe awards.Lastly, we are so lucky that GAME OF THRONES ended up on cable. It it had landed on one of them regular networks, it's probably canceled by now. As it is, Season Two can't have come soon enough. To echo one and all, GAME OF THRONES is a rousing triumph of style AND substance and a dazzling psychological drama. It is magnificently realized and stunningly visualized. And those direwolves are just too damn cute.This impressive DVD set is boss! It collects all ten episodes of Season One and comes with five discs. The bonus features:- "Complete Guide to Westeros" - a comprehensive and interactive break-down of the Lands and Houses of the Seven Kingdoms, including character profiles- "Making GAME OF THRONES (00:30:00 minutes)- "From the Book to the Screen" (00:05:14 minutes)- "Creating the Show Open" (00:05:05)- "Character Profiles" - the cast chats about their roles (00:30:41)- "The Night's Watch" - an indepth look at the brotherhood of men who patrol and guard the 700-foot ice Wall (00:08:05)- "Creating the Dothraki Language" (00:05:26)- 7 Audio Commentaries from the cast & crew (including Lena Headey's awesome - and occasionally blue - commentary)- Pamphlet w/an episode guide, a family tree of the Houses, and a map of the Seven Kingdoms of Westeros
summary: "We who presume to rule must sometimes do vile things for the good of the realm."

reviewText: I had never read the books this show is based off of, but it's an epic and a fantasy so I figured I would probably get into it just fine.  It took me a while to come round to it, but I finally gave it a rent and watched through the whole series within a matter of a few days...very good show!As far as battles and action, it wasn't overall quite as epic as I was expecting in that regard, but there was enough action to keep me engaged in the show...especially later on in the season.  More than that but the twists and the dialogue and the quality of acting in the movie also kept me very engaged in it!  At the end of the season, I was just like 'wow' and very excited to see the 2nd season, which I will probably do soon.My only disclaimers for anyone reading this that hasn't seen the show are as follows:  1-If you are squeemish and don't care much for gore, you may want to avoid Game of Thrones, because there is definitely some gore in parts.  2-If nudity and sex bother you, you probably should not watch this show either because there is quite a bit strewn throughout the show...one scene in a later episode felt almost like porn and I couldn't believe it, and I'm not even easily bothered by nudity & such in movies and shows.  It's still a great show, but those are just a couple of things I felt that some folks may want to be aware of before watching this.Aside from that though, if you can get past that stuff or it doesn't at all bother you, I do highly recommend giving this show a watch...great acting and premise, can't wait to see more!

reviewText: I started watching Season One of GAMES OF THRONES and was immediately hooked. I watched the entire season in a weekend. I could not get enough of this medieval fantasy saga. "Sprawling" is the key word here. GAME OF THRONES is a story of immense proportions with a rich and intriguing cast. Have a scorecard handy to keep track of all the characters and how they inter-relate. The Starks collide with the ruling Lannister family while the Dothrakis find a new princess.Visually stunning and a virtual visual effects feast, GAME OF THRONES is like nothing on TV. Here is a lavish production that outshines most anything in movie theaters. George R.R. Martin's story can be done justice in an ongoing TV series rather than compacted into a movie. So many worlds collide that we are often jolted from one location to another. Dark times are coming for the the 7 Kingdoms - political intrigues, the looming dark winter to come and the mysterious forces lurking in the woods will change life forever.GAME OF THRONES does have a fair amount of violence and sex and nudity but they all seem to fit into the telling of the story. The violence can be shocking since it can be unexpected. The show is not for the squeamish but there is an amazing story to tell here. Things really get going the last 3 episodes as the fight for the future of the kingdoms goes into full force.GAME OF THRONES is an amazing journey into fantasy and reality.

reviewText: I stumbled across this little gem here under my Amazon recommendations.  I'd never even heard of this series of books or the fact it was an HBO show. I read the synopsis and all the reviews here about the show and I was very intrigued.  I like Sean Bean as an actor, and enjoyed Peter Dinklage from Nip/Tuck, and as everyone raved about his performance in this, I thought I'd check out at least one episode.WOW oh WOW.... This series just blew me away!  The storyline was amazing!  All the machinations, assignations, intrigue, deliberations, or stunning confessions that go on are incredible.  The sets and locations are gorgeous.  The theme music is very stirring and the opening credits are creatively done.  I can see why each episode runs a cool $6 mil.... I'm afraid I'll run out of superlatives in describing this show.  There were many times in watching the series where I was shocked and stunned, like "wow.... Oh my gosh, did that really just happen?".... You think you may know what's going to happen next, and the show surprises you.  It plays out like an elaborate and intricate game of chess.  I love shows that do that.You may not recogize many of the names, but you'll recognize a lot of the faces.  Mark Addy (Roland from A Knight's Tale, Bill Miller in Still Standing) is wonderful as Robert, king of the seven kingdoms.  Rightfully on the throne?  Some aren't so sure about that.  Eddard (Ned) Stark (excellently played by Sean Bean, Boromir from Lord of the Rings) is Lord of Winterfell and Robert's friend. Ned is asked to come to Kings Landing and accept the job of Hand of the King, due to the recent demise of the previous title holder.  Some whisper assassination.  If that is indeed the case, Ned wants to know why he was killed.Lena Headey (Queen Gorgo in 300) is superb as Robert's wife Cersei Lannister.  Talk about a 180 degree character portrayal from her role in 300.  She was amazing, I loved to hate her. And no one could have played the role of Cersei's brother Tyrion, "the Imp" better than Peter Dinklage. He almost steals the show with his performance.  The actors playing two of Ned's younger children are phenomenal, especially Maise Williams as Lord Stark's spunky and scrappy daughter Arya.  This little gal will be a force to be reckoned with in the years to come.  She will definately be one to watch.  Isaac Hempstead Wright plays Arya's brother Bran to perfection.  The actors playing Ned's older children deliver solid performances as well.  Even Natalia Tena (Nyphadora Tonks in Harry Potter) delivers an outstanding performance in a minor role as Osha, a criminal turned new house slave at Winterfell.Then of course, there is the ominous and massive Wall.  Manned for thousands of years, most have forgotton why they even continue to stand the watch, and where deserting your post still means death.  Yet rumors and frightened witnesses swear that monsters and white walkers are beginning to stir, and icy horrors wait beyond the wall. Dragon lore and direwolves are also spoken of.Toss into the mix House Taragaryen across the narrow sea. In exile, Viserys Targaryen desires to take what he feels is his rightful place on the throne in Kings Landing, and sells his sister Daenerys in marriage to the Khal of the fierce and nomadic Dothraki tribe, (think Klingons of the wastelands) so that Khal Drogo (Jason Momoa from Stargate Atlantis) will provide the muscle Viserys needs to get the job done.There are several family dynamics occuring at the same time and it's very involving, so I would refer to IMDB to better understand who was who and where they fit in to the storyline, (thank you IMDB). There is soooooo much more happening than what I've mentioned here, but this review is already getting to be the length of a book itself, so just check it out for yourself.  If you are offended by nudity or violence, this may not be the show for you.Game of Thrones hits the ground running right from the opening credits where you see a white walker, and let me tell you, they're creepy.  This show grabs you and doesn't let go. It's one hell of a ride. I can't wait for the second season.  HBO, you definately have a gem of a winner in this series.  During the hiatus, I'll be reading the books.~ jade ~
summary: This One's A Jewel in the Crown!

reviewText: After watching all of season 1 I really don't see what all the hype is about. Actually, pretty mad they keep killing the only characters that I liked!  My friend that is obsessed with this show told me it was better than any other shows he had seen. I don't agree. I did not find the show overly sexy or violent as some mention, then again, watchSpartacus: Blood and Sand - The Complete First Seasonfor what I consider maybe too violent and sexy for most.There are some aspects of the show that do live up to the hype and are as good as any of the best shows I've ever watched like:--the locations and scenery were spectacular and fit perfectly for a fantasy story--the technical and image qualities are flawless and really show off Blu-ray.--Tyrion the dwarf probably turns out to give the best and most witty lines I've ever seen. He really surprised me and kept watching just to see what new crazy things he would do or think of! The rest of the characters were pretty predictable and you could pretty much tell what was going to happen to them.--The extras on the disk actually serve a purpose and are very useful. Helps you get a lot more excited about the series if you learn about all the different Houses, characters, and history before starting to watch the series.I would've rated it 5 stars for the above points but the other points I mentioned bring it down.I guess you have to have read the book to really get excited about this series?Maybe that's one reason I didn't care for the show was too much politics and backstabbing for my taste.I guess that's why I like Tyrion so much because he always tried to stay out of it and just wanted to have a good time!I guess I just expected more dragons, wizards, special effects, action etc. because that's what I think of when I think of fantasy. Maybe that will come in later seasons but I never read the books so I wouldn't know?But as it stands I will probably get the 2nd season just because I want to know what happened and the show has an annoying tendency to end with cliffhangers every episode! Actually, this is probably what part of the excitement is with this series for some but the longer you wait to see it the more likely the entire series will be ruined by spoilers because everywhere I go people seem to be talking about what happened on this show!I won't be in a rush to get the 2nd or who knows how many seasons unless the pace picks up and some more magic,dragons, excitement start to show up!I bumped up the review 1 star because it has one of the best quotes I ever came across and one of my favorites now:"a mind needs books as a sword needs a whetstone, if it is to keep its edge"--Tyrion

reviewText: brief review.  I didn't read the books- but a friend of mine did, so I had some backstory knowledge.  Basically you have 3 different kingdoms competing to gain even more power, after one of their kings unexpectedly dies.Politics, alliances, brutality, power-lust, and simple lust and shown in full force here.  Just as HBO did with its "Rome" series showing the underbelly of the Roman Empire, so too here we see a mythical medieval realm similar to Lord of the Rings (as least in production design).  But instead of people trying to capture a ring for power, here they do it the old fashioned way, by butchering their enemies, in many novel ways.LOTR alum, Sean Bean, here in perhaps the role he was born to play is brillant; as is the rest of the cast (which is well-cast).  There are many intriguing plot lines that play out, so you the viewer are constantly trying to figure them out to see where they will lead.  In other words, the writing is really good.I've only seen the first handful of episodes, but having seen enough to offer this brief review to HIGHLY recommend it.

reviewText: After the free weekend of HBO I just got that played every episode of GAME OF THRONES back to back, I was excited to watch it, being a fan of genre television. I was also a fan of a lot of the people involved, from Sean Bean to Mark Addy to Lena Headey to Peter Dinklage.So, watch it I did, and it was just about everything I hoped it would be: smart, engaging, involving, bawdy, lusty and just the right amount of the fantastical that doesn't take away from the rather gritty realism the show has. In short, the show is addictive, and it almost made me want to subscribe to HBO just to be able to watch it.But after taking the last few days to think about it, I've found some things that I just don't think work as well as they should and maybe it's more revealed in Martin's books but I just have to sound off.I have a great amount of respect for this show. It's done very well. I found myself liking characters I didn't think I'd care about, such as Dani Targaryen and Khal Drogo. I found myself hating characters I thought I'd like, like Littlefinger Baelish (which makes me think, was anyone on THE WIRE American? Not that I care, but I just find it funny with Aidan Gillen, Dominic West and Idris Elba...). But the characters that are a little too one-dimensional are ultimately MOST of The Starks and MOST of the Lannisters. We get to see Catelyn be the loving, doting mother and wife, but once things go all pear-shaped, we get to see her more brutal and vicious side. Ned, Robb, Jon... all the Stark men, really, are men of honor, courage, and virtue. And conversely, other than Tyrion (who is just AWESOME), the Lannisters are unrelenting scumbags with no redeeming qualities whatsoever, with the exception of a few scenes of Cersei's, where we see some of the stone that her heart has become begin to bleed.Don't get me wrong; I'm all for clear heroes and clear villains in a film. But in a film, you only get a few hours at most to develop characters and sometimes, there's too much story to get in the way of adding layers to the characters. Television is a lot different though. You can get more into the thick of the characters. In many ways, television is more about character than it is about action and story, and this was the only way I felt the show fall short.Now, this is just the first season, and with the Lannisters and Starks largely intact, I'm relatively certain we'll see these characters with more dimension and depth. Until then, I want a Direwolf pup really bad.A Lannister always pays his debts, but Winter is coming. Season Two could get really awesome.
summary: Great, but if you look at it too long, there are some glaring problems.

reviewText: Game of Thrones, for those that do not know, is based on a novel written by George R.R. Martin, who was proclaimed by Time magazine as the modern day Tolkien.  Being so highly acclaimed it came as no surprise it soon found its way into a film adaptation.  Fantasy has never been one to be very good on film due to its need of a ridiculous budget to make it look well produced versus a B movie from the 80s.  However, I can say without hesitation this is one of the best adapations I have ever seen.Game of Thrones is set in a fantasy world, but it is simply a backdrop to a very human story.  The entire series is character driven, each coming from different cultures, all playing for power to rule on the iron throne.  Violence, sex, love and political intrigue this series has it all.  L.A. Times describes this series as a medieval version of The Sopranos and it comes pretty close to that description.  I will spare you the in depth synopsis since it is complicated to say the least and would only spoil it for anyone viewing this for the first time.  I suggest everyone reading the first book to fully enjoy this series, but if you don't please watch all bonus material that has to do with the characters and setting on these great blu rays before starting episode 1.Game of Thrones Blu Ray set is the definitive way to watch this series.  First, for those that have not read the book can easily get a brief history lesson in the world and the characters that inhabit it.  The Blu Rays are simply put reference quality.  This is a 5 star set with flawless picture quality and an incredibly immersive 5.1 DTS Master HD sound track.  To top it all off you are not simply getting just the episodes which is so common with TV series sets.  You also get this long list of extras as well:- Complete Guide to Westeros - "An interactive compendium of the noble houses and lands featured in Season One."- Making "Game of Thrones" - "An exclusive 30-minute feature including never-before-seen footage from the set and  interviews from the cast and crew."- Character Profiles - "Profiles of 15 major characters as described by the actors portraying them."- Creating the Show Open - "An inside look at the creation of the Emmy-winning opening title sequence for 'Game of Thrones'."- From the Book to the Screen - "Executive producers David Benioff & D.B. Weiss and author George R.R. Martin talk about the challenges of bringing Martin's epic fantasy novel to life on HBO."- The Night's Watch - "An in-depth look at the unique order of men who patrol and protect the Wall, a 700-foot ice structure that separates the Seven Kingdoms from the darkness beyond."- Creating the Dothraki Language - "An insightful glance into the comprehensive language created for the Dothraki people in 'Game of Thrones'."- Audio Commentaries - "Seven audio commentaries with Cast and Crew including David Benioff, D.B. Weiss, George R.R. Martin, Emilia Clarke, Peter Dinklage, Kit Harington, and more."- Blu-ray Complete Guide to Westeros - "An interactive compendium of the noble houses and lands featured in Season One PLUS 24 exclusive histories of the Seven Kingdoms as told by the characters themselves."- In-Episode Guide - "In-feature resource that provides background information about on-screen characters, locations, and relevant histories while each episode plays.- Anatomy of an Episode - "An in-episode experience that explores the creative minds and colossal efforts behind Episode Six, `A Golden Crown.'"- Hidden Dragon Eggs - "Find the hidden dragon eggs to uncover even more never-before-seen content."That is a HUGE list of extras that should excite anyone buying this incredible series.  Do not think this series is just for fans of the books or for fans of this genre of film, this is an incredible story that everyone should experience.  This Blu Ray set comes not only Highly Recommended but as a must own.

reviewText: I've never read G.R.R. Martin(the sheer length of the books being a bit daunting), so I sat down to watch the first season of Game of Thrones with no preconceptions or understanding of what was going to happen. Simply put, from the first episode, I was hooked.While I can understand why some people could be turned off by the violence/sexual content--and the sex often was gratuitous to the actual storyline, Game of Thrones still features some of the best acting I've seen on TV in a long time, with Sean Bean bringing back his "Boromir" look to the utterly brilliant role of Ned Stark. He and Peter Dinklage are easily the best male actors in the series, followed closely by Iain Glen.The story is truly epic and the show does it justice--I don't even want to imagine the production costs that went into it--but the scenes live with a feel for the world that is Westeros. Well done, and I'll probably start watching Season 2 in a couple of weeks.

reviewText: In ways, this was the best show I'd seen from HBO to date... yet, in ways, it felt stifled from being true entertainment.I've read comments that people thought this show had parts that were too raunchy to be true to the books and I'll admit, though I haven't read the book, there were nude/sex scenes that simply didn't feel true to the overall presentation, let alone feel right anyway.The story itself was very strong, not just in concept and presentation, but also in execution from all the points-of-view, especially that of Khaleesi and her husband. There plenty of shocking moments throughout the season to amp up the action and whatnot (honestly, the lack of Whitewalkers after the first episode was rather disappointing, but if that's how it is in the book, then I've just shownm my ignorance, haven't I? ;) as well as to provide extra character-based moments in later episodes. The cast theirselves were great, each holding true to who they were, even through each one's own overall progression.I just hope they'll decide to make the next season more organically sound as a companion piece to the book rather than follow some raunchy quotas from HBO to make non-book fans of tv shows happy and have fans of the book be ecstatic.(Hint, hint, HBO)

reviewText: I'm not using hyperbole when I say HBO has done a great thing by backing this production. It's a visual treat with sets and costumes that fit the books well and the music and introduction are also well done. It's a relief that the actors do a great job as well, even the youngest actors give fine performances. I found Cat and Cersei a little grating but that's no different from the books. If I had a complaint it's that it goes a little overboard with nudity but it's an HBO series and I'm sure they were in favor of this. I'm also sure it will be picked up by a cable network and broadcast without the nudity and possibly with less graphic violence at which time my wife will be willing to watch it. For the most part the series follows the first book very closely including the lively dialogue being nearly the same. The most impressive performances are Sean Bean as Eddard Stark and Peter Dinklage as Tyrion Lannister, both capture the characters in the book perfectly. Jack Gleeson's Joffrey is as callow and vicious as in the book and I can't wait to see him suffer his fate in a future season. Sansa is also annoying and vapid and looks a lot like I'd imagined from the book. I'd pictured Arya very differently but Maisie Williams does such an excellent job that now I see her when I read the books which is good. The actors across the Narrow Sea are also amazing, especially Jorah and Dany.*** spoilers ahead *** Dany's vulnerability being replaced by a powerful character is delightful and Iain Glen is perfectly cast and far more enjoyable than Jorah was in the book. Khal Drogo is also perfect and I hated to see him go so soon, much as I hated seeing Eddard's inevitable end - just as I hated these events in the book. George RR Martin is very hard on our favorite characters. Any claims of sexism must come from people who haven't seen or fail to understand the evolution of the female characters. Dany's evolution is one example. Arya and a future character refuse to follow a stereotypical role which is far from sexist. One complaint I do have is that the direwolves haven't become the massive protectors they were in the books. That is probably a practical matter but I wish they'd found a way to use perspective or even CGI to give them the stature of a real direwolf.Forget the criticism, if you ever enjoyed fantasy or historical fiction you should give this show a try. I can't recommend it highly enough.

reviewText: the series was highly anticipated, yet lacked the depth, intensity, realism, and grit of its contemporaries: rome, sparticus, band of brothers. i am a stickler for realism or believability and game of thrones was lacking...not because its fantasy (lord o the rings did it well) but because of lack of attention to detail, coherence of plot, sterile sex/ battle scenes (merely "insert sex/battle scene here" rather than a passionate build up, causality or quality interplay). the whole thing smacked of a trailer for something else more brilliant....lots of interesting "what ifs" that were never really addressed, i guess thats for season 2. the knights of the black? total joke...like you are going to create a trustworthy, honorable legion of highly trained bad-asses that the whole civilized world depends on for protection from the dregs (not to mention fat mammas boys) of other kingdoms, rather than a select few whose qualities merit there post. another point of notice: almost all of the kings/ lords get killed whilst their female counterparts survive, placing them in position to make the moves...great, looks like season 2 will be a middle-earth "sex in the city"...pointless. "women can rule!" you say? well, that is true but to merely replace all the male leadership with females is implausible, unrealistic, and frankly boring.  an even mix keeps things balanced and believable. matter of fact, a eunuch has more masculinity in this milktoast epic than sean bean's grizzled and apathetic character.

reviewText: This is the first time I've ever caught myself opting for the cinematic over the book.  However, after my experience with Wheel of Time, I am reluctant to invest myself in another fantasy series before the vision is completed and the ending is written. reviewText: I read the book, "Game of Thrones" and was totally disappointed when the author failed to close each storyline (character) with something that resembles what professional writers are expected to do.  I thought I'd borrow the DVD series at the library (did the same for Pillars of the Earth before I purchased it) and was double-disappointed. Maybe I was born too soon for this kind of film but I do like fantasy/science fiction. What I don't like is repetitive sex for the sake of titillation. I find repeated sexual acts beginning a A and ending at Z boring after an hour or so. Giggling sex slaves and prostitutes spreading their legs added nothing to the story line and sure didn't improve the dialog. Both the story and dialog were inconsistent and the transition between locations and characters was clumsy. There were two characters well-acted in the film. The dwarf role actually had something to say and I came to admire the courage he showed in accepting who and what he was. The girl-child who preferred sword fighting to dolls came in a close second. I admired her courage to do what she loved and stick with the training. I've read the other reviews and I think we watched different films and read different books. The violence was way too graphic and the sex/nudity was way too frequent.  Pillars of the Earth presented the same issues but once the tone was set and the reader/watcher knew how crude the times were, the writer got on with the story and it was rewarding and easy to follow. I may be old fashioned but I like to see a little justice for the underdog and I want to good guys to win. Game of Thrones failed on both counts. If I want to see this kind of gratuitous T&A I'll go to a porn site. If I want to see the good guys come in last, I'll watch the evening news.

reviewText: As the title states, this is a specific review of the Collector's Edition set for Season 1. First of all, let me state that I was very ecstatic that I got this product at a great price of $39.99 when Amazon price matched Best Buy's offering. To everyone who got this set at the said price, we are a lucky bunch.The box is made of quality material. It's not just some cardboard box set like other collector's edition. The front cover is soft and feels like it has a cushion. Once you open the box set, you'll see the Dragon egg inside its recess and the Season 1 Digipack. Underneath the season 1 digipack is another blu ray with a sneak preview of the first episode of Season 2. I know that's a bummer but it's better than getting nothing else as an extra.You also get DVDs and digital copy of the first season.The Dragon egg feels very solid. It's a little heavy for such a small egg but it was finely crafted. Great for display in your office or just on your collector's shelves. Overall, this is a great product. If you don't have the first season already, get this.Specially if you find this product going down to $39.99 again. IT's a no-brainer.

reviewText: By Jim Clark, publisher Lee County Courier, Tupelo, MSGame of Thrones is set in the fictional Seven Kingdoms of Westeros. It borrows from Roman, Greek, Viking and Assyrian cultures. By the second disc viewers will be totally immersed into the House of Stark and the House of Lannister.Eddard and Catelyn (Tully) Stark have six children Robb, Sansa, Arya, Bran, Rickon and the bastard Rob Snow.Rob is following in the footsteps of Eddard's brother, Benien Stark,  becoming a member of the Night Watch. The Night Watch consists of three groups, the rangers (who defend the wall), the builders (who maintain the wall and castles) and the stewards (who support and feed the other members). Rob, of course, wants to be a ranger like Benien. Benien has just left the safety of the wall and wandered into the Haunted Forest on the lookout for White Walkers (a type of frozen zombie).Eddard's second to the youngest boy, Bran, has fallen from a castle window, but his mother thinks he was pushed. The boy lives but loses the loss of his legs and can't remember what happened. That's good for Jamie and Cersei Lannister, brother and sister, who are having an incestuous affair (to keep the bloodline pure) and who the boy saw. Cersei is married to King Robert Baratheon, an old friend and ally of Eddard's.The King has asked Eddard to help watch over the throne fearing he has enemies from within. That's possible with Grand Maester Pycelle, who acts decrepid, but is more spry than he lets on, Varys, an enoch, and Lord Petyr Baelish, who has some hidden agendas of his own, are his closest advisors.
summary: Complex houses foundation for medieval HBO'drama

reviewText: Overall, this is a good production of Martin's books and for the most part stays true to the events depicted in them. Since Martin is a "co-executive producer," that might explain why. Peter Dinklage as Tyrion and Jack Gleeson as Joffrey are two great character picks. They play their parts well. Gleeson is convincing as a wannabe tyrant/spoiled brat/bully/coward and Dinklage is convincing as the sly, manipulative dwarf who manages to survive against all odds. Some of the settings are impressive and close to what I imagined them to be in the books. This is a must-see series.
summary: Almost as good as the books. Almost.

reviewText: I won't go into detail about the story line but I will say that I enjoyed this season one DVD set a lot. HBO has hit another home run with a good series of the kind that always seems to keep them on top of the ratings. This series is every entertaining and the acting is just superb. It contains multiple characters that are carefully developed and you begin to support the character or hate them for their evil and manipulative ways. Each character seems so real and you feel empathy for their problems that they are going through.The show is high action and it contains multiple plots, heroes and villains. The suspense about what is on the other side of the wall is building and I cannot wait to see season two. With the threat of a fierce winter, dragons, white walkers, giants, the wild ones and giant wolves the kingdom is under threat. Can they stop fighting each other and unite to survive or are they their own worst enemy?This show features many outstanding actors and actresses who portray their characters to perfection. The film work is top notch and the scenery and special effects are outstanding. This is a first class saga and it is well worth the money to buy it and enjoy it.There is violence, sex, profanity and bloodshed in the story so make sure that you make note of that. The disks are unrated but they are probably for mature audiences only and they are at least an R rating.I strongly recommend this series to you, I really enjoyed them!
summary: One of the best TV series I have ever watched, it is first class quality!

reviewText: I'm a huge fan of fantasy and scifi, and I've heard so much hype about the Game of Thrones series, that I was ecstatic to see it available on-demand from Amazon Prime. I ponied up the extra buck to watch it in HD, sat back, and prepared to be amazed. Well, I guess I was amazed, but not in the way I expected. This episode falls amazingly short of its potential. There are plenty of elements to grab and hold attention: characters facing tough choices, boys coming of age, a young girl more suited for combat than cross-stitching, mysterious and outrageously evil enemies, etc... I mean, sure those are old stand-bys, and maybe a bit trite, but they work. Production and casting are also quite good. But things quickly go from promising to pathetic. Gratuitous nudity, coarse sexual content, scenes demeaning to women, and foul language, all of which turn my first (and last) episode into a real dirt sandwich. Wish I had my money and time back. Not recommended.
summary: So much potential, but bitterly disappointing

reviewText: HBO you @&$%tards.  Shut up and take my money.  I've been paying AMC for every season of Walking Dead and Breaking Bad and GLADLY.  For all but 1st season of Breaking Bad which I bought the DVDs of, it's been through Amazon Instant watching them the day after they are aired.  I feel like the character in Pretty Woman who says I have all this money and they won't sell me anything.  I got this fistful of dollars and half a year later you still won't take it from me.  It's a big ol upraised middle finger to anyone who bought the 1st season, watched it, appreciated the product and waited with bated breath and a fistful of dollars to support the 2nd season... only to get the ol stiffarm.Generally speaking, I believe artists, actors, writers, directors etc do something useful and meaningful, something worth paying for (even a truly awful movie like Ink I would pay to check out as opposed to pirate), so I don't know that I'm ready to turn pirate now or ever, but there's a point at which I may just write off what I see as a bad business relationship.  There'll be a point at which I say boy that season 1 was great, wonder what happened to them, oh well nevermind time to watch the new Walking Dead and Breaking Bad episodes.  Yeah I got attached to the characters in Game of Thrones, wanted to know what happened to Tyrion, Arya, Snow... but at the end of the day, yknow what, they're fictional characters and if a bus didn't ever arrive on time, if my cellphone kept dropping calls, at the end of the day okay, I can move on and get invested in some other product.  Presumably season 2 would just get me more interested, attached, and frustrated by HBO.  I FOUND game of thrones via Amazon Instant and purchased it there.  Its availability online at all was the reason why I wanted to pay to see season 2, since I am not subscribing to 200+ channels of cable.  In the future, when I shop on Amazon, I will watch to see if a show I am considering purchasing is an HBO show to ensure that I do not hit the buy button and get stuck in a #%&^-tease type situation again.I can visualize the responses to my review based on AVAILABILITY of the product as opposed to the actual quality of the actual product.  So let's talk about the product.  It is a SERIES.  It's an ongoing story.  I rate things on Amazon based not on any artistic merit but on its value as a purchase on Amazon.So starting from that premise I'll tell you... the series is great.  Great production, interesting characters and so on.  I absolutely would love to continue paying to be told the tale in season 2 as I have done with some great AMC series - I use them as an example because they have some great shows and are doing the opposite of HBO.  Most importantly as I said, you are buying into a series here.  Your purchase of season 1 as opposed to the first one or two episodes means you've bought in for the entire story and I am sad to tell you that the story does not stop off at a satisfying point in season 1 but much as you might like to continue watching, HBO does not want your money to follow along with the story and will not let you pay them to continue telling it to you.  Not through Amazon, Netflix, iTunes, etc.  What you're therefore buying into, if you're buying this product, is the frustration of getting into the very beginning of a story, the characters, only to be told yes we have more, no you can't have any. That's the package experience so to speak being offered by HBOBy contrast, AMC has some great selections and is actually interested in letting you pay for them and watch them if they exist.  Mad Men, Hell on Wheels, The Killing, Walking Dead, Breaking Bad... sadly you have to think of what company you're getting involved with prior to purchase.  With HBO or Showtime you may find that becoming a fan means the product exists, you want to buy it, but your money is no good with them.  The show is clearly tailored to play on your emotions such that you are on the edge of your seat for the next episode - normally this would be high praise for a show, but when you take into account what you KNOW they will do to you... had I known, I wouldn't have made the initial purchase.  There are other good shows out there.HBO's business model is to hold back their shows from availability on Amazon and elsewhere.  Therefore, if you watch the occasional cable show via Amazon, definitely reconsider your purchase of this or any HBO show.  If the show has run its course and is available here in its entirety, go for it.  If you subscribe to a cable package and plan to continue doing so, definitely consider watching Game of Thrones although you won't be purchasing it here on Amazon, you'll be going to HBO's on demand web page available only to those who subscribed to a cable package that includes HBO. Due to the absence of GoT season 2, I tried The Killing here on Amazon and found it to be quite gripping and entertaining.  Definitely shop around before you hit that buy button here on Amazon for any HBO show including Game of Thrones.  Sorry, but this frustration is part of what you're buying with your purchase of this product.

reviewText: What a triumph this series is! With a few notable exceptions, Fantasy has been a long neglected genre and this show really lifts the lid on its potential. I've only read the first novel that the series is based on and have to say, it didn't really get me in. The TV version though hits all the right notes. There are characters you love and some you loath and plenty that just intrigue the hell out of you! There is heaps of action and some jarring plot twists. Characters can engage you completely one minute and be dead the next. I love the unpredictability of it all! The thing I am most grateful for is that the makers have done it properly. Castles look like castles. Halls look like medieval halls and there are a host of supporting actors and extras to give a clear sense of the grand sweep of the events. There are no wobbling sets here. This is a quality show made to look absolutely real. Note there is extensive nudity at times, very strong language and some very gory scenes. All to the good, as far as I'm concerned. These are real people living in very troubled times and they express themselves accordingly. The stakes are high and mistakes in this world mean the loss of everything!

reviewText: It is a puzzle to me why the vocal, liberated women of the 21st century do not seem to be overly concerned about how shows like this exploit and objectify them. Every other scene in episode one of Game of Thrones had a naked woman in it and a mostly clothed man mounting her like a dog. I've read the books, and I know that this is consistent with Martin's writing, but this kind of information can be implied. The graphic visual is not crucial to the story. In fact, it grinds the story to a halt every time, to the point where it becomes comical.The greatest films leave so much to the imagination, but the cable networks like HBO and Showtime seem to have a fascination with dragging their shows to the borderline of pornography. I suppose the execs at these networks are trying to cash in on a piece of that multi billion dollar industry. I also suspect that many of these execs have sons and daughters. I wonder how proud they would be to see their own children disrobing and simulating (?) graphic sex acts on film for the whole world to see? People are classifying this as an adult fantasy, but I couldn't help imagining the production team of Game of Thrones as a group of pubescent junior high boys sitting around the monitors and giggling about all the naked women in the show.Alternately, The Lord of the Rings is a truly adult fantasy that draws concepts like honor, sacrifice and beauty in much sharper relief. And the irony is that the Lord of the Rings has an even stronger sex appeal than Game of Thrones could ever hope to have because Tolkien was able to employ the art of subtext and the power of suggestion to a greater effect. I for one would love to see the Game of Thrones production team focus next season more on the truly adult themes of this great story like loyalty, friendship and justice, and stop insulting our intelligence with porn.
