reviewText: You have to give a hand to HBO for having the guts to take on such a lofty and risky project. Even for a company as successful and well thought of as them, Game of Thrones was no sure thing. Though based on a much loved series, A Song of Ice and Fire by Gorge RR Martin, adapting it to the small screen was an enormous risk. Since Lord of the Rings there hasn't been a live action adaption of a fantasy series as large, as deep, and as populated as this. The world of Westeros is huge, with many incredible locations, a plethora of rich three dimensional characters, large battles, and a unique culture.So how did Game of Thrones match up to the books? Quite well, as a matter of fact. Unlike other TV adaptions of beloved books (looking at you Walking Dead) the writers of Game of Thrones didn't have the hubris or arrogance to think they could out write Gorge Martin and kept the story pretty damned faithful to the original source material. It's astonishing, really, how close the first season follows the first book. Oh, there are differences, slight as they may be, but it always seemed to me that most of these differences were made either because of budget restraints (there are a few battles that are glossed over) or simply in order to better render Martins story on the small screen. All the characters, the major events, the plot twists, the unexpected deaths, are maintained as faithfully as any purest could ask for. Its abundantly clear to me that the writers of this show knew and respected their source material very much. Such loving care is put into bringing the world of Westeros and Essos to life that I could swear Martin was involved in the screen play... oh wait, yes he was.That's probably the biggest strength of Game of Thrones. The integrity of the writing is unmatched in modern television. They don't make the silly mistakes the writers of Walking Dead make, they don't change the characters and their motivations for the sake of one episodes drama, they don't gloss over the more uncomfortable aspects of this world. Westeros is a harsh and unforgiving world, and the show captures that perfectly. Rape, murder, betrayal and murder, none of the horrors of Martins story are pussyfooted in order to appeal to as mass an audience as possible, something that is greatly appreciated not only because it is necessary to tell this story right, but because it must have been a major risk for the studio to produce. When we see Walking Dead stray from its source material to avoid showing rape or torture, I watch Game of Thrones and see those exact elements brought to life as real and uncomfortable for the viewers as they can be. It makes no apologies for these elements, but nor does it flaunt them. Nudity isn't used in this show for shock and awe or titillation as it is in Spartacus, it is merely part of the world and so is shown with such casualness it fades into the background. The same could be said for the violence. For the most part there aren't any long drawn out highly choreographed sword fights that go on forever. They are often very short, to the point, and very bloody. The fight between Ned Stark and Jamie Lannister takes less than thirty seconds, and that's  one of the signature fight scenes of the entire season. Because of this much more time and energy is spent on developing the characters and setting up the conflict between them instead of devoting all their time and money on big action scenes.I guess this is the time where I should talk about what Game of Thrones is about, though every time I try to explain to someone who's never seen it, or read the books, I never quite know how to explain it. Do I say it's a fantasy story like The Lord of the Rings? But that's not quite right, as this is a much more character driven story. To I say it's a character drama? Because that's not quite right either. Westeros is a fictional world where eight families rule over their countries and serve as wardens to King Robert Berathion, who sits on the Iron Throne in Kings Landing. When the Hand of the King, John Aryan dies of under suspicious circumstances, King Robert marches north to Winterfell, the seat of Eddard Stark, the Warden of the North, and Robert's longtime friend, in order to offer the position of Hand to him. Eddard agrees, and returns with the King to Kings Landing. Simultaneously an exiled King Arey's Targaryian has given up his younger sister, Deanary's, to Khal Drogo, the ruler of a vast Mongolian like hoard of Dorthraki in the hopes he can then lead his 30,000 man strong army back to Westeros to reclaim his father's throne.The story moves rather slowly at first, setting up the story and the conflict within it. Not to say any of this is boring, or unnecessary. It isn't until halfway through the season when the conflict between the two competing families, the Starks and the Lannisters, when things start to pick up and the political positioning is replaces by violence. Needless to say, there is a lot going on in this show. Without fantastic writers, and directors who know what they're doing, this could easily have become a wild mess. With so many POV characters playing a vital role in the story as a whole it's hard to given them all the screen time they need to become fleshed out characters while still moving forward at a pace fast enough to keep the audience's attention. Season one is the easiest season to adapt as there are far fewer locations then there will be in following season, and less characters, but even so it must have been very difficult to do. There is no filler, few scenes are wasted, and each character is given room to grow as befitting their status in the books.I haven't even touched on the acting, the effects, the overall look of the show, or the strength of the characters. Needless to say these are all top notch. Every character is portrayed perfectly, from Tyrion Lannister, to Jon Snow, to Eddard Stark and Deanary's Targaryian. If there is one complaint I can give this show, however, it's how rarely they actually show  some of the locations in this show. Granted, with budget restraints they couldn't Lord of the Rings everything, but it would have been nice to get some sweeping shots of Kings Landing, The Erye, Riverrun (which wasn't really shown at all) or Vas Dorthrak. The only location to really got a lot of detail was Winterfell, and it looked amazing. Even for being so briefly show, the locations look fantastic. I just would have liked to see of them.So who would enjoy this show, you ask? Well, if you're not squeamish and the two B's (blood and boobs) don't bother you, I'd recommend this show to, well, anyone. If you're a fan of fantasy, it goes without question you should see it. If you like character drama's, see it. If you like action and battles, you'll get that in season 2, so watch this first. If you like scheming, mystery, and politics, see it. I could not recommend this show enough.Replay value; extremely high.

reviewText: There's so much information available about Game of Thrones that the newcomer to it may feel overwhelmed.  So here's a capsule review intended for  people who have heard of this immensely popular series but have never read the books or seen any episodes, and are wondering if it's worth their while to start watching the DVDs.Game of Thrones is the first book of a heroic fantasy series by American author George R. R. Martin.  The books, like Lord of the Rings, form an extended epic set in a detailed alternative world.  This world is more or less medieval in atmosphere, and includes a certain magical element:  sorcery is effective to a limited extent, and there are actual dragons and other creatures considered legendary in our own world.  The plot concerns the intrigues and wars of various aristocratic families maneuvering for power.The HBO series is considered by most fans of the book to be a faithful adaptation.  It has also been highly and justly praised for its quality as entertainment - personally, I think it is the best television show ever made.  The acting is of a very high quality, with most of the characters being perfectly cast, and the realization of the alternative world in its landscape, architecture, and costume is superb.  And the story is told about as clearly as can be managed with such a complicated plot.  Special effects are used relatively sparingly for this sort of production, but when they are used, they are absolutely convincing.So with all that, what's not to like?  Well, this series, good as it is, isn't for everyone.  For one thing, it pushes the envelope with sex and violence - it doesn't go beyond what's currently considered acceptable in adult TV, but it goes right up to the edge.  And there is plenty of adult language, sometimes of the bluntest kind.  It also is so complicated, with so many characters, and so much backstory presented by references in the current story, that people who haven't read the books may find it difficult to follow at first.  The DVD set has some informational inserts and special features that will help, but many beginning viewers will find they have to beyond those to other information on the internet or in spin-off books in order to sort out who's who and what's happening.  And the story, unlike some other heroic fantasies, is generally not very romantic or whimsical.  There are few unambiguously good characters, many of the ones who seem most positive get killed off, and the overall atmosphere might be described as grim seriousness punctuated with grim humor.Recommendation:  if the characteristics mentioned above don't put you off, by all means watch these DVDs:  you'll probably find yourself rapidly becoming fascinated with them.  But be aware of what you are getting into.  And above all, don't let the fact that these are fantasies which include queens and dragons and sorcerers mislead you into thinking they are suitable for children.  You do not want your kids in the room when these are playing.
summary: A review for those wondering if they'd like it

reviewText: My wife and I recently finished the first season of Game of Thrones on DVD. We both enjoyed it as a sort of bloody, sex-filled, As the World Turns-type show. Beyond the hacking, slashing, and whoring what we both noticed was that there were a lot of holes in the show which diminished our enjoyment. Some examples SPOILER ALERT:- In one of the first episodes a boy is hurt while his father is out traveling with the king. Almost immediately after he is hurt, the father appears at the boy's side. We have no way of knowing how his father received word of the injury; he's just suddenly there which feels like a cinematic mistake.- When the main character arrives in his new post as "King's Hand" he is asked to make a decision on whether or not a tournament will be held. After quick analysis, he determines it is a waste of money and it should not happen. But then in the following episode or two the tournament is apparently happening. There's no explanation for the sudden change from "its not going to happen," to the tournament actually happening.- The the main character is executed he has hold of essential information about the death of the king and the rise to the thrown of a child who is not actually the heir. I find it odd that upon finding out that he is going to be beheaded, the main characters does not divulge any of this information to the people in attendance and seemingly lets this HUGE secret die with him. Ultimately this makes the main character look like an idiot.There are numerous more holes, unexplained items and so on, that ultimately made Game of Thrones Season 1 less like a fantasy epic and more like a poorly written fantasy daytime soap opera (which can be fun in its own right, but surely not to be taken seriously in the way, of say, Lord of the Rings).
summary: Plot Holes and Gaps SPOILER ALERT

reviewText: I have heard about George R.R. Martin for a number of years, but had not (and still have not) read his "Games of Thrones" series, or any of his other books for that matter. I had nothing against him and I rather like fantasy with K Gabriel Kay being one of my favourite authors. It is simply that I had too many other books to read and had never, up to now, taken the time and trouble to start with Games of Thrones. On Friday 14 June, I bought Season 1, at least. The next day, at 5 pm, I watched the first episode, and the next nine followed in quick succession, giving you an idea at when time I finished and to what extent I got hooked in. Since then, I have made up for my "error" and all of the books have just arrived...Since I am not yet part of the absolute fans, and haven't yet read the books, I cannot assess to what extent the series mirror the books. However, as you will have guessed, they are rather entertaining - it is very hard to stop in the middle of an episode and grab something to eat, for instance.Another strongpoint is that this is yet another series from HBO, which I have enjoyed just as much as the previous ones (the two Rome series, in particular). Arguably, HBO series tend to lean on the "realistic" side and may not be for the "faint hearted": the fights and stories tend to be gory and full of sex. This was not a problem for me and it is hardly surprising for a fantasy story set in a world that seems to have borrowed many of its features from the fourteenth century in Europe.A third element which I very much liked was some of the book's features, such as the huge Wall - loosely inspired by Hadrian's Wall and the Great Wall of China - that separate the continent inhabited by the humans from the far north where all sorts of creatures lurk, each one more deadly and horrible than the next. Another of these nice touches was the crows used to carry messages across the continent, allowing the contended great Houses to keep abreast of what may happening a couple of thousand of leagues away.Then, of course, there are the actors. My initial expectations here were rather low, with the exception of Sean Bean, who was just as good as I expected him to be in the role of Eddard Stark, Warden of the North. I was agreeably surprised by some of the other characters, especially the four main Lannisters (the father, his daughter the Queen, and his two sons) and King Robert Barratheon. I also liked the performance of the actor playing Lady Catelynn. I less liked some of the other performances, such as Daenerys for instance, but none were unbearable or absolute drivel.I am waiting with some trepidation for season 2 to come out in Europe. I wonder if it will be as good since some of my favourite actors will no longer be part of it. Meanwhile, I'll go through Martin's books and since the smallest of these is 500 pages and the average size is more like 750, this should keep me patient for a little while...Addendum on 4 July: I have just finished Game of Thrones (the book), which I found excellent. The series is remarkably faifhtful to the book itself, with only a few things left out, such as the two brothers of King Robert Barratheon. While Lord Stannis is only mentioned ans does not appear in the book, Lord Renly does, even if briefly. Reading the book after having seen the series has reinforced my initial impressions and assessment. Four additional actors which I did not mention initially and who seemed to correspond rather well to their characters in the book as those playing the roles of the devious Lord Barrish (Littlefinger) and of Varys the eunuch, of Prince (and then King) Joffrey, rather good in his role of a cruel, mean and spoilt little twerp, and of Sandor Clegane (the Hound).

reviewText: Game of Thrones is HBOs television series based on George R R Martin's series, The Song of Ice and Fire. The episodes take place on the fictional continent of Westeros, separated by the Narrow Sea. The season begins, for the most part, in Winterfell which is one of the seven kingdoms under the reign of King Robert Barrathian (current occupier of the iron throne), who resides in the capital, King's Landing, to the south.  Winterfell, the furthest north of the kingdoms, is under the command of Lord Ned Stark, the king's most trusted friend who fought by his side when he took the iron throne.The first few episodes are focused in Winterfell so that the large cast may be introduced slowly; several story lines branch from here and run parallel through the remainder of the series, often crossing paths. Ned Stark and his wife, familiarly known as Cat, have three sons and two daughters, though Ned also has a son named Jon Snow from an affair he had during the war for the iron throne. Jon joins his uncle, Ned's brother, in the Night's Watch on The Wall, a barrier between the kingdoms and what lies beyond. The Wall is north of Winterfell and beyond it is a wintery wasteland occupied by "wildlings" as well as legendary zombie-like beings. The Night's Watch serves to protect Westeros from the terrors north of The Wall.In Winterfell, the Starks soon learn of the death of Jon Arryn, the hand of the King and Lady Stark's brother-in-law. The King and his family inform the Starks they will be coming to Winterfell, but the Starks know the only reason for the trip is that Robert will ask Ned to fill the position of king's hand.  Upon the royal arrival, we are introduced to the queen and her brothers of the Lannister family; one is her twin, known as King slayer (because he was who stabbed the previous king when Robert took the throne), the other is called the imp because he is a dwarf. The Lannister family is the wealthiest in Westeros, but the Starks soon learn they are not to be trusted.The remainder of the season is split between dealings in Winterfell, King's Landing, The Vale, and the whereabouts of the two surviving Tarrgarians. The Tarrgarians are recognized by their silvery hair and were the previous holders of the iron throne, when it was taken, only two of the children survived and now plot their way home from their current position across the narrow sea. The girl, Danarys Tarrgarian, is forced to wed Khal Drogo, leader of the Dothraki, a savage clan. The marriage is forced by her brother in hope that the Dothraki will lend him the power to cross the narrow sea and take back his homeland. Danarys learns to love her new husband and his people; she is pregnant with Khal's son.I have chosen to end my synopsis here in effort not to spoil too much, but the series itself is essentially a fictional history set in somewhat medieval times, though far more glamorous. The plot and it's subplots do a remarkable job of engaging viewers as well as invoking suspense. I began watching the series because I had heard of its popularity, though I wasn't initially captivated. I soon, however, found myself constantly thinking about it and what would happen next and feel pretty empty when I run out of episodes.

reviewText: Almost all the reviews of Game of Thrones have been very positive.  Written by those who have gobbled it up.  My review is tentative as I've only gotten through the first 2.5 shows so far, and I didn't read the books.  I read that the writer loved J. R. R. Tolkien's works [a plus for me, but it's extremely difficult for anyone else to match the quality of Tolkien's main work] so I am not able to comment on the original writing in the books.As for the show: The acting so far is very good.  The cinematography is very good.  Costuming and integration of real with CG elements so far is spectacular.  About the story?  Yes most of the characters are self-centered, manipulative, deceptive, untrustworthy.  In that sense it's like a lot of history, but in a fantasy setting.  As for the fantasy: SO FAR, little is in evidence.  One sees that apparently dragons are going to appear at some point, and there are vague "white walkers" and strange things beyond a high wall, protecting the civilized areas.  Something not immediately apparent in very brief reviews: if this world were real, it must have had a highly elliptical orbit.  Summers last for many decades.  Winters can last an entire lifetime.  As the story starts, summer is beginning to change to winter.  Kids and young men who have known nothing but summer are in for a rude awakening.  The elderly remember, or at least they know the stories.To be hooked on a story one must sympathise with at least some characters.  The focus initially is on the Stark family, who rule the northern of 7 centers of power.  Interestingly the father is first seen in a harsh light, executing a man some would think deserved some mercy.  But he tells his son, "It's important to carry out a decree you order."  [Presumably so you can witness the ugly consequences, and know the implications].  In his world rules are rules and can't be bent, for the protection of everyone.  As we later watch his interaction with his family I felt sympathetic to all of them [which I suppose means they won't do well...]Yes there is some nudity and there is some violence, though so far neither full frontal nudity, nor gratuitously graphic violence.  In that respect, "The Tudors" was definitely worse so far.I find myself becoming hooked.  It's expensive to produce high-quality shows [which is why many get cancelled early].  I think it deserves the audience support it is getting.  If I get all the way through four seasons I shall update my review with a much broader perspective but so far find myself wondering: WHAT HAPPENS NEXT?
summary: What's Wrong with Soap Opera, Anyhow?

reviewText: Please note: As of thiis date, May 17, it turns out that I haven't been able to do weekly updates, primarily because this review would become unwieldy. I think you'll find that the descriptions of the episodes included here should be enough to decide whether this is worth watching. My conclusion? Yes, although I'm finding significant differences in the apparent ages and characterizations of some of the people - compared to the book.When I started this review, only the first episode had aired and I've continued to update this review - up to a point - and plan to do a summary of the overall series eventually.This series is based on the first of four books in the George RR. Martin series, Game of Thrones. Other titles are A Clash of Kings, A Storm of Swords, A Feast for Crows, etc (see link below). The corruption and betrayal that will ensue between the Stark and Lannister families is obvious - although the full details are, of course, yet to be revealed. Movie adaptations of books have their pros and cons and this series - so far- is no exception. Clearly, plenty of money has been spent to create a realistic sense of the time and place. You can almost feel the chill in the air and the sense of danger is palpable from the start. It does not take long for graphic violence and sex to appear.After seeing the first episode, I went back and reread part of the book and that episode did stay true to the events in the book that were covered so far. For those unfamiliar with the book, it could be confusing to keep track of the various families. Also, the television version is quite graphic when it comes to sexuality and violence. This is not a family friendly series but then...would anyone familiar with the books expect it to be?The setting and political intrigues between the various noble families is clear. The tight script and editing made the sex scenes stand out while the depth of the novel and character descriptions took second place. But the first episode was still very riveting and I'm eager to see how the series progresses.George R. R. Martin's A Game of Thrones 4-Book Boxed Set: A Game of Thrones, A Clash of Kings, A Storm of Swords, and A Feast for Crows (A Song of Ice and Fire).Update: As the series proceeds, as might be expected, tensions increase and loyalties are tested. Young Bran remains in a coma, with his life hanging in the balance. By the end of the latest episode (thus far), keep an eye on Bran. Again, plenty of graphic nudity combined with cruelty. And of course details from the book have either been tightened or eliminated (how on earth could a series capture the vivid descriptions of the author?) So I've downgraded my expectations somewhat.Kudos do have to go to the producers and directors of the HBO series for allowing each character to be introduced and evolve, perhaps a major aid to those unfamiliar with the book.But back to the series....Jon Snow, the "bastard son" is off to join the Night's Watch. Ned also leaves while Dany (Daenerys) is taught the sexual techniques which she hopes will please her new husband. There are hints that their relationship has the potential to grow deeper, although that is far from certain as the episode ends. Because I'm working hard not to include too many spoilers, I'll only add that some viewers may find at least one death in this episode to be distressing while another is not unexpected.Catelyn continues to reject Jon as she remains by Bran's side. But she can't prevent Jon from showing his affection for Bran before he leaves. The teenager, Joffrey, appears to be wooing Sansa Stark successfully - until they run into Anya, fencing with the butcher's boy. Joffrey bullies and taunts the boy and things come to a distressing climax (again, trying to prevent spoilers). Meanwhile, the direwolfs are proving to be more than just pets, with far greater insight and power than imagined. There is a very touching scene involving one of them as well as a painful event with another.At several points, the Dragon's Eggs are shown, building momentum. This time around, I watched with a friend who hadn't read the book. He was completely hooked by the end of the episode. Again, would love to hear others' take on the show so far. These are only brief recaps of each episode and I can't include every crucial plot development or this review will soon become far too long. I hope I've included enough to intrigue you.
summary: Will try to update review as each episode appears

reviewText: This show really does live up to the accolades, I haven't read the books but the fact that the writer is closely involved with the series and script adaption is obviously part of the reason the show is so well structured and produced. I am not usually a fan of these type of fantasy shows but what sets Game of Thrones apart is the great characters who are created to be more real, dimensional and human even though the mystical and unexplained happens they are regular humans for the most part dealing with extreme situations.Also the production and set design is incredible shooting on location in regions that evoke the performance also adds another layer something I like to see in an age where green screen performance can be a little obvious regardless of how good the actor is, there is something to be said for making the set so authentic that it inspires the performance.There are plenty of great reviews in depth here on Amazon, so all I want to say is from someone who usually finds fantasy a bore, that this has kept me wanting more at every episode!
summary: Great Production Values, Acting and Writing

reviewText: Every episode costs $3. It's overpriced. The scenery is lovely, and the series has one or two good actors. However, this story lacks irony and true character development (they're all "ordinary joes", which is supposed to make them identifiable-meaning they don't have true swings of temperment, ambitions, anything...) I don't care that that one is a king and this one is a little boy who is crippled for life because of an attempt on his life, or another is a car salesman from Toledo. There is never any doubt what any one of them is going to do. I can honestly say that after 2 episodes, that I know for certain that the aforementioned boy will somehow wreak violent revenge on the guy who pushed him off the tower-but only after much time (and viewer patience) has passed, and only for the death of his dad, which I foresee... I know the sister sold as a bride will wreak violent revenge on everybody for the death of her husband with the eyeliner. Yeah, I haven't seen the episode where he dies, but I'm quite certain he will. The car salesman from Toledo will have sex with somebody that is considered sexy because it's somehow violent itself (it's a rape, or it's incest, or something else gross). Then the salesman will plot dire revenge (which will only be death) against somebody for doing the very same thing he did. I envision more tournament battles amongst two characters to the death. I envision the discovery of many creatures that never play a significant part in the development of the plot, but will somehow be the deciding factor in some epic finale. (Maybe the white walker thingie? Or will the white walker thingies be a persecuted minority?) Anyway, after I post this, I'm gonna Wikipedia the series to see how many of these predictions were true. I might have missed one or two, but on the whole, I think I rather have the thing figured out. As one commenter put it, (who gave it 5 stars, by the way-wish I'd read her post before buying it) "it's renaissance porn with gore".
summary: I enjoy a story w/political intrigue...but this isn't it. Thrones is dull.

reviewText: Few shows have been more eagerly awaited than the arrival of HBO's adaptation of George R.R. Martin's masterful and massive epic "Game of Thrones" (the first in a series).  As the books have progressed, however, faithful followers have cried foul as promises have yet to be delivered.  But no matter where you stand in that controversy, there is little debate to the majesty and quality of the novel "Thrones"--an almost instant classic in the adult fantasy genre.  Multi-layered and ambitious, this sprawling tale charts a powerful story of intrigue, political machinations, and violence amidst the brutal landscape of a nation divided.  It is not a production you could approach half-heartedly.  To do justice to the novel's intricacies required a massive cast, extensive period sets and costumes, lavish effects and a focused and intelligent screenplay.  Well, creators David Benioff (a top notch novelist himself--check out City of Thieves) and D.B. Weiss were up to the challenge and the astute HBO has once again backed a winner.  Make no mistake, this is no cheesy kid's story--this is dark and relentless entertainment for people who enjoy quality programming.At the heart of "Game of Thrones" is the Stark family.  Living in relative isolation, patriarch Sean Bean is called to assist the King when a vacancy opens up due to suspect causes.  Suspicions have fallen on the King's wife (Lena Headley) and her twin brother (Nikolaj Coster-Waldau), and there may be further nefarious acts in store for His Royal Highness.  When the Stark's young son witnesses something he should not have, a violent act that will have long range repercussions occurs.  This, however, is just the jumping off point for a tale with numerous dimensions.  There are the exiled Targaryen siblings, a brother and sister who have a claim to the throne and hope to retake the power seat by aligning with a barbaric and powerful tribe of warriors.  Bean's illegitimate son figures prominently as well, as a guardian on The Wall preparing for imminent danger.  There are so many other peripheral characters and story lines, it would be impossible to delineate them all concisely.  There are assassination plots, vigilante justice, court intrigue, various sexual escapades, vicious barbarism, unseen monstrosities, plenty of wolves, family drama, and a dragon egg or two.Through it all, there is a recurrent theme that "Winter is Coming"--a threat that poses a menace and a danger that may be unavoidable.  This show is not for the faint of heart, and should only be considered for age appropriate audiences.  As an HBO production, the screenplay doesn't shy away from the gritty violence that this time period and life style would necessitate.  I, for one, appreciate the authentic feel to the drama.  This show is also not for the casual viewer.  It unfolds at its own pace, much like a good novel.  It requires both patience and attention to really appreciate just how sophisticated and complex this tale is.  It is a grown-up and smart piece!The show looks absolutely fantastic.  Technical aspects of the production are as good, or better, than any comparable feature film.  The cast is also uniformly excellent.  It would be impossible, again, to highlight everyone in the cast that deserves a special mention--so I'll limit my accolades to Peter Dinklage.  As Tyrion Lannister (the black sheep brother of Headley and Coster-Waldau), Dinklage steals just about every scene that he is in.  Funny, sardonic, and wise--this Imp (as he's called) has a terrific knack of putting things into perspective.  Dinklage has had many great roles in his life--but this is a performance of true star wattage.  Don't be surprised to see him invited to the Emmy race for Best Supporting Actor! He is one of the best things in this great presentation.  I truly admire and recommend "Game of Thrones" because it never panders.  It requires your active participation in the narrative to fully appreciate how well constructed it is--and any show that treats me as an intelligent human being deserves recognition in this age of formulaic TV.  Watch it--and read the books (Game of Thrones and A Clash of Kings especially are monumental)!  KGHarris, 5/11.
summary: Complex, Brutal, Smart And Sophisticated--A Fantasy Epic Geared Toward Adults Proves HBO Does It Best

reviewText: I'm not to sure why consumers at Amazon and critics on the net are giving the series such glowing reviews.The acting is really a mixed bag. Yes, there are some outstanding performances by some of the leading actors:Mark Addy is terrific in the role of Robert Baratheon, a once heroic king who has become overweight and buffoonish in middle age and is plagued by an unhappy marriage. Maisie Williams, who plays my favorite character in the books, Arya, is an absolute scene stealer -- she is exactly how I envisioned the character of Arya, scrappy and adorable with those huge eyes of hers. And of course Peter Dinklage is terrific as Tyrion Lannister, the deformed but cunning black sheep of the Lannister family. There are also some reasonably good performances from Michele Fairley (Catelyn Stark), Sophie Turner (Sansa Stark), Richard Madden (Robb Stark) and Emilia Clarke (Danys Targearean). Unfortunatley, thats were the good performances end, and we haven't quite covered all the main characters yet. I'm not sure what happened to Sean Bean since the Lord of the Rings, but whatever happened, it isnt good. He looks old, tired, and distracted in the role of Ned Stark. He is not able to hold is own in scenes with Robert Baratheon (and he is supposed to be the great King's most trusted and loyal ally), he cannot hold is own is scenes with his wife, Catelyn Stark. I'm as big a fan of Sean Bean as there is -- I loved him in the Tom Clancy movie Patriot Games, and he was great as Boromir in LOTOR, but wow was he miscast for this series. Another huge letdown is Lena Headley as Cersei Lannister. Headley is a magnificent looking woman, as Cersei is in the books, but that's where the resemblance ends. Were Cersei is cruel, calculating and fiendishly cunning in the series, Headley actually has this strange look of COMPASSION (of all things) in her eyes most of the time. And where Cersei is a force of nature in the books, screaming and cursing her contempt at wretched brother Tyrion, or arduously flirting with her beloved brother Jaime, Headly is a drooping lilly in this series -- her voice is barely above a whisper most of the time! She gets overwhelmed in scenes with Mark Addy, Peter Dinklage, even Michele Fairley as Catelyn Stark proves too much for her. The same criticism applies to Nikolaj Coster-Waldau in the role of Jaime Lannister. Again, Nikolaj looks the part of Jaime, handsome and roguish. But where Jaime is a dashing, daring, risk-seeking warrior in the books, Nikolaj comes across as some stuffy academic, more comfortable poring over tomes in some library by his lonesome rather than baring steel on the battlefield.I would recommnend a viewing if you are a fan of the books, but, as a result of some of the tepid performances by some of the cast members, dont expect many repeat viewings!
summary: Not nearly as good as the books

reviewText: 4.6 starsWhy is HBO so far beyond its competitors? They keep on making cinema-quality series while the other networks make pure drivel. Game Of Thrones is quite simply, like The Sopranos, The Wire and so many other HBO shows, in another class altogether from what's on TV.HBO is tailor-made for folks like me who avoid TV and grab the pick of the litter when it comes out on dvd. Or in this case blu-ray, which is perfect for such a lush production as GOT. Everything here is top-notch, while focusing on character above all (though never sacrificing huge sets and epic landscapes). Martin's books do, and that's why this is such a fine choice for adaptation: drama and lots of it. There's plenty of slash and hack for action fans (and be warned, there's some very graphic stuff, but less sensational violence and more brutally real), yet the real focus is on relationships, and the fine acting makes it work.There's not a duff performance in the bunch, and some real winners, above all Dinklage and Gillen, who as in The Wire plays a morally-challenged political weasel to perfection. Dinklage has a small part, but works it to the hilt (as in the original Death At A Funeral, such a great film). There are myriad plot lines here, and the excellent casting makes it all work. Harrington and Bean are two other standouts.The pacing of this first season is truly impressive, as is the credit the viewer is given for having some brains. Many things are hinted at rather than spoonfed to us, and it involves us to a much greater and more satisfying extent. Plus, in a rare twist, the series is very true to the books, and some of it is even written by Martin. Respect for the author's vision! What a novel concept...Above all, I like that they didn't try to make Lord Of The Rings again (HB RR O)---this is fantasy but it's more concerned with people than mythical creatures, and that keeps it always compelling. If they keep this series at this level it will go down with The Sopranos and The Wire as one of the best tv series ever made.{Edit: 4/12/12. Well that won't be the case judging from the first few episodes of season two. Looks like killing off your best actor and character ain't a very good idea. This new season just feels more Hollywood than the first so far. Too bad.]
summary: One of the best fantasy tv series to date

reviewText: We do not have television so our son recommended this to me as he knows my interest in this kind of movie.  I have read the first book, so I was interested in seeing this.  I thought it was a great presentation and enjoyed it very much and feel they did an excellent job sticking with the book, however I never can understand why those who make projects to be shown on TV or even in the theatre seem to feel that making it as sexual graphic as possible will bring in patrons.  I am certainly no prude, but I found the over abundance of frontal nudity and graphic sexual intercourse scenes totally tacky and unnecessary....actually, I've seen porno movies with less.  My son says the next season is not as bad and I certainly hope so.  I am stunned that this kind of presentation is even on TV...I knew there was a reason we unplugged it many years ago.

reviewText: I think that Game of Thrones has become the show that all other subsequent fantasy shows will be compared to.  The show takes twists and turns that I cannot anticipate (having not read all the books yet) and keeps surprising me.  While not always pleasant, it keeps me riveted and wanting more each week, and now that season 3 is over, I really miss it, so I've started reading the books.  HBO has spared no expense with this show; the acting, writing, special effects, costumes, editing, sets - all of it - is top notch.What I enjoy most about the show is how no one person is all good or all bad (except, maybe Joffrey...).  I find myself rooting for a character who I previously disliked.  You grow to understand these characters and their journeys are fascinating.  Even friends of mine who would never step foot in a theater to see Lord of the Rings, are watching this show.  The fantasy element is completely secondary to the excellent storytelling.I highly recommend this show and hope that many more people give it a chance.

reviewText: This show has everything. Murder, rape, incest, treason, beheadings, arson, rape (I know I said rape twice... I like rape), giants, chases, escapes, miracles, true love...Yeah, it has every thing all right. Great production values, outstanding acting, sweeping panoramic shots of amazing places...Everything except complex characters with a modicum of depth. The only one with any depth is presumably one of the ones we are supposed to hate. But mostly they all suck. Honestly the first season is pretty decent, especially given what it is, but it goes down hill sharply, and quite frankly I'm surprised it has gained so much popularity. I guess it goes to show. People love crap. And if you like shallow characters and pointless plot twists with no end in sight... you will surely like this drivel.

reviewText: The five star rating is for the quality of the show - not the set itself. This is due to a couple of issues I had with the design of the box set. The DVD release of season 1 had five discs, so I was surprised that the blu-ray release had the same number of discs seeing as blu-ray holds considerably more information. Each disc only has two episodes on it. So despite my mild annoyance at having to change each disc after only two episodes, this is hardly a dealbreaker. The quality of the show in high definition makes this purchase well worth it. The set also includes several Easter eggs, or as the makers of the set are calling them - dragon eggs. Unlocking them will open extra features which should satisfy hardcore fans who will take the time to look. Each disc includes special features but it does not say which special features are on which disc. The features are listed within the booklet. However, the booklet doesn't state the location of the feature either. This seems a bit of an oversight on HBOs part and makes accessing special features a little less user friendly.
summary: Great Box Set - Look for the hidden dragon eggs!

reviewText: I purchased the Game of Thrones First Season. This film is poorly written and directed. The characters are generally cold. The characters in the story need more development to make it interesting. I am guessing that it is a film which is supposed to be an epic similar to Lord of the Rings. The producers of this film spent more time on very graphic violence, many scenes of very vulgar sexual acts, and the entire movie represents a cynical way of looking at life. For the money spent making this movie, it is one of the worst movies I have ever seen. I imagine that the creators of the movie had no respect for their audience, assumed that they were stupid and need violence and sex to pay attention to the movie.I have seen movies with sex and violence in them before before, but this one is really overdone and it does not work to make the story connect.The first season ends, which I am assuming is a cliff-hanger. The story ends without conclusion. One of the queens immolates herself and survives bearing dragon children. I am guessing that they will be unleashed in the conquest of the throne. There should not be a season two, judging by season one. If you like character and story, you will not like this film. If you like sex and violence, you can find better films. If you just want intoxicate yourself in a bar and see a brawl, this movie is for you.
summary: Game of Thrones or Game of Hollywood Idiots?

reviewText: Game of Thrones is definitely engaging to watch.  However, I really don't want to see burbling blood coming out of a guy's throat who was stabbed. reviewText: I'll count myself among the masses of come-late readers who got sucked into the (now 5) novels after watching the show. HBO seems committed to following the books to the conclusion so long as it's economically viable (just renewed through season 3 which will cover 1/2 of book 3) meaning we could easily 10 years here (at a minimum 7 novels and some split to two seasons).::::Though I don't consider them spoilers, some plot set-up follows in the next paragraphs::::At first impression GOT, based very closely on George R.R. Martin's Song of Ice and Fire series, is a story about the Stark family, lords of the North in the mythical land of Westeros. Lord Eddard Stark is called upon by his childhood friend, partner in rebellion and now King of the Seven Kingdoms, to take the position of Hand of the King and travel south to Kings Landing to basically rule the kingdom while Robert "hunts, drinks and whores himself to an early grave. The family must divide up, the eldest son Robb, his mother and two youngest brothers remain in their home Winterfell, Ned and their two daughters (the eldest now betrothed to the crowned prince)travel to Kings Landing while Ned's Bastard son goes north to "the wall" (a 700 ft miles long wall of solid ice separating the "wild" north) to join the black guard.Very quickly all semblance of peace is gone. Stark learns that the old hand may have been murdered, the queen may have born her children out of incest and a move to grab the thrown may be in play. Meanwhile the last decedents of the over-thrown king are in the east, the vanquished prince has traded his sister as wife to a massive tribe of horse-lord barbarians in exchange for an army to march into Kings Landing to re-take the throne.A death late in the season sent some viewers crying fowl and running from the show, though, it's merely following the book and is the catalyst for the events of the next for novels.The show appears to have been shot digitally, not a bad thing, but blu-ray hounds will note the grainy look, but it saves a ton of money and the show cost over $50,000,000 for 10 episodes (season two is 15 - 25 million over that yet). The DTS-HD track is fine, though the nuance sounds you get in a theatrical film aren't there to begin with, nor are they required. The production values are excellent, no visual effect looks cheap, nor do you ever have to take the show with a grain of salt because it's not a theatrical film. The show is also relentless in gore, sex and explicit nudity as well as language, this is not for children or the easily offended.The acting is near flawless and the dialogue well written if not verbatim from the book. The one issue is the heightened age of everyone in the story. All the children are 2 - 3 years older than the book, the Starks should be at the most in mid to late thirties are pushing fifty. No idea why the did this, anymore than I understand casting a woman in her mid-twenties to play the 13 year old Dany (except they couldn't have a 13 year old with all the nudity and sex.) In the long-run though it will add up to continuity issues in a story where keeping track of when-what-happened is already hell. As the plot gets thicker and more complex in the next seasons the writers are going to have to alter history a bit to fit the age difference's in. But when Dany's older brother looks at the 24 year old woman and says "you have a woman's body now" it sounds really stupid because, yeah, she's had it for 10 years!The issue with the Blu-Ray is the menus. For some idiotic reason each disk has the same, exact menu options, even if the content of the link isn't available on that disk. So done watching EP2? Click EP3 and a message "insert disk 2" comes up. Same thing with extras.  And there's "In Episode" feature, an annoying drop down you have to keep clicking through rather than a "pop-up" feature that feeds you facts as you relax and enjoy.It's a great show, really alone in it's class and puts Spartacus to shame in a hundred different ways. Absolutely worth the Blu-Ray set and books. It's also noteworthy that there's such a depth to the story and mythology you can watch these over and over and keep coming away with new information you missed or didn't get before.
summary: Show is better than the Blu-Ray

reviewText: Just the fact that this product has been reviewed over 1300 times says quite a bit about Game of Thrones. There's very little that I can add to what has already been said---this is an excellent series considering that its a television adaption of George R.R. Martin's best-selling novels. In fact, I've never seen a television adaption that did more justice to its source material. The writers made a remarkable effort to stick as closely to the books as possible. There have been a number of criticisms from other reviewers, some of which seem fair and others which are way out in left field in my opinion. It is these I'm going to address in my review, and by doing so, offer a review of Game of Thrones itself.1) It's not like Lord of the Rings, and therefore is not true fantasy:My response: hogwash! LOTR was written 50 years ago and targeted to children and teens. LOTR was a great series, both in literature and film, but it is not the definition of fantasy. GOT is for adults, it's fresh, and it's author, GRR Martin, specifically took great pains to correct or address many of the faults found in traditional fantasy epics; that is, untarnished, invincible heroes who can do no wrong and never die. In GOT there are no angels or saints, and anybody can die at any time. This makes for great edge of your seat viewing.2) It's graphically violent.True! Both the books and the television series are extremely violent and gory. For me, this adds to the constant tension and sense of danger, and brings a real-world grit to the show often lacking in traditional fantasy. But for those who do not like a lot of blood and violence, this series is not for you.3) It's gratuitous and pornographic.Agreed. That's HBO for you. The books had their fair share of sex, but nothing like what's in the show. It doesn't bother me personally, but it also brings nothing to the story and seems to be there for no other reason than to titillate over-sexed heterosexual males. There is far more female nudity than male, in fact, almost comically there is an exposed breast in every third scene. Again, not a problem for me, but it adds nothing at all to the entertainment.4) It's soap-operatic. Again, true. It's the nature of epic television series in general, but this is a soap opera of huge proportions.5) It's boring.Huh? On what planet could GOT be boring??? It's chaulk full of violence and intrigue, with dashes of romance and revenge, mystery, horror, and magic. This is the definition of entertainment!6) It's cheap-looking.I'm on the fence about this criticism. For television, it's at the very top of production quality and attention to detail. For a feature-length film, no. But this is a television series, folks. We're never going to get movie-quality production in a television series---the budget and time constraints just won't allow it. It looks really good for what it is.7) It has a homosexual scene.Yes, unfortunately it only has one, and there's not much to see other than two young men nude from the waist up. They don't even kiss. If you can watch a series with over 500 heterosexual sex scenes, and find fault with one homosexual scene that doesn't even contain sex, then you need to move to another part of the world---say Uganda or Iran or somewhere else stuck in the dark ages.To sum up, GOT is a fantastic series, as good as television entertainment gets. However, if you demand unicorns and elves in your fantasy, turn squeemish at the sight of blood, and do not want to see gratuitous nudity every 3-10 minutes, than GOT is definitely not for you.

reviewText: In those words, you will either like it or you won't.  I usually like the period royalty shows/ stories such as The Tudors, or The White Queen, but not necessarily the ones that lean more towards fantasy, but this show is pretty amazing:  The sets, the costumes, the stories, the quotes about life in general no matter the time period in this show are pretty great.There is some soft porn scenes in just about every episode, as it is HBO, there is blood and gore and mutilation, so for children it is not.  Started watching this weekend to replace The Walking Dead.  I am almost done with season 1.The drama starts with The burly big dark-haired King Robert and his family of blondes going to meet his old friend Ned to ask him a favor.  The king used to have a love for his friend's sister.  His beautiful Queen Cersie, and her family, the Lannister line:  her one brother is like the evil prince in Shrek 2 (Handsome, but shallow), her son with the king, Joffrey, as beautiful and blond and with some possible evil tendencies himself, the "imp" brother, played expertly by Peter Dinklage, who is very smart with words and seems to have a way of always getting himself out of his constant dilemmas.  As with royal bloodlines, there are some secrets going on behind the scenes, and some drama ensues during this visit between the two families, making the King side with either his wife and family, or his friend and their children.Meanwhile there are some other forces out there with a brother and sister, fair-skinned and blond, almost reminiscent of the Dark Crystal gelflings, elf-like, who are lords of dragons, or something, whose father lost the throne, and they are forced to align with some barbaric horse-worshipping clan for their army.  She must become one with her new family so she can win her kingdom  back.  And so the battle for the iron throne begins. . .
summary: Great fantasy / battle for the kingdom show."When you play the Game of Thrones, you win or you die.  There is no Middle Ground."

reviewText: I'm very happy I went with the blue ray on this one cause it has a quality and extras I dont think the dvds have. If you have not read the books, this set is for you as it has extras that explain all the lore, the different family houses, relationships and personal histories of people. This is a fantastic story for those unfamilar and are thinking of doing a blind buy. Think of this as a cross between the Tudors and lord of the rings. Like Lord of the rings, there is a fantasy element present but its more about the people and their vying  for control over the Realm or just trying to survive the tyrany and war between the lords. The Fantasy element is something that starts small and is very slowly building in the background. Its a merciless story where the just are not rewarded and tyrants are not stopped by the good guys. Its alot closer  to how things would really be in a world  that happened to have some fantasy creatures in it. This is a whole world you'll be getting to know with its own history and cultures in different parts of its lands with different families and a cast of about 40 going into season 3.

reviewText: This series is outstanding, the writing is impeccable.After watching the first episode of "Game of Thrones" about a year ago, I became completely enamored of the show. The rest of last summer was spent reading the series of fantasy books by George R.R. Martin.  He understands how to create a fantasy world based on fact.  The characters, cultures, and situations are infused by events, locations, and people who were often very real and made their mark felt by us today. Look up the Lancasters, Hadrian's wall, the War of the Roses, the Mongols, and the Colossus of Rhodes for a start!The right actors were found to play very complex characters.  You may find that you have favorites.  Don't get too attached to any of them, though!HBO has put the necessary money into bringing the books to life with top-notch production values.  Every episode is better than most movies released today. George R.R. Martin brought his vision to the right place. David Benioff and D.B. Weiss show tremendous respect for the books and even bring dialogue directly into the scripts.  The show is fast-paced, intelligent, and has made all the other TV shows that I used to like - boring.  My only request would be to tone down on the nude scenes that might interfere with character development!As for the controversy about George Bush's head on a pike next to the Starks - they are the side that represents family values! His head is up there with Lord Eddard Stark, who died for loyalty and honor.  He is in very good company...
Title: N/A

reviewText: Having seen every episode except the finale, I feel that it's time for me to write this review. After watching the first episode I was hooked and I decided to buy the first four novels together in paperback soon after (for less than $20!). I have been keeping pace with each episode and I'm surprised how much they have translated from book to screen. At the rate I'm going I'll be finished with the first book a couple of days after the final episode ends this Sunday (800 plus pages in a month is fast for me). Having seen the show first actually helped me visualize the book and the huge number of characters within it.The enormous cast is excellent in every role. I can't picture anyone other than Sean Bean as Ned Stark and Peter Dinklage steals every scene, much as his character does in the book, as Tyrion Lannister. The visuals are big budget movie calibur and the writing, thanks to the outstanding source material, is better than anything I've seen on TV or at the movies in a long time. The Lord of the Rings trilogy are really good fantasy movies of course, but the lack of eye rolling dialogue found in Game of Thrones really puts it a notch above. Plus you get the added gore and sex that just adds to the realism.HBO is back on the map with high quality shows like this and Boardwalk Empire. Here is to hoping the show last the 7 seasons (one for each book) it needs to tell the complete story.Edit 6/24/2011: I saw the finale and loved every minute. Bring on Spring 2012!

reviewText: What follows is a review of the Game of Thrones: Season One Blu ray set ... not a review of the show itself, of the series, of fantasy as a genre, or anything else.  This is a review to let you know what you're getting when you open the box and put the discs in your blu ray player.What you get:Game of Thrones comes packaged in an attractive fold-out cardboard case with a decorative slipcover.  The box art contains images of various characters in the series: a Stark, some Lannisters, a few Baratheons, and even a Snow just for good measure.  There are five discs in this set, each one emblazoned with the sigil of one of the powerful noble houses inhabiting the world of Westeros.  A handy insert is included, along with some advertisements for other GoT merchandise, providing a brief synopsis of each episode as well as its writing credits.  The insert also contains genealogies of the four main families featured in season one, as well as the members of their housholds, the royal court, and some allies.  Open up this insert, opposite all of the information previously listed, is a full map of Westeros.The Discs:The episodes are spread across all five discs which is convenient enough, but I would have preferred a separate "bonus" disc.  The special features are listed in the description, but the short version goes like this; there are commentaries on selected episodes and a handful of bonus features on each disc giving you information about houses, characters, history, locations, some making of featurettes and interviews etc.  It's all interesting stuff but nothing wildly unexpected.The interface itself on these discs isn't all that great, although it does look nice enough.  There is no scene selection menu which seems like a glaring omission, and the on-screen bonus features that play while you're watching an episode actually seem pretty distracting.  Sadly a lot of the "bonus" information is presented entirely as text, which is pretty crummy considering these are blu rays.  It would've been nice to see HBO shill out the extra cash to have a "Maester" conduct "Lessons" on the various houses, nations, and other powers at play in Westeros.  This feels like a missed opportunity, but I'm really picking nits.Load times ... oh man load times.  It takes two minutes to load the disc from selecting play on the blu ray player menu to the start of an actual episode.  This.  Is.  Bonkers.  I'm not sure what's at fault here, but I've tried this set on three different blu ray players (Sony BDP S380, Samsung BD-D6700, and an original Sony PS3 Fat/the one that's backwards compatible) and in each case the discs take about two minutes to load.  I've tried disabling BD live, but all that seems to do is make the loading icon (a moving image of a weirwood) disappear ... then again this loading icon only shows up occasionally anyway.  I've encountered reports on a few forums that in some cases people can't get their discs to load at all, fortunately I haven't had that problem and your individual mileage may very - but something is definitely up with these discs.Audio/Video quality:Visually I have no complaints with GoT.  It's honestly one of the most beautiful blu rays I've come across.  There are no artifacts of any sort visible, and black levels and fine detail are revelatory.  Textures pop with insane detail; the hair and pores on an actors face, embroidery on fabric and embossing on leather, wood grain ... it goes on and on.  There's not a single shot that isn't downright beautiful.  Even the darkest night scenes featuring the black brothers, which is essentially black on black, offer no crush or loss of fine detail ... as long as your display is up to the task.  This is one of the best releases on the blu ray format, truly perfect visual representation.As for the sound, uh it's good.  I guess.  I'm not an audiophile, and as such not nearly as concerned with audio fidelity as I am with the visual.  Despite that though the encode on these episodes seems nice enough.  A surround system gives a great sense of presence in all of the environments without ever getting too bass-y or blowing out the high end.  When the Hand has his first council in King's Landing there's a great sense of directionality to the conversation (voices reverberating from walls and columns).  It's one of those small details, but it really sells the experience.  All in all it's good.  And in case anyone is wondering if you're watching these episodes through headphones, a soundbar, or built-in speakers you're not missing out on anything ... I promise!Pros -Game of Thrones: Season One on blu ray is worth the price of admission purely for the quality of the visuals alone.  All of the other stuff is just gravy.  I haven't worked my way through all of the bonus features, but they seem entertaining/educational enough so far.Cons -The biggest one hands down is load time.  I've never come across discs that take two minutes to load up and sadly it's unlikely that anything is going to improve this built-in flaw.  Each blu ray player manufacturer will have to release a firmware update (for specific players in many cases) to address this issue which ... seems unlikely.  If you buy this set and can't stand the load times or can't get your discs to play at all - contact HBO.  Let them know that they're BD java programming sucks.The bonus features could be implemented a little better.  I would've like to have had commentaries on every episode, and I would have preferred a fixed commentator cast as opposed to an ever changing one.  Still what's there in the commentaries is entertaining enough, but the set feels kind of incomplete.  I don't like reading text on my television, not for any decent stretch of time.  HBO should really have taken it upon themselves to film something to show us this information, instead of copy-pasting faq-type material.  A disappointment.Give me scene search ... seriously this has been available on pretty much every title I've encountered since blu ray launched.  This omission is silly.The Verdict:Despite some serious flaws in execution - load times load times - Game of Thrones is a must buy.  If you've read the books, like fantasy or genre fiction, or whatever ... you have to buy this series.  If epic fantasy isn't your cup of tea, well - borrow these from a friend then.  You just might get hooked._________________________Edit:Special FeaturesWell it hasn't taken me long to flip flop on some of my feelings already.  In regard to the special features (histories and lore) I've warmed to the short snippets included in this release.  Selecting one of these special features will play an animated featurette, averaging 2-3 minutes, narrated by a relevant character; for example Viserys narrates the title "Valyria & The Dragons".  These are pretty cool after all, although longer entries and a "play all" feature would definitely be welcome.  I'm still not thrilled with the on-screen experience during playback of an episode, but I can see that it would definitely be useful for a lot of viewers.  So in that regard, it is a plus.
summary: Perfect Presentation - Ample bonus features - Handsome Packaging

reviewText: Season one is an excellent adaptation of "A Game of Thrones," the first novel in George R. R. Martin's bestselling fantasy series "A Song of Ice and Fire."If you haven't read the novel series: don't.  The TV series is understandable without having read the original novels.  A little background information could be helpful for you.  In a fantasy world, about 16 years ago the Seven Kingdoms were ruled by Mad King Aerys of the Targaryen family.  The Baratheon and Stark families (with many allies) overthrew the Targaryens, killing most of them.  Two small children, Viserys and Daenerys (Dany for short) were smuggled out.  When the novel begins, Viserys dreams of returning to the throne, now held by Robert Baratheon.  Robert's second-hand man (the "Hand" of the King) has just died under mysterious circumstances.  Robert heads north to offer the job to Eddard ("Ned") Stark, who rules the northern region of the Seven Kingdoms as a sort of governor.  Further north, the realm is bordered by a giant wall of ice.  Legend has it that monsters live north of the wall, but who believes in monsters?If you have read the series: I think the actors did a very good job in their portrayals.  The creative folks behind the series seem to have gotten the idea into their heads that "there are no bad guys" in the series.  This is not true, but it hasn't hurt the series yet (but Cersei is pushing it.)There's more sex and nudity than there was in the original first novel.  There's this really weird thing going on in this series that people are calling "sexposition:" either before, during, or after sex, some man is explaining to a woman (usually Rose, a prostitute, a character not in the novels who seems to have been invented for just this puropse) vital background data.  It's very difficult to pay attention to what the characters are saying while this is going on.  After the third or fourth time this happens, you're thinking to yourself  "Uh-oh, they're about to have sex.  Let me bring out my notebook, this is bound to be on the final."  There's this one scene in particular where Littlefinger commands two of his employees to play with each other, well, I had to play that scene about 6 or 7 times before I was able to concentrate on what Littlefinger was saying.Regarding the special features of the DVD set:  There's a fold-out map that contains family trees with pictures of the main characters on the reverse side.  If you're new to the series, I advise that you look only at this, and do not look at any of the special features on the discs before watching all 10 episodes, because some of these contain spoilers, particularly on disc 5.  I tried to listen to a couple of the commentaries and got bored 5-10 minutes in.

reviewText: A lovely visual spectacle set in a great fantasy world, sometimes brutal, sometimes sexy, with production values more like large-budget movies than TV.  The BluRays play fine on my Sony BD player (current firmware), with no artifacts or problems.I've been a fan of GRRM (the author of the series, a Song of Fire and Ice) long before the show, making me the "skeptical audience" for an on-screen translation, but his participation in making this series is evident in how closely the shows hew to the original storyline.  The few divergences stand out for their rarity.  It's also evident in how many episodes there are per book-- just enough to convey such a complex story, but far better than the usual condensed Hollywood versions of books.The shows are distinctly more sexy than the books, and a little less violent, but it feels balanced.  And who would object to a little sexiness (particularly if you don't object to the bloodshed!).The shows are also a little less gritty than the books.  People are mostly healthier, life appears less hardscrabble than the accurately pre-industrial depictions in the books.  For example, Tyrion is a reasonably attractive dwarf, rather than an ugly, misshapen dwarf as he is in the books.I won't rehash reviews of the episodes or story-lines, suffice it to say that the plot is complex, the cast large, the story enormous, very compelling, and occasionally shocking.  I say read the books first, but definitely watch it as well!  Highly recommended.
summary: A visual spectacle, great adaption of the book

reviewText: OK, might as well stick in my 2-worth I suppose:The violence, bouncing boobs, sex and incest don't bother me per se; sometimes they're laid on so thick it just makes me laugh.  But past a certain point, they do bore me.  I suppose they're trying to cast their net for the audience as wide as possible.And I, too, am irritated by pointless deviations from the original story — in which Season 2 is indeed much worse than Season 1.These considerations aside, this series has much to recommend it.  For a start, the acting is almost uniformly first rate: if I had to award just one Oscar, it would go to the Casting Director.  A second would go for Special Effects, and a third for title music.This script is crisp and entertaining, too, and — a definite benefit over reading the books — you don't have to put up with the author's appalling grammar.No, it's not perfect, but my wife and I both look forward to it very much — and she HATES fantasy, I had to twist her arm into even giving it a chance.So 5 stars from me.
summary: Winter — not to mention dismemberments, orgies, incest, decapitations and disembowelments — is coming

reviewText: So there they are, trudging across the tundra, the cold wind blowing hard. The men are all bundled up in thick animal furs. The women are all half naked. Hmmm...But it gets better. Up on "the wall", where it's really cold and the ice is everywhere, nobody wears a hat. Multiple layers of fur coats and no hats? Really? And one wonders if the makers of this program have ever seen real snow? They certainly do a horrible job of simulating it.Ah, but here's the best part. Every episode has a few sex scenes, usually rather energetically portrayed. In one scene a young stud is slamming a sweet young thing from behind, his sweaty thighs making a loud smacking sound against her sweaty buttocks with every brutal thrust. He achieves what might seem to be a very satisfying climax, and no more than 4 to 5 seconds later he has withdrawn and we see him in full frontal nudity, his totally flaccid 10" long member hanging straight down between his legs like badly overcooked linguini. Now, as a fully paid-up, card carrying member of the male gender, I can attest to the fact that it takes a bit longer in the real world for a penis to go flaccid. Perhaps HBO has some policy against the display of an erect human penis? I don't know if they do or not. But to go to all of the trouble to show something that is physiologically impossible just seems a bit silly.Otherwise, it's a pretty good show.

reviewText: Production values are unequaled. I'll bet the author had the end of the War of the Roses in mind when he put this together. A veryhairy period, e.g. wars, pestilences, foreign invasions, famines, Large weather changes all accompanied by social upheavals.All this leads to a period which it is easier to observe from the outside than as an observer on-the-spot - if you like the good life (orany kind of life).It is hard to imagine this sort of privation until you've seen enough of our current-day pest holes during war, pestilence, famine and open latrines (then throw in an Viking invasion).
summary: Tudors - end of the War of the Roses. Absolutely FIRST RATE!!!!!!

reviewText: I love the series, the Blu-Ray has awesome image and audio quality, and great on-screen extras. But there is a known issue with this set of discs on the Sony BDP-S580 player. The discs either take forever to load, or they lock up completely, requiring you to reset the player. I've found that the best solution is to hold the power button down until the player shuts off, then turn it back on. I read on one discussion board that Sony is working on a firmware update, but that could be a while.  Meanwhile, I'm enjoying watching the show, once I get the discs to load.

reviewText: This is one of the best series I've watched in a very long time...  This series has a exhilarating story line, a great cast that you personally connect with, great action scenes that leave you on the edge of your seat...  It's captivating... I can't wait for season two....  I truly hope it's producers and directors do not screw it up by continuing to go out of their way to put sex scenes and nudity in it.... I know...  it's cable network and expected but with this outstanding story and strong characters it's just not needed.. I don't mind a little T&A; but please don't mess up this series by struggling to introduce awkward shock & awe in the form of Adult Content... There's a couple of times early in the series it actually distracted from the storyline...  They got a good thing here...Just can't show to the kids....  I'm looking forward to several more seasons if the writers can last....Great price match offer by Amazon on pre-order...  Amazon is Great!!!  Game Of Thrones Great!!!

reviewText: I love this series.  But then I like Medieval history.  This is 12th and 13th century Europe in a more fantastic planet with a little fantasy thrown in.  We'll see how that develops.  But it's brutal, sexist and violent - what else would you expect from that period of history?  The characters are interesting and compelling - the story is endless - but that's enjoyable too.My one complaint is that George r.r.Martin has this obsession with breaking all the rules of fantasy writing.  Heroes don't win, evil is not vanquished, good is not rewarded and worst of all, the people you grow to care about are killed off.  Enough is enough.

reviewText: Having never read any of the "Song of Ice and Fire" series of fantasy epic books by George R . R. Martin's (with the fifth about to be released) has not proven a significant problem in following HBOs epic serialisation. Granted approaching the television series did require some care since the pre fanfare on Sky cast it as sort of "Lord of the Rings Lite" not least with the presence of Sean Bean. Happily this is not the case. For one "Game of thrones" is largely free of huge set piece battles, it also requires real patience since it is a series that slowly unfurls it glories through multiple plots and all kinds of political skullduggery. This is high fantasy for Machiavelli fans since "Game of thrones" has a "Il Principe" quality to it as rulers struggle to maintain or gain power through a mixture of the methodical exercise of brute force, deceit and downright treachery. Indeed some have suggested that it not so much Gandalf the Grey as James J. Gandolfini from the Sopranos.It is in addition it is beautifully filmed, has incredible sets and you almost shiver with the chill of Winterfell and the ancient Ice Wall. But at the heart of this series is tremendous characterization and intriguing plots which gradually weave together to great effect. And as with most HBO series this is a very liberal sprinkling of sex and violence, thus if you don't like this sort of thing please don't buy it.No review could do justice to all the characters so lets pick out a few. Bean is of course very solid as Ned Stark and so to is Michelle Fairley as his wife Catelyn. The emerging star of the Stark family however is the wonderful young actress Maisie Williams as their daughter Ayra who somehow dominates the screen everytime she comes on and grows in importance as the plot line evolves. Their primary enemies are the Lannisters who are a mixed bunch. For the life of me every time Jaime Lannister (Nikolaj Coster Waldau) enters the series I can help but think of "Lieutenant Templeton "Face" Peck" (Dirk Benedict) from the A Team! That said this family contains the two real stars of the series the beautifully twisted and power hungry English actress Lena Headey as Cersei Lannister and the utterly sublime Peter Dinklage as Tyrion Lannister who brings new meaning to the term "poison dwarf". Cersai is the archetypical power behind the throne, cruel and bent of gaining power. She is beautiful but twisted and not in the least anxious about incestuous relationships , murder and deceit if they will seal power. Baddies always have the best lines and a classic is her lecture to Starks daughter which is a lovely piece of sarcastic realpolitik. As she questions "Do you have any notion what happens when a city is sacked, Sansa? No, you wouldn't, would you? All you know of life you learned from singers, and there is such a dearth of good sacking songs." As for Dinklage his part of Tyrion the dwarf is an acting masterclass. He plays the part of this "half man" as a lecturous, whoring, rude, cunning and often hilarious character with such aplomb that he steals every scene and you feel almost guilty for liking him quite so much. His scenes at the prison at Eyrie or with the Mountain Clans of the Vale are some of the best as his survival instinct kicks in and he outmanoeuvres his capturers. Fantastic stuff and other honourable mentions should go Jason Momoa as Khal Drogo the powerful and violent horse lord and his surprisingly resilient wife Daenerys Targaryen played by the lovely Emilla Clarke."Game of thrones" is made up of a predominantly British and Irish cast who demonstrate that our two little islands have talent to spare. It is series which more than lives up to advanced billing and HBO will thankfully be filming a second outing shortly particularly as the ominous threat of "winter coming" and all sorts of viciousness from the other side of the Ice Wall looms large. All in all it's a great series and should secure a prime position on the shelf near the Wire, the West Wing, the Sopranos and your other big box sets. Recommended without hesitation or deviation.
summary: Game of Thrones - "The Soprano's in Middle Earth".
