reviewText: I'm a big fan of the books; well the first 3 anyway. You know what I mean if you have read all of them. I didn't see the 1st season when it was on HBO originally, but they started re-airing the 1st season in January  to get ready for the 2nd season. I almost pre-ordered the 1st season on Blu-Ray, but I decided to wait and watch it on HBO. Boy am I glad I did. Now I know a lot of people really like this HBO series. I got through the first 4 or 5 episodes of the 1st season; not loving it, but just watching because I enjoyed the book so much. Right off the bat didn't like how they depicted the whites in the opening scene. They are slow and sluggish in the book; strike 1. Several characters are presented well; Robb Stark, Jon Snow, Arya Stark, Littlefinger, to name just a few. But Tyrion Lannister is probably the most interesting characters in the books and Peter Dinklage does a good job, but he is too good looking and isn't shown enough. Sean Bean as Ned Stark is too brutish. It was really hard to get past Catelyn Stark looking like such an old hag; strike 2. The final straw was their depiction of Loras Tyrell and Renly Baratheon; couldn't believe it. Don't know where they came up with that. I asked a friend of mine who turned me on to the books; he hasn't seen the entire 1st season either. I explained how they depicted sir Loras and Renly and he never suspected how they portrayed them in the HBO series. I won't drop any spoilers, but after that I didn't have any desire to watch the series; strike 3. I've turned it on the 2nd season a couple times since then, but always turn it off. If you have read the books don't waste your money buying this. Also, I don't even recommend wasting your time renting and watching it.
summary: I Wouldn't Waste Your Time or The Money...

reviewText: I will not comment on the series itself, since so many others have except to say- 1)  my wife and I loved it and and we are NOT fantasy fans at all; 2) the filming and especially the casting is terrific; 3)  Fascinating story in the mode of the British "War of the Roses" (which is perfect for my British wife).I wanted to say a few words about the Blu-ray extras.  There are many and they are incredibly extensive.  I still haven't watched/read them all-  easily 5 hours of extras, and maybe closer to 10 (I haven't tracked it.)First of all, short interview clips with all the stars helps newcomers/reminders of the characters. Second, extensive video clips with actor voiceovers tell the huge backstory/history of much of the places and the houses/families.  Again, this really helps fill in the information.  Also, there is a during the episode ability, while watching,. to get info and highlights on characters/places within that episode.  And, of course, many commentary tracks on most individual episodes, and documentaries on various aspects of the production.Look,l this is a VERY complicated story and back-story, and these extras really help fill that in.  All are very well done.All in all- a terrific package, the best I have seen for any series.
summary: Numerous and excellent extras add much to this terrific series

reviewText: HBO has done it again. After viewing Band of Brothers and The Pacifc (which I enjoyed less), I was hopeing this would live up to all the hype it was getting but I was unsure as while I had been told a good amount of the plot, I was unsure about how it could interest me. Once the first episode was over I knew that question mark was no longer an issue. The structure of the show, although slightly confusing at first, proved to be quite ingenious, giving multiple story arcs and all kinds of different themes.The leader of a family, trying to make sense of important royalty being killed, one families plot to overthrow the monarchy, one man's quest to seek revenge towards the land that exiled him, a woman's journey towards respect of her new culture, one young man trying to find his place being viewed as an outcast, views about religion, trust, power and much more. This show is loaded with awesomeness.Like with Lost, the new Battlestar Galactica series and Heroes, the shows contunity is very detailed and if you miss one episode you will be lost. The characters although it will be hard to recall names, all provide very interesting stories, although some stories/characters are ment to be hated. Yet part of the show is to show human nature and very different personalities interacting with each other. I honestly cannot think of anything to complain except it is hard to remember names, thankfully faces are not.If you haven't picked this up or viewed, make sure you do.

For a straight TV show its great, as an alternative to the book series I would have to say stick with the books.

reviewText: I usually don't review an item before the product is released, but there has been so much discussion about this series, I figured I'd try to approach it a bit differently.  I expect the blu ray discs will be fine, but if they aren't, I will update this review.The first thing I noticed is that the casting was just about perfect.  The actors were all well chosen for their roles.  No Hollywood cuties here.  To their's and the directors' credit, there was no "over-acting".  Everyone stayed true to character.  Some characters gave you an instant impression of where they were on the spectrum of good and bad, while others had a bit more subtle...just as they were in the book.  The sets were superb as were the locations.  Each region had its own feel and nothing was laid on too heavily.  You got the feeling you were looking at a "real" place.To be fair, the series doesn't cover everything in the book.  If it did, it would have to have 50 episodes, rather than 10.  But it does keep the storyline intact and understandable.  Besides, we don't absolutely need to know all the things they wore and ate, or just how frequently they had sex.  Yes, there is sex in the series.  I didn't feel it was gratuitous.  some of it was absolutely necessary for the plot and the rest gave an insight into the mores and habits of the different peoples.  Were there differences between the book and series?  There were a few, but when they occurred, it was to make the series more understandable without some of the details contained in the book.There are two questions I'll try to address.  If you haven't read the book, will you enjoy the series? Yes, if you lake a well told story that is fantasy, but not the kinds that kids like.  Will you like the book if you see the series first?  Absolutely.  If you like stories where everyone lives happily ever after and the good guys always win, this isn't for you.  But if you like a well told, well acted story with plenty of twists and turns to keep you coming back for more, this is it!
summary: A fantasy world like no other (no spoilers)

reviewText: There's no need to rehash the plot of GRR Martin's fabulous "A Song of Ice and Fire" series; everyone remotely interested in this extraordinary piece of fantasy/adventure is familiar with its medieval story-line.Things I liked in this HBO series...1.) it's not often a movie-series turns out to be the perfect visual compliment to what many consider to be the gold standard for epic fantasy writing...but this does. It captures the atmosphere, the subtle edginess, those brutal, unexpected moments; it really does grasp the mood and essence of the book.2.) in addition to presenting a riveting tale, the production gives us acting that brings the books' characters to life in realistic settings.3.) a computer enhanced animated map is shown as a short cut scene at the start of each episode. Giving those of us familiar with the books a brief refresher and those new to the series a sense of the geography, direction and distances.4.) a pulsating, musical score to start each episode that perfectly fits the heraldic spirit of this story.Conclusion:HBO has done a wonderful job making this first book (Game of Thrones), into a first rate TV series. 5 Stars.Ray Nicholson
summary: A brilliant transition from book to TV series

reviewText: I liked it very much.  Enough to immediately order the 2nd season.  It has what is so sadly lacking in most of the drivel that comes out of Hollywood these days.  A real story line.  Charactors that are more than one dimensional (at least some of them).  Complex subplots.  And, just like in the real world, the good guys don't always win.  In hours of programming, I never had a moment of boredom.  In addition, the acting & direction are excellent, the sets, costuming, supurb.  If the option existed, I'd give it 4 1/2 stars.  There was nothing about it I didn't like.  The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars, is that whatever that magic something is that elevates a film to instant classical greatness wasn't quite there.  That said, I would recommend the series highly to anyone who enjoys costume drama.  They won't be disappointed.

reviewText: So much has been said in praise of this superb adaptation, there's not much to add.Seven noble families fight for control of the mythical land of Westeros in HBO's medieval fantasy adapted from George R. R. Martin's best-selling series A Song of Ice and Fire for HBO by David Benioff and D. B. Weiss.  Lena Headey, Jack Gleeson, Peter Dinklage and Sean Bean star along with new faces, all of whom wonderfully inhabit the warring clans - kings and queens, knights and renegades, liars and noblemen - in the two mighty families who vie for power in the Seven Kingdoms of Westeros where summers span decades and winters can last a lifetime.The seductive ten episodes that cover the first book in the on-going series, which is still being written, is a visually rich, sweeping epic and arguably the best thing on TV right now.  If this is new to you, prepare to be hooked and engaged as betrayal, lust, intrigue and supernatural forces shake the four corners of the Kingdoms in a bloody battle for the Iron Throne, the outcome of which has unforeseen and far-reaching consequences.  The cliff-hanging ending will prime you for Season Two.

reviewText: The series is phenomenal (and true to the book, as others have noted).  Rivals Peter Jackson's Lord of the Rings, it's that good.  Don't doubt it.  There are plenty of other rave reviews to convince you on here.The real reason for me to write this review is for the sake of those with a blu ray player that has trouble with the apparently overly complex menu system.  A lot of folks are having trouble even getting the discs to load, especially on the later discs.  It is not confined to any one brand machine, though some do better than others, and it seems inconsistent at that (you're not guaranteed to have trouble with these discs).It appears the workaround is to load up disc 1 and then choose the episode you want from there; it asks for the appropriate disc and you eject disc 1 and insert the one you really wanted to watch.  It's a bit of a pain, but it seems to work, and it beats the heck out of waiting on and on, staring at a black screen wondering if the disc you want will load up on the first, third, or fourth try or at all.  Actually takes far less time, even after waiting through the HBO ads I can't seem to skip at the start of disc 1.That stated, I still give this set a 5-star review, because even with this annoying flaw, it's still that good.  And beautiful on blu.  Do not hesitate to purchase this set--the extra features on the blu ray set are just as well done.  Rarely do the extras turn out to be so integral to an experience, and rarely do they meet, let alone exceed, your expectations.Can't say enough good things about this set; just use the menu from disc 1 to load all other episodes on the rest of the set, and you're all good.  (Actually, once you have a disc running, you can choose any other episode on that disc from that disc's menu without going back to disc 1; it's getting the darn things to load up initially that is the issue.)I hope this helps anyone who has been frustrated or was wary because of hearing the discs were buggy or something.
summary: Use Disc 1 Menu to Select Episodes

reviewText: I read the 1st book years before and I bought the first season on DVD but for some reason never watched it – I think I was afraid to. But having watched the first, I had to keep going, damn sleep, and made a two-night marathon of the entire 1st season. It left me breathless and in awe. Because there were years between the reading and the watching, I’m not sure I can safely say – I don’t remember it being that gory and bloody and having that many sex scenes. But yikes! Definitely not for the faint of heart. Is some of it gratuitious? Yes. But still, the story and the characters are so magnificent, and the show so faithful to them, that nothing is ever lost. The casting was sheer genius. Peter Dinklage as Tyrion is a marvel to watch. The only disappointment I had really was the lack of battle scenes.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The kingdom of Robert Baratheon is in peril. Whitewalkers to the North of the Wall are massing, much to the oblivion of everybody in the South. The exiled daughter of the mad king is gathering an army of barbarians while cradling three dragon eggs, ready to take back the kingdom. And a family is broken up by the actions of a drunken king and an evil knight called the Kingslayer.I can't summarise the whole series here, it's too complex and why would I want to ruin it for someone coming to it new? I did read the books years ago though. 2000 I read "Game of Thrones" and "Clash of Kings" and utterly loved the story. I can say that a lot of what I saw in these 10 episodes had a lot of what went on in "Game of Thrones" and several casting choices were perfection itself. I'm thinking particularly of the Lannisters who all look exactly as I imagined, especially the best character in the entire series Tyrion - Peter Dinklage deserves an Emmy for his work here.I didn't think of Sean Bean as the likely star of the show or of the best person to play Ned Stark but he does well here. Nor did I think all of the cast would speak with haughty English accents or variants of the Yorkshire brogue, but it's better than having them speaking with American accents.To those who haven't read the books and are coming to this cold - it is a bit slow. It wasn't until the later episodes that I really felt the series took off. This is mostly because of the death of an important character which changes the situations for everyone involved and the story really starts to come together. It's with the conflicts of the various characters, Daenerys plotting her return, the Starks and the Lannisters gearing up for a fight, and the supernatural menace to the North, that the books really took off and where this series ends, so a viewer could be forgiven for thinking not enough happens. I think Season 2 will be outstanding as the action will be unrelenting and a host of fascinating situations reveal themselves. Season 1 felt like the setup where you meet the characters, understand the world, and then got a taste of what was coming.Not that it wasn't done well. Every episode features beautiful scenery, costumes, and sets. "The Eyrie" was particularly breathtaking, especially with the cell Tyrion is imprisoned in. All of the actors do a fine job and the writing was very loyal to the books. I think a lot of the magic and a lot of the fighting present in the later books will make this series even more popular but meanwhile this series did a fine job of prepping the audience for what this story is all about - good vs evil on an epic scale.It's absolutely fantastic to see fine literature translating into fine television. I cannot wait for Season 2 to explode when "Game of Thrones" returns next spring. Definitely a must watch for fans of great television.

reviewText: I have been a fan of George R.R. Martin for several years now, and I think it would be accurate to label me a Martin "Fan Boy."  I have readA Game of Thrones: A Song of Ice and Fire: Book Onefour times, been active on message boards, followed his blog for years and practically pulled my hair out in frustration at reading countless posts about the New York Jets andWild Cards Iwhile waiting anxiously forA Dance with Dragons: A Song of Ice and Fire: Book Fiveto finally be released. At the news that HBO had picked up the rights to Thrones to adapt to a series, I couldn't have been more excited.  A 13 episode series, from a company like HBO, was fantastic news.  While you might presume that authors like Martin would love fans like me, we are a double edged (Dothrakian) sword.  Although we will eagerly consume everything Martin's world creates, that adoration also comes with an overwhelming amount of scrutiny, which authors and production companies can almost find it impossible to live up to (e.g, Tom Bombadil and the Scouring of the Shire fromLord of the Rings, The: The Fellowship of the Ring - Extended Edition). I followed the development of this series with other fans from the initial announcement until the final trailer.  Even though I saw those same type of demands and expectations from fans, I can say that HBO produced not only the closest adaptation of a book I have seen, but even managed to surpass Martin's original story in some aspects.Told over the course of ten one-hour episodes, HBO's Game of Thrones might seem at first glance to simply be a high fantasy adventure story, but it can more aptly be described as a political drama.  Taking place in an alternate medieval world, the series focuses more on the characters and their interactions with each other than on the adventure aspect.  Character development, and Martin's refusal to write a conventional story, ensure that the viewer is always kept on the edge of their seat. I remember finishing one of the first chapters of the book and sitting up in my bed in shock, thinking about what had just happened and trying to figure out how Martin could have done that.  I have no doubt that viewers of the first episode will feel the same way.  The acting, especially performances by Sean Bean (as Ned Stark) and Peter Dinklage (as Tyrion Lannister) is superb.  Production value on the show is nothing less than amazing and it looks more like a feature film than a cable series (especially the opening sequence).If I had to name any criticisms of the show, all I could say is that some of the acting, particularly Emilia Clarke (Daenerys) and Michelle Fairley (Catelyn Stark), was a little stiff.  I know Martin includes a lot of sex in his books, but it seemed like some of the scenes were designed a little more toward shock value.  Tyrion was not nearly ugly enough  (if at all).  I know that sounds like a nitpick, but I think it's important to his character to mirror the misshapen appearance in the books, to draw more attention to his wits.  And lastly, it can be very difficult for a new viewer to keep track of all the characters and families without a cheat sheet. Even after reading all of the books I still had to look some people up.The first season of Game of Thrones is amazing writing combined with above-average acting and amazing production design and direction. Not only is it everything fans could hope for in a series, but it helps to bring Martin's work to a new audience, who might be turned off at the idea of reading a long and complicated fantasy series. Producers David Benioff and D.B. Weiss have done an excellent job of faithfully transitioning Martin's work to the small screen while keeping fans happy and introducing millions of new fans to the Seven Kingdoms.
summary: With their adaptation of 'Game of Thrones,' HBO deserves to sit atop the iron throne

reviewText: Game of Thrones is acceptable entertainment, but below the usual HBO standard.  It will never be confused with the excellent Lord of the Rings movies, for example.  My biggest complaint is that the pacing of the show is so slow.  Coupled with rather wooden acting by most of the cast, it can be very annoying.  If only the other actors had fed off the enthusiasm and energy that the dwarf noble  put into his performance!  I like Sean Bean, but he plays his role like Liam Neeson on downers.  The characters seem better suited to a Dickens novel than a fantasy series in my opinion--very extreme characterizations.  The productio9n values are excellent and add to the viewing experience.  If you watch this series with reasonable expectations, you will be entertained.  I had much higher hopes for it, though.

reviewText: I was extremely excited to get my hands on the set. The show itself is amazing and really well done. The story is engaging full of plots of betrayal and intrigue, and the show is masterfully crafted. Each episode felt like a movie. From the scenery to the outfits every detail was well thought out and planned and it really pays off. When each episode ended I couldn't wait to start the next one and was hooked from the first minute.This boxed set was very well done. The disks are stored in a typical printed card board sleeve and housed inside a box. It felt very sturdy and I have no doubts will last a long time. The detailing on the other box was exceptionally well done. I was very impressed by the quality of this set and have no doubts I'll be picking up any future boxed sets from newer seasons. My only complaint is the lack of DvDs/digital copies that newer revisions have.
summary: A wonderful show and a masterfully made boxed set

reviewText: I really didn't want to like this show. I resisted watching it for a couple years. (Season 3 ended before I started season 1)I even gave up after 1 episode because the pilot episode had too much rape and child killing in it for my usual liking. (I tend to enjoy as little of those things as is humanly possible...call me old fashioned)But then everyone, and I mean EVERYONE started talking about the dang show telling me how I HAD to give it another try because I was judging the first episode too harshly.So I did. I gave it another try. I restarted with the pilot and still didn't like it. But I was fair and promised the 900 people who demanded I watch it to give it a 5 episode run before quitting. By the end of episode 2 I was hooked. I haven't been able to stop. I've been binge watching it for a week now trying to get through it so I can listen to what everyone around me is saying about it. (As of now I am only half way through the series so I have to ignore everyone talking about season 3)So damn you, Game of Thrones! I really didn't want to watch you! But you beat me. I can't stop now. I'm hooked. I will soon be joining the masses of people who are desperate for season 4 to start.A couple notes to some specific categories of reviewers for this show...To the people who are upset over the use of foul language on the show...What the actual eff is wrong with you? It's a show that features more bloodshed every hour than you could see in an all day film festival of Braveheart, Rambo, and Dead Alive. That's okay, but a little off color language is totally beyond your standards? Seriously?To the people who say the show is too violent...What, exactly, were you expecting in the show about a medieval war with dragons? Fluffy rainbows and unicorns?To the people who say the show is sexist and demeaning to women...You might now have noticed this blatantly obvious theme, but all the sexist characters are the bad guys. ALL OF THEM. All of the good guys are respective towards the women in the show. That seems like a condemnation of sexism to me, but what do I know...I won't even mention how many women in this show are strong in both character and morals. That Lady Stark being a bad ass to protect her family or Kahleesi fighting off death and destruction at every turn to keep her people safe really shows how weak women are, right?To the people who say the show is too misogynistic....Really? Misogyny in medieval times? How dare the writers depict such lies....To the people who say this show is badly acted and poorly filmed...I didn't know blind people watched much television. So I learned something today. Thank you for making me aware of this.
summary: I didn't want to love this show, but it sucked me in

reviewText: After seeing the previews for Game of Thrones on HBO in the weeks leading up to the premier episode on 4/17/2011, I said to myself, "Here we go again with another Ken Follett-esquePillars of the Earthkinda show." Game of Thrones looked like your typical Medieval times storyline full of knights in shining armor, sword fights, debauchery and that kind of stuff. I was disinterested...until a few days before the premier I happened to catch a making-of Game of Thrones production. So I set my DVR.Game of Thrones is right up my alley. Indeed it has the sword fights and debauchery that I mentioned a second ago, but I was under the impression that this was to be a depiction of some real world that existed a long long time ago. No...not at all the case. In the opening moments of the show we are introduced to a place that clearly has some "Otherly" world creatures in it. So after a little checking I see that the story is based on the fantasy book series by George R. R. Martin called A Song of Ice and Fire. The book series is highly rated here at Amazon with over 1000 reviews for the first installment called...you guessed it...Game of Thrones.The show is excellent. The HBO crew has created magic with Game of Thrones. It's a fantastic drama aimed towards an adult audience. It's must see TV for fans of the fantasy genre.

reviewText: At least non-relevant to those who have read the novels.  The basic problem is that the novels were so incredibly detailed, that making a TV series out of them doesn't add anything to the story.  In fact, when they make changes in the story or characters, it takes away from the story.  Now, for those who have not read the books, it is probably a good watch, although some mis-perceptions of events may occur compared to the reality.What may have made more sense, and maybe 20 years down the road, the series will be re-made again, would be to either completely stick to the books (they do say that the future of TV and movies made using books as sources will be to stick as close to the source material as possible), or perhaps they should have down a few movies, or the best idea - to set some movies or a series set entirely dealing with the events at and beyond the Wall.  After all, this is where the most interesting cinematography occurs anyhow.While there have been some changes in characters, for the most part the actors are well-acted and  interesting, in particular (don`t mind my spelling): Eddard, Jon Snow (looks like Deidrich Bader), The Old Bear Mormont, King Baratheon, Ser Jorah, Arya, Sansa, Jamie, The Hound, Shagga.  Of course the key to good directing is to choose actors who fit the roles, not to change the roles to fit the actors.Khal Drogo is unfortunately a complete non-character as portrayed.  Theon will probably turn out well with his actor.That being said, they did make some changes from the books that were really not necessary (and therefore kinda of makes you wonder why they made them), for instance:- Catylyn Stark (and her sister Lysa Aryn) are way, way too old.- Cersei is supposed to be a great beauty, but they choose a very plain actress to play her.- the Dothraki are supposed to be Mongols.- Robert never baited the Lannisters (not counting Cersei).- Ser Loras was supposed to be someone that folks looked up to, instead they've turned him into a prancing fool- Robert never intended to join the joust, it was the melee.- for important reasons, they needed to make it very clear that Jamie was a great swordsman, but it is rarely shown or referenced- the Others would never cut off someone's head or dis-assemble them, cos' then they wouldn't come back very well as wights.- the books never specifically portrayed Ser Loras and Renly as homosexuals.  That is to say, they may have been and they may have not been, but there was no evidence either way.  Certainly, there were some insults thrown around from others characters, but then again accusing your enemies of homosexuality has been the insult of choice since the first battles at the dawn of time all the way up to the present war against Iraq.- Jamie would never stab someone in the eye, Jamie was the best swordsman in the land and certainly doesn't need tricks to beat some hack household guard..- Littlefinger was never a hands-on brothel manager, it was just a file in his business portfolio.- Catylyn's "investigation" of Bran's accident was a bit ridiculous.- the sky cells should be far narrower, there is supposed to be a constant fear of falling out when sleeping (not rolling 20 ft to get to the edge).- the Lannisters are supposed to have blond hair, not dirty brown.- Joffrey & Gendry should have long hair (and actually Joffrey is supposed to have long, curly hair), although long curly hair would have been difficult to pull off on TV to be honest.- Winterfell seems way too big and built up.- Robert and Gendry should have jet black hair (a key plot point).- Gendry seems too old.-  Lysa is supposed to be fat.-  Sam Tarly is not fat enough.- the king should be a lot taller (after all he was supposed to be one of the strongest warriors in the land), ever hear of `lifts`, boots, trick photography?, sheesh.- Cersei's emotion about a black-haired baby didn't to seem to make any sense considering the circumstances (I really think that would confuse viewers).-  too much of a difference in height / age between Arya and Sansa.-  Arya would never have made that bow shot.- Jon should be at the king's feast.Renly is supposed to be very charismatic and can gather many to his banners, yet the character on the tv series has no charisma at all- the older Night's Watch man was the one who survived, not the younger one.- i could be wrong, but i seem to recall that Lord Walder could not walk.- Rickon is too old.- and obviously the Moon Door is not in the floor, it is on a wall standing vertical (and face it, do you really think anyone is stupid to build an entire stone throne room over an empty space?)- I have also just heard that Season Two starts with a horrific event that did not happen in the books.None of these issue are major issues by themselves, but a lot of mistakes tend to add up, especially since they could have been corrected.And of course, as with most HBO shows, there is a certain amount of low-level prostitution (ie: a lot of the actresses will paid to take their clothes off and appear in sexual scenes).  There are additionally regular characters that are actually playing prostitutes or courtesans as well.  Hey, I am definitely not complaining about nudity, although HBO does come off as exploitative sometimes.The best part I think in the first season was the Wall, a very interesting placeThe overall impression that I received, was that I've already read the books, watching the 1st season really didn't add to the Games of Thrones experience, so I don't feel any particular desire to watch the second season.  That being said, for folks who haven't read the books, go for the 2nd season, I'm sure it's a lot better than Xena the Warrior princess (although one of those does show up later for that matter in the series).
summary: Decently made, but at the same time completely non-relevant

reviewText: I wasn't too sure about this when it started. I was unfamiliar with the books, and the show really looked like a bit of a low-rent Lord of the Rings for television. When I watched the first episode, I was mesmerized by the production values but utterly bewildered by the huge ammount of characters and back story. I wasn't sure I would continue watching.That would've been a mistake. I watched the pilot twice more before the next episode, soaking in every detail. I wikipedia'd the first chapters of the book and the character pages. I was into it. This show is an all out roller coaster. The characters are uniformly fantastic, the production exquisite, the writing and directing all beyond what you see in most theatrical films. The plot takes astonishing twists and turns, entirely unpredictable.It's great. Amazing. If you get this set, it will be impossible to space out the episodes. You would end up watching them all as one giant 10-hour movie.And in that regard it would be the best movie in many years

reviewText: I was excited about this series, but after watching it; it seems much more like a period or Medieval soap opera.  There's a lot of geopolitical posturing and who's sleeping with who, but no magic, unique creatures or fantastic elements that make well, fantasy.  In fact, I've read in many reviews that magical or fantasy elements don't even really come into play until the beginning of Season 3.  I'm also concerned, as I've been told to NOT get attached to any character, as no one is safe good characters are regularly and sometimes, arbitrarily killed off.  To get through any epic, I need someone I can invest emotionally in to go the distance.  Can you imagine Lord of the Rings, if you had taken the journey with Frodo over three years and three 3-hour films only to have him killed by an orc at the 11th hour and Sauron reign supreme?  I'd feel manipulated and cheated.  It's not that I need a happy ending to everything.  That's different.  I just need some sort of pay off and it seems like Game of Thrones doesn't offer that or classic fantasy.
summary: More Like Period Soap Opera than Fantasy

reviewText: I can't add much to what others have said about Game of Thrones - Season One, it's a very good portrayal of Martin's complex novel.  It helps to have read the book, but the series stands on it's own for the most part, so it's recommended whether or not you've read the novel.I figured I'd watch the series on my 720P plasma in the family room (no surround sound), so I ordered the DVD version and not the Blu-Ray.  Since the wife didn't care for it, I ended up watching most of it in the basement in my somewhat small home theater room.I have a good surround sound setup that cost close to $3K (not bragging, a lot of real HT enthusiasts think this is entry level), a Panasonic Blu-Ray player and a 56 inch 1080P Samsung DLP TV, one of the later models that I set up according to guidelines of one of the top video gurus.  The DLP TV is pretty tough on regular DVDs with average transfers, there's often a grainy quality visible that goes beyond film grain.  I can say that Game of Thrones is probably the best DVD I've viewed on the TV.  The picture is very smooth and sharp (many DVDs have either one or the other), colors look realistic, and blacks are really black. The audio is great also, speech is clear, and when things bang and crash, you really hear it.  So, if you don't have the latest and greatest 1080P or Blu-Ray setup and are thinking of getting the DVD version, don't worry, you're still getting a top notch product.I can't think of much more to say.  The series itself is outstanding, and HBO has taken care of the technical details on the DVD.  Highly recommended!!
summary: Good series and equally good audio and video quality on the DVD  version

reviewText: I watched the first 3 episodes of season 1, looking forward to finding a new, quality series to become engrossed in.  I loved Lord of the Rings as well as other good fantasy and science fiction.  I just could find nothing about this series worth watching.  It's a bunch of dysfunctional royal families, with stereotypical overbearing kings, conniving queens and evil princes, vying for power and willing to do anything to get it.  I see no love, no compassion, no spirituality whatsoever; darkness after darkness upon darkness is just plain boring and unimaginative.  I also found the sexuality to be totally and completely presented from an adolescent male's perspective; again, boring and unimaginative (not to mention demeaning and objectifying toward women).

I haven't read the book.

reviewText: Jane Espenson seems like a very likeable person from her interviews, but I am very unhappy with what she did to Buffy, Galactica, Torchwood, and now Game of Thrones.  Her Thrones episode was great where she parroted the book and weak where she impiously "improved" upon George RR Martin's work (hubris much?), in particular by misunderstanding and shaving off the subtle moral nuance of the Viserys Targaryen story, watering it down from truly wonderful into something merely fun to watch.In GRRM's book: Khal Drogo intends to give Viserys his army, but Viserys is too arrogant to be patient, so he dies through intemperance a la Hamlet.  Subtle.In Espenson's TV script: Viserys is led to believe that Khal Drogo will *never* give him his army, so he has little to lose in a desperate gambit.  Blunt.I seldom notice who wrote a TV show unless it's very good or very bad, but Espenson's work has jumped out at me. She once won a Hugo award for cowriting an excellent Buffy episode, but since then I've been disappointed in a favorite program several times only to notice her name in the credits.  Google for "Battlestar Galactica" and "worst episodes" and you'll see that Espenson's "The Passage" and "The Plan" are nearly always at the top of the worst episode lists, yet in interviews she often refers to them as "fan favorites."  Hmph.  I wish she would stick to stuff like 'Gilmore Girls,' which I think suits her strengths much better.Almost everything else about this series is flawless.  If the producers read this, this viewer at least would prefer no more Jane Espenson scripts, please.
summary: Please no more Jane Espenson scripts! (spoilers)

reviewerName: The Taminator "There's no going back. You've ...
reviewText: Spoilers to follow.I don't hate this series, but I don't particularly like it, either. If HBO cancels it right now, I won't be upset. If it runs for another 5 seasons, I'll watch. After struggling with these blu ray discs over the weekend, at this point I'm just in it for the LULZ. You have to laugh at the menu design, otherwise you'll throw the box set against the wall and cry.Short Version:There was a flock of dragons, and a very badly designed blu ray menu. That's about it. If you'd like the details, read on.The Blu Ray Discs:I don't know what the DVDs are like, but the blu rays make me mad as a hatter. I have seen complaints from many people who can't get them to load at all. I'm using a Sony BDP-S350 1080p Blu-ray Disc Player that I bought in 2009, and updated my firmware before I even bothered to insert a disc. They do take a very long time to load, but once they were loaded I didn't have problems beyond the confusing menus. Still, be prepared for potential problems.Frustration comes in with menus and having to constantly switch discs for bonus content. Whoever designed the menus, content and storage on these things should be trapped on a desert island with Joffrey Baratheon with no sunscreen. If you're in it just for the show, you should be fine. If you want to watch the extras, just know in advance that you are going to be as confused and frustrated as you are with the Cast of Thousands. Add to that about two dozen copyright notices that appear randomly in different languages after certain featurettes, and you may want to give the discs the same fate as Ned Stark.Some of the extras are on the discs where they say they are, and some of them are not. Let's say you want to watch episode one with commentary. It's on disc one with episode one. Same with episode two. Go to episode three, and it tells you to switch discs to watch episode three commentary. It does this throughout the set, sometimes sending you to the next disc, and sometimes sending you to the previous disc. After a certain point, you've forgotten where you were and you have to stop and figure out what episode you were on, and you wonder whether it's worth getting up 8 times just to get the extras.I was hoping the commentary would give me some more insight into what was going on in the show, but this sadly didn't pan out. The first episode with David Benioff and Dan Weiss does exactly what I wanted. There's another one with one of the directors giving good information, but the rest of the commentary really didn't contribute much. Or maybe I was just too frustrated with the menu to care at that point. Lena Heady pointed out something about Cersei's relationship with Sansa Stark that had not occurred to me, but that's the only useful thing I got out of it.A lot of the featurettes have been available on You Tube on HBO's own channel since the beginning of the series. Still, there are ones I have never seen and found quite interesting, like the making of the opening of the show, so you may find some great content here--if you can find the right disc. So the extra features are quite the mixed bag.Season One:This is a pretty good series, but it's got problems. It's supposed to be high fantasy, but it comes across as more alternate history. I think the rule for fantasy writers these days is to use as little magic as possible, but this series has been stripped of too much. The only hint of magic or otherworldliness comes at the end of the series with the appearance of the dragons. To make up for the lack of magic, they throw in a bunch of "gritty" stuff to make it more "real," and I do mean they throw in everything--rape, incest, prostitution, graphic violence, and a potpourri of other disturbing images and events.Game of Thrones has way too much expository dialogue. It gets bogged down with characters talking about stuff that happened off screen years ago. Most of the time this is done to establish character, even though we already know what the character is like. We may even already know the story and it ends up being a repeat. They just keep talking and talking and will not shut up. Just when you think something is going to happen, someone launches into a long speech about some past traumatic event. Even Tyrion does this, and it's agonizingly long.They even do this during the quintessential HBO sex scenes, which themselves get way out of hand. I know this is HBO, and it's going to be graphic, but there's a point where it turns into bad soft porn and contributes absolutely nothing to story, character or anything else. I know this is why some people tune in, I know some of it is expected, I'm not a prude... it's just that the show takes it beyond the usual levels of absurdity.Then, there are loads and loads of characters--mostly because they keep getting killed off. This is one of those shows where anyone can die. What makes it irritating is that this often comes shortly after we've been told the character's life history and we actually start to care. A lot of times the information turns out to be unimportant, and you wish they had spent the time showing something else... anything else.You literally need to take notes to keep up with what's going on with so many plots and points of view. It's hard to remember all the names and relations. For example, The Lord Commander of the Night's Watch is father to Jorah Mormont. Jorah is the Wikipedia of Westeros who runs around with the Targaryen/Dothraki bunch in the Free Cities, doing a LOT of exposition along the way.Jorah was the one sending information about the Targaryens to the king, which is why he got a royal pardon for selling slaves. He is the one who disgraced the commander, and that's why the commander gave his heirloom sword to Jon Snow. It's hard to follow that in the series because there is so much other stuff going on. You have to watch it 2 or 3 times to get everything out of it. I had to go looking around fan web sites to figure out what was happening sometimes. The show is full of situations like this.In turn, the series progresses very slowly until Ned Stark's pivotal execution scene. The plot moves at the speed of smell until that point, then suddenly you've got battles, kings, hostages and negotiations all over the place. It's just as confusing at the faster pace, if not more so.Ultimately, the characters are the reason I stuck with the series. Peter Dinklage as the dwarf Tyrion Lannister is priceless as the highly intelligent snark knight. He's the only comedy relief in an otherwise exceptionally miserable world. At times I am just waiting for Tyrion to appear on screen and the other stuff is just time filler.Harry Lloyd as Viserys Targaryen was gone too soon, but what a spectacular exit! Fortunately Jack Gleeson as Joffrey Baratheon has stepped in as an entertaining character everyone can love to hate. Neither seems to have any redeeming qualities. I prefer my villains to have some bit of grey or good part to them, and I wish they would show more of Joffrey's human side.Sophie Turner as Sansa Stark is also one of my favorites, but most fans tend to not like her. I think it comes from Sansa's genre blindness and naivety. This changes, and I think it is interesting to see how someone who thinks the world works like fairy tales adjusts to a world as grim as this.I'm rating this series and blu ray set as four stars because I think most people will enjoy the main content. I'm not a huge fan, but I think almost everyone else would do well to give it a try. With so many characters and plots, most people are bound to find some part of the series they will want to follow. You're just going to have a difficult time of it if you want to enjoy the extra features.
summary: Decent show, VERY bad blu rays

reviewText: I picked up a copy of season one of this show after seeing just one commercial for it.  It looked interesting enough and the fact that Sean Bean was in it made this a must buy for me.  So I purchased the first season and popped dvd one into my blu-ray player.  I was totally unprepared for and blown away by what this show had to offer.  This show is definitely not like most of the traditional medieval style fantasy movies/television shows out there.  This show bravely takes a convincing and unflinching look at the characters and their interactions together.  This means that most issues/elements that get dumbed down/sanitized in a lot of fantasy movies/television program is left intact in the this show from the fascinating characters both good and bad, their realistic motivations for doing the things that they are doing even if you don't agree with their methods, clever villains rather than the usual dimwitted ones, and good guys who don't always win regardless of how perilous the situation they find themselves in which to me is a welcome change.  This show also has lots of twists, plenty of political intrigue, superb action, and features some of the best production values I've ever see on a television program.  Season 1 is estimated to have cost 60 million dollars to make and it shows in the various locations featured in the story, the costumes, and overall quality.  All I can say is wow!  I highly recommend giving this show a try you will not be disappointed.
summary: Came for Sean Bean stayed for the story and intriguing characters.

reviewText: I don't have HBO so for the past few years I had not seen this show despite having heard A LOT about it.  I finally broke down and bought the first 2 seasons on DVD, and all I can say is WOW, it sucked me in from the very first episode and would not let me go until I'd finished Season 2!  And then I immediately had to start watching it all over again for a second time!  This show has to be the most epic show ever produced for television.For those unfamiliar with Game of Thrones (GOT), it's a cable TV show based on an as-yet-unfinished fantasy book series by author George R.R. Martin.  It's set in a fantasy world similar in many ways to our own world during ancient Medieval Times in England and Europe.  The notable exception being that dragons, zombies, shapeshifters, witches, warlocks and black magic exist in the fictional GOT world, though MUCH more sparingly than one might assume.  Dragons, zombies and magic seem to be rare and ancient things, almost lost and forgotten in the GOT world.  And their use in the story is handled very craftily and deftly, creating a rare mystique and uniqueness to these often overused fantasy elements.The content is very adult.  Like most dramatic cable TV series being made these days, it is a VERY adult show, with full-frontal nudity and graphic sex and violence.  So not really the kind of show you can enjoy with the family necessarily.  I have no idea why HBO doesn't put out an adult version and a family-safe version.  Seems with some editing and creative camera work, they could easily do both versions.  But for whatever reason they don't.  Nowadays, cable TV is a lot more "adult" than theater movies are.  Oddly, the adult content paradigm has completely switched around--the "bad stuff" now being more on TV than in the movies.  But honestly, the adult content in this show is a relatively small aspect of the show.  Concerning, yes, for families and possible underaged viewers, but it shouldn't dissuade the average adult viewer from seeing this truly remarkable show.The story in GOT is both simple AND exceptionally intricate--opposing comments, I know.  But that's how well this show-based-on-the-books is written.  The writing is spectacular.  At its core, a simple act in the first episode (a boy seeing something he shouldn't) leads to the unraveling of a tenuous peace between three ruling families on an island continent.  Mysteries, deceit and treachery are slowly spun and uncoiled, hidden truths are revealed, and soon the entire continent is building towards a war over a multitude of reasons.  That is a very simple assessment of a VERY complex and extremely engaging story.  But trust me, how it all unfolds is VERY entertaining and fun.  And the story doesn't pander to the audience at all.  In numerous cases I expected the story to go one way and it went the completely opposite way.  So the show challenges the viewer on many levels and is never afraid to pull the rug out from under our feet or add even MORE ongoing characters and storylines to its vast tapestry of epic storytelling.  Again, it all adds to the delicious fun of watching this hugely elaborate story unfold.The cast is enormous and the acting across the board is brilliant at all levels.  And Peter Dinklage in particular is phenomenal.  He stands out even among a cast of spectacular actors.The sets and wardrobe are jaw-dropping.  I've never seen sets or costumes as great as these on any TV show ever.  I don't follow the Emmys, so I don't know if this show has won any yet, but buckloads of Emmys should be rained down on the folks behind these sets and costumes.  We viewers greatly appreciate your hard work and your genius!The editing and camerawork are seamless, beautiful, perfect.  Same with the VFX.  And the exceptional soundtrack.But does all this make it my favorite HBO series?  No.  The Sopranos and Rome are still my all time favorites, but this show is a very close third.  And it's still FAR from over.  The series could end up running for a total of 7 to 10 seasons, so who knows where it will rank by the time it's over.  It might end up being my top fave.One thing's for absolute sure, I can't wait for Season 3 to come out on DVD!
summary: A TRULY REMARKABLE ADULT FANTASY DRAMA

reviewText: I heard a great deal of positive reviews about this series, but I can't understand why. I just viewed the first disc of season one and I won't waste any more time, effort or my money in trying to watch it further. Disc one is long and drawn out and nothing much happens until the last five minutes. The second episode on this disc wasn't much better either. For us, this is a long drawn out series spread out over three seasons and involves way too many characters to keep things straight throughout.Overall, I guess if you're a fan of medieval times, you might enjoy this series, We, however, did not. We'll watch something else that involves less of a commitment.I still can't understand all the hoopla over it, personally.UPDATE: Thought I'd follow up on comments others made about giving this show a chance by watching more than just one episode. As you can see, we watched two. Unfortunately, this show did nothing for us and if we don't like a show by two episodes, why on earth would we want to watch more? Fact is, there just hasn't much on TV worth watching over the last decade and this for us is one of them. That is our opinion, anyway.
summary: Don't understand the hoopla over this show-it's okay. I won't waste any more time with it.

reviewText: I had never read(or even heard of) the A Song of Ice and Fire novel series until this mini-series came out and by the first episode, I was hooked. There are not enough words to describe it. This is such a lush, vivid, dramatic piece of work, with no expense spared. From the writing, to the acting, to the glorious set pieces, costumes and locations, Game of Thrones is one of the best series in years. And being an HBO picture, you know the quality is there already. This is a fantasy series without it ever feeling out of place or too fantastical. The tone is just right.I don't wish to spoil anything regarding this series, but there are HUGE surprises, even from the very first episode. Most of the actors are new-comers, but do such a fantastic job and fit so well with the setting that their inexperience never shows. Sean Bean, the always mysteriously dashing, brooding actor is the main star of this first series. Again, not wanting to spoil anything, I'm just going to say that he will surprise you. Also a refreshing surprise came from the actor Peter Dinklage who plays the dwarf brother and son to a rich, spoiled family, and I would have to say he was my favorite part of the whole series. His quips are spot on and and each scene with him is even better than the last.Basically, if you love drama, intrigue, mystery, suspense, costumes, and great writing; you will love this show. Throw in some incest, sex, deception, murder and outrage and you have a whole new level of magnificence. The synopsis you can read right on the amazon dvd page so there's no point in repeating it, the less you know about it, the better it really is.I started actually reading the first book after the first season ended, and I must say; the writers and directors did a superb job with keeping up with the material. It is not an easy book to adapt. There are tons of different characters, locations and plot twists and even though I saw the show before reading the book, I had no trouble following along, and was quite impressed with how much was actually kept for the show.Easily a five star rated mini-series. Cannot wait for the 2nd season!

reviewText: There is no bad acting here; good music; fantastic production design and costuming; excellent locations.  This is a story of various kingdoms battling each other for power and control over the whole dominion.  Mainly it's the Lannisters vs. the Starks, but there are also people coming from much farther away, and there are Wildlings that commit savagery in the forest, and much more.

reviewText: The whole series and content is fabulous, no complaints there its a 9.5 star show. But who ever created the Menu for this boxset should be FIRED immediately. Worse navigating menu I have ever come across. Viewer should be able to see whats available on the disc not be told after selection load a different disc.....and the loading times, especially the first disc. Look I dont write this review to put you off, you must get the series as I wrote content is fantastic. Am just writing to make you aware as many others have done to be prepared for difficult navigation through the discs. Being aware is forearmed.PS. Boxset is Region Free.

reviewText: Season 1 is pretty close to the book, so I don't know why everyone was so upset when Ned got his head chopped off. I like movies and shows much better when they stay closer to the book. I would advise reading the books before watching any of the Game of Thrones series because then you will know all the side stories and things that are going on. I think if you only watch this and never read the book you would be lost.

reviewerName: Wayne Klein "If at first the idea is not absu...
reviewText: Set in the imaginary Seven Kingdoms protected by an eight hundred foot wall where the Night Watch monitors the wild north for ancient, deadly creatures called the White Walkers, "Game of Thrones" nicely captures the feel of George R. R. Martin's popular fantasy series of novels. Lord Stark (Sean Bean) finds himself pulled unwillingly into the court intrigue of King Robert (Mark Addy)who Stark helped put into power after the Mad King Targaryen executed Stark's grandfather along with thousands of innocent women and children. The King insists that Stark take on the role of Hand of the King to administer and protect the Seven Kingdoms from, among other things, the heir apparent to the throne Viserys Targaryen (Harry Lloyd)who pimps out his own sister (Emilia Clarke)for troops from Khal Drogo (Jason Momoa star of the forthcoming "Conan The Barbarian"). Stark finds himself at odds with the Queen's (Lena Headey)wealthy family including her brutal brother Jaime Lannister(Nikolaj Coster-Waldau who, interestingly enough, appeared in the film "Night Watch")cunning Tyrion (Peter Dinklage)who must survive by his wits because he is a dwarf in a world of warriors.The Blu-ray transfer looks marvelous with a detailed, sharp transfer. The depth to the images are remarkable. The colors range from cold to sunny and warm depending on which of the main characters and lands the sequence is set in.The special features are quite good--we get seven commentary tracks (there are ten episodes of the show)and, unlike a lot of commentary tracks, there's plenty of good information both on the shooting of the episode, how the episode fits into the season and the development of characters, etc.We also get "Episode Guides"--they provide a bit of trivia. "The Complete Guide to Westeros" gives us detailed information on the various families, maps, etc featured in the series. It's a nice interactive feature.The "Character Profiles" features the actors playing the roles discussing their characters."Anatomy of An Episode" gives us considerable insight from the beginning until the conclusion of production on the episode "A Golden Crown" one of the pivotal shows from the ten episode first season."Making 'Game of Thrones'" clocks in at around 30 minutes and is a good "behind-the-scenes" glimpse into the production of the series. As I recall much of this is repurposed from material available from the promo pieces and stuff at the website."The Night's Watch" gives us background on these characters and their mission to protect the realm that is drawn from the novels."Creating The Title Sequence"  and "Creating The Dothaki Language" are interesting featurettes on the creation of the wonderful evocative opening sequence of the show as well as the langauge for the fierce Dothaki that will, later, be so important to the series.We also get quite a few Easter Eggs included as part of this set.Series developers David Benioff (novelist and screenwriter of "The Kite Runner" and "Wolverine")and D.B. Weiss manage to stay true to what made Martin's marvelously detailed novels so popular with readers while making the show visually appealing to viewers. The series does have a convoluted plot so if you miss an episode it's wise to try and catch up by actually watching what you've missed.I'm hoping that the show continues to develop in popularity so it doesn't face the same fate of "Rome", "Carnivale" and "Deadwood" all three shows that were rich in character development, plot and visually stunning shows that HBO cancelled without allowing them to fully develop. The ten episodes of the first season are filled with enough twists and turns for a 24 episode normal TV show.The strong performances from Bean, Dinklage, Headey and others in the case make their characters rich, appealing, appalling and sympathetic at turns. The stylish direction and visually rich production design only add to the appeal of the series which has just begun to develop more of the fantasy elements towards the end of the first season.I can recommend "Game of Thrones" based on viewing the HBO series and although I have no idea what special features HBO has for the Blu-ray or DVD set yet, even without those extras, this show is essential viewing.
summary: A glimpse into the fantasy world of the Seven Kingdoms and those willing to do anything to take/keep power

reviewText: Well, unfortunately, once started I couldn't quit watching The Game of Thrones.  I just finished watching Season Two and am looking forward to being able to purchase Season Three in February, 2014.  The HBO special was so good, I also decided to purchase the Kindle version of the books.  So far, the Kindle version parallels the series quite accurately, further demonstrating how faithful to the books the HBO series is.  Of course, there are some relatively minor changes as would be expected, but so far nothing that dramatic. I'm not normally very much into this kind of fantasy stuff in the first place, but the acting and writing (in both the books and the series) is so outstanding that I haven't been able to simply walk away and forget it.  The only problem I have is that all my favorite characters keep getting killed off and I find myself badly wanting Joffrey's head on a platter along with his creepy evil queen mother.  That means that they are doing a great job of acting.The actual content of the DVD gets a 5 star rating, but I have knocked off a star because of the convoluted menu system used on the DVD.  It is designed so that you can't easily select a given chapter.  That is completely unacceptable in this day and age when a simple chapter selection menu is the norm.  Other than that, the quality of the Blu-Ray DVD is excellent.  There are also several other features of this set, such as a complete guide to Westeros, an anatomy of episode six ("A Golden Crown"), a 'making of' feature and so forth.Despite the crummy menu system, I would still recommend this set.  Game of Thrones is, in my opinion, one of the best adult Television series ever devised.  However, if you are offended by nudity and/or violence, avoid this series.  This is strictly mature adult material and should be treated as such. Please be advised.
summary: I'm addicted but dislike the disc menu system

reviewText: Some movies are for entertainment and some for analysis.  This movie is both.  If you are a history major, pay close attension to details as even history book writers could miss a bunch.  Who is the true son and who is the Hagar child? You can be totally loyal and honest and still loose your head.  They didn't cut any corners on cast or props.  Only their accountant experiences true Excedren Headaches.  The headsman must put Alcohol in the Grass as the horses really get a work out. Today's congress would say the need Claymore control.

reviewText: I absolutely love game of thrones.  After watching a few episodes of the first season I was hooked.  Sadly at the time I had to travel overseas before I could finish the first season.  So I cheated and actually got all the ebooks and read them while I was gone working for a few months.  I actually have read all of them up to the last that George Martin finished which is A Dance With Dragons I believe.  It's been a while.Anyway if you are a fan of mid evil style action and the usual HBO high drama then this is a show for you.  I have yet to meet anyone that has not liked it.  I will admit the television show strays slightly from the books but not in a bad way at all.  For the most part the story line stays intact according to the books.  So far anyway....Great show watch it.
